:mentalKLINIK,http://ivde.net/artists/mentalklinik_1/biography</Address>
:mentalKLINIK is an artist duo from <Location>Istanbul</Location> composed of Yasemin Baydar (B.<Date>1972</Date>, İstanbul) and Birol Demir (B.1967, <Location>Ankara</Location>) who began their collaborative works in <Date>1998</Date>, forming an open laboratory to reconsider process, production and presentation. Their studio has functioned as a space for dialogue and they enrich their process by engaging other artists and professionals in fields ranging from chemistry to industrial engineering.
The collaborative resist the limitations posed by a singular vocabulary or style and craft material and digital technologies into works that seem to belong to anticipated aesthetics. Their works range from immersive time based works and installations to sculptures and objects that thwart categorization. Publications often accompany projects to reflect their interactive process, and include a form of documentation seeking to explore concepts and contexts pertaining to emotions, behaviour, viewpoints and senses.
Their work also engages the public in live and embodied installations. Terribly Jolly (<Location>Istanbul</Location>, <Date>2013</Date>) for example is a pop-up dance club contained within a small red curtained room that begins at nine am and lasts just thirty minutes, folding together the time of work and leisure to cut short any possibility of shared pleasure. By contrast FRESHCUT (<Organization>Museum of Applied Arts</Organization>, <Location>Vienna</Location>, <Date>2013</Date>) invites the audience to cut and arrange a massive installation of flowers, transforming them into actors in an augmented cinematic reality.

Abbas Akhavan,http://www.thethirdline.com/artists/abbas-akhavan/biography/</Address>
Abbas Akhavan's practice ranges from site-specific ephemeral installations to drawing, video and performance. The domestic sphere, as a forked space between hospitality and hostility, has been an ongoing area of research in Abbas' work. More recent works have shifted focus, wandering onto spaces just outside the home – the garden, the backyard, and other domesticated landscapes.
Residencies include Foundation Marcelino Botin with Mona Hatoum (<Location>Spain</Location>), <Organization>Le Printemps de Septembre (France)</Organization>, <Location>Trinity Square</Location> Video, <Location>Western Front</Location>, and <Location>Fogo Islands</Location> (<Location>Canada</Location>), The <Organization>Watermill Center (USA)</Organization>, and The <Organization>Delfina Foundation (Dubai</Organization>, <Location>UAE</Location> & <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location>). Recent exhibitions include: 'Variations on a <Location>Garden</Location>', Galerie Mana, <Location>Istanbul</Location> (<Date>2013</Date>); 'Study for a <Location>Garden</Location>', <Organization>Delfina Foundation</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>); 'Tactics for Here & Now', <Location>Bucharest</Location> Biennale, <Location>Bucharest</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>); 'Tools for Conviviality' <Organization>Power Plant</Organization>, <Location>Toronto</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>); 'Beacon', Darling Foundry, <Location>Montreal</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>); 'Phantomhead', Performa 11, <Location>New York</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>); 'Seeing is Believing', <Organization>KW Institute</Organization> for Contemporary Art, <Location>Berlin</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>). Abbas is the recipient of Kunstpreis <Location>Berlin</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>), and Abraaj Captial Art Prize (<Date>2014</Date>).
He lives and works in <Location>Toronto</Location>, <Location>Canada</Location>.

Abbas Kiarostami
Filmmaker,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/k/kiarostami-abbas</Address>
Abbas Kiarostami graduated from university with a degree in fine arts before starting work as a graphic designer. Later joining the Centre for Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults he initiated a film section, which launched his career as a filmmaker at the age of 30. An active filmmaker since <Date>1970</Date>, Kiarostami has been involved in over forty films including shorts and documentaries. Among his most critically successful works as director are what came to be known as the Koker Trilogy (Where Is the Friend's Home?, <Date>1987</Date>, And Life Goes On (a.k.a. Life and Nothing More, <Date>1992</Date>) and Through the Olive Trees, <Date>1994</Date>), A Taste of Cherry (<Date>1997</Date>), The Wind Will Carry Us (<Date>1999</Date>) and his innovative <Date>2008</Date> film Shirin which was screened at Past of the Coming Days. Amongst many other honours, Kiarostami has been awarded a Palme d'Or, <Location>Cannes</Location> Festival (<Date>1997</Date>), Silver Lion, <Location>Venice</Location> Film Festival (<Date>1999</Date>), Gold Leopard of Honour, Locarno Film Festival (<Date>2005</Date>) and Glory to the Filmmaker Award, <Location>Venice</Location> Film Festival (<Date>2008</Date>). His <Date>2010</Date> film Certified Copy was screened that year at <Location>Cannes</Location> earning its lead, Juliette Binoche, a best actress award.
Abbas Kiarostami was born in <Location>Tehran</Location> in <Date>1940</Date>. He is also a poet, photographer, painter and illustrator.
<Date>November 2010</Date>

Abdelfattah Kilito
Writer,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/k/kilito-abdelfattah</Address>
Esteemed writer and academic Abdelfattah Kilito was born in <Date>1945</Date> in <Location>Rabat</Location>, <Location>Morocco</Location>. 
His lecture titled Thou Shalt Not Translate Me, followed on from the topic of his well-known book Thou Shalt Not Speak My Language ( <Organization>Sysracuse University Press</Organization>, <Date>2002</Date>). In his work Kilito '. . . disrupts dominant modes of Arabic literary scholarship and challenges us . . . to reexamine contemporary notions of translation, bilingualism, postcoloniality, the pedagogy of world literature, and the discipline of comparative literature."*
Kilito studied at the Faculty of Arts and Human Sciences in <Location>Rabat</Location> and obtained his doctorate on the narrative and cultural patterns in the works of Alhmdani and AlHariri from the new University of Sorbonne in <Date>1982</Date>. He has been a Professor of Arts at <Organization>Mohamed V University</Organization>, <Location>Rabat</Location>, since 1968 and Visiting Professor at several European and <Origin>American</Origin> universities, including the <Organization>University of Bordeaux</Organization> and the Sorbonne, the Collège de <Location>France</Location>, <Location>Princeton</Location> University and <Organization>Harvard University</Organization>. Kilito has received several literary awards among which are the Great <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> Award (<Date>1989</Date>); Atlas Award (<Date>1996</Date>); <Organization><Origin>French</Origin> Academy</Organization> Award (<Date>1996</Date>); Sultan Al Owais Prize, Criticism & Literature Studies (<Date>2006-06</Date>). He is the author of both fiction and literary criticism with some of his works translated into other languages including <Origin>English</Origin>, <Origin>French</Origin>, <Origin>German</Origin>, <Origin>Spanish</Origin> and <Origin>Italian</Origin>.
Works (selected):La Querelle des images, <Location>Casablanca</Location>, Editions Eddif, <Date>1995</Date>.La Langue d’Adam;<Location>Casablanca</Location>, Ed. Toubkal, <Date>1995</Date>.En quête, <Location>Montpellier</Location>, Editions Fata Morgana, <Date>1999</Date>.Le Cheval de Nietzsche, Editions Le Fennec, <Date>2007</Date>.Les Arabes et l’art du récit, Editions Sindbad-Actes Sud, <Date>2009</Date>.Dites-moi le songe, Editions Sindbad-Actes Sud, <Date>2010</Date>.
* Quoted from the Translator's Introduction to Thou Shalt Not Speak My Language by Waïl S. Hassan, <Organization>Syracuse University Press</Organization>, 2002<Date>October 2010</Date>

Abdul Qadir al-Rassam,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Abdul-Qadir-al-Rassam.aspx</Address>
Abdul Qadir al-Rassam (<Date>1882 - 1952</Date>) was part of the first generation of modern <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> painters. He stands at the core of a group of artists trained in <Location>Istanbul</Location> who brought their artistic knowledge back to their home country. This group of soldier-artists is credited with introducing easel painting to <Location>Iraq</Location> at the turn of the century. Working in a realist style, al-Rassam is known for his sweeping landscapes, immaculate portraits, and faithful portrayals of everyday life in <Location>Iraq</Location>. He is one of the most prominent and prolific painters in <Location>Iraq</Location>'s modern art history and his work heavily influenced the generations that followed.
Al-Rassam was among a group of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> officers to study military science and art in <Location>Istanbul</Location>. He began his education around 1904 when the Ottoman Empire was still the main power in the region. As part of his education in <Location>Istanbul</Location>, al-Rassam and his classmates were required to produce paintings or drawings for military use. These images adhered to a strict European academic style. Eager to cultivate their new skill, these officers sought out private art training. Al-Rassam himself studied under a number of prominent painters living in <Location>Istanbul</Location> who worked in contemporary <Origin>French</Origin> styles. Although he is most recognizable as an oil painter, al-Rassam experimented at this time with watercolors representing <Location>Istanbul</Location> with its crowds and markets. Even at this early stage in his career, the painter showed expert skill and a conscientious eye. Al-Rassam's ambitions were interrupted by the outbreak of WWI. Directly following the war, when the group of soldier-artists returned to <Location>Iraq</Location>, al-Rassam again took up easel painting. Along with his colleagues, he focused on landscapes, military scenes, and archaeological sites. 
An important characteristic of this initial generation was their desire to stimulate awareness and appreciation of the arts amongst the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> population. Al-Rassam taught painting lessons out of his studio in <Location>Baghdad</Location> and encouraged young artists to continue their art training abroad. Due to this early artistic proselytizing, al-Rassam became hugely influential to the following generations of artists. The painter's interest in promoting art awareness was further realized when he became an honorary member of the <Organization>Society of the Friends</Organization> of Art, a group that sought to cultivate public interest in art making and to enhance their own skill through interaction.    
Utilizing the same academic style as his early colleagues, al-Rassam painted with a crisp realism capturing vistas of the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> countr​yside. The clarity found in oil paints is employed to its fullest advantage by the artist, who is known for his mastery of perspective and detail. He oftentimes painted panoramic views of historical sites along the <Location>Tigris River</Location>. The ruins of Ctesiphon or the Great Mosque of Samarra were particularly notable representations in al-Rassam's oeuvre. Indeed the <Location>Tigris River</Location> was itself the central theme of many of al-Rassam's canvases. Winding as it recedes through an expert use of atmospheric perspective, the river and the activities surrounding it compose a vast, yet serene, landscape.
Al-Rassam was also to a lesser extent a portraitist. One of his well-known portraits is of Mohamed Darouich al-Allousi, completed in <Date>1924</Date>. The bearded sitter gazes out at the viewer with a directed stare. He is set against a background of clouds that are ever-present in most of al-Rassam's canvases. The subtleties of the face show the painter's mastery of modeling and the poignant gaze reflect his skill as a keen observer. The portrait exhibits the same attention to clarity and detail as al-Rassam's landscapes.
A collection of al-Rassam's works was held at the <Organization>Pioneers Museum</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> and the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> until the destruction and the looting of the collection of the museum in <Date>2003</Date>. He also created a mural for the entrance of a movie theater in <Location>Baghdad</Location>, The Royal Cinema. This was the first large-scale work of art to be displayed on a public building. Later in his life, the artist travelled to <Location>Italy</Location>, <Location>France</Location>, <Location>Germany</Location>, and <Location>England</Location> to expand his knowledge of art.

Abdulaziz Ashour,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdulazizashour.html</Address>

Abdulhalim Radwi
Radawi,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdulhalimradwi.html</Address>
Abdulhalim Radwi (<Date>1939-2006</Date>) (also: Radawi) from <Location>Makkah</Location> was a painter, poet and sculptor in <Location>Jeddah</Location> and a pioneer of contemporary arts in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. He was one of the first <Origin>Saudi</Origin>'s to go abroad for an art education and held a <Organization>BA</Organization> degree from the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> (<Date>1964</Date>).
Radwi started his career as a teacher of fine arts in <Location>Makkah</Location> but became much involved with the government of arts. From <Date>1968-1974</Date> he was director of the <Location>Jeddah</Location> centre for fine arts and later (<Date>1980-1992</Date>) director-general of the culture and arts city of <Location>Jeddah</Location>.
In <Date>1973</Date> Radwi spent time in <Location>Madrid</Location> were he was action director of the <Organization>Association of Arab</Organization> artists. In <Date>1979</Date> Radwi graduated from the royal arts academy in <Location>Madrid</Location>. He was awarded many art prizes and honours while he spent much time abroad organizing as many as 105 exhibitions. 
His family maintain a website with some of his work and say it can also be seen in museums of modern art in <Location>Jordan</Location>, <Location>Brazil</Location>, Marocco, <Location>Spain</Location> and <Location>Tunisia</Location>.
In Riyadh Hewar Gallery in <Date>2008</Date> offer watercolours and an oil painting. Christie's at an international modern & contemporary art sales in <Location>Dubai</Location> on <Date>October 30, 2008</Date> will auction Still Life (<Date>1956</Date>). Radwi signed this work twice: in 'latin' on the lower left and in arabic on the lower right.
Radwi's paintings dealt mostly with <Origin>Saudi</Origin> lifestyle and he is said to have believed that <Origin>Saudi</Origin> artists must always keep an eye on their national identity. His two personal favorite paintings were thus Recitation of Quran, which won a prize at the <Date>1988</Date> Biennale in <Location>Spain</Location>, and Old Buildings in <Location>Makkah</Location>, which he refused to sell for half a million <Origin>Saudi</Origin> riyals and kept in his personal museum in <Location>Jeddah</Location>.

Abdullah Al Saadi,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/s/saadi-abdullah-al</Address>
 
b. 1967, Khorfakkan, <Location>United Arab Emirates</Location>
Lives and works in Khorfakkan
Abdullah Al Saadi is a <Date>1993</Date> graduate of the <Organization>United Arab Emirates University</Organization>, Al Ain and holds a <Organization>BA</Organization> degree in <Origin>English</Origin> Literature. <Date>From 1994 to 1996</Date> he studied <Origin>Japanese</Origin> painting at <Organization>Kyoto Seika University</Organization> in <Location>Japan</Location>. Al Saadi’s work ranges from painting, drawing, the creation of lengthy artist’s notebooks, to the collection and systemic categorisation of found objects, and the invention of new alphabets. A great affinity with nature and rural life informs his practice, which explores the changing environment as well as personal and cultural history. He has exhibited internationally and regionally including; Emirati Expressions: Realised at <Organization>Manarat Al Saadiyat</Organization>, <Location>Abu Dhabi</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location>(<Date>2013</Date>); Body Art and Performance in <Location>the Gulf</Location> Area: 16 artists at <Organization>New York University Abu Dhabi</Organization>, <Location>UAE</Location> (<Date>2013</Date>); <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> 10, <Location>Sharjah</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>); 54th International Art Exhibition of the <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Venice</Location>, <Location>Italy</Location>(<Date>2011</Date>); ADACH Platform at the 53rd International Art Exhibition of the <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Venice</Location>, <Location>Italy</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>); Languages of the Desert at <Organization>Kunstmuseum Bonn</Organization>, <Location>Germany</Location> (<Date>2005</Date>); the 26th <Organization>São Paulo Biennial</Organization>, <Location>Sao</Location> Paolo, <Location>Brazil</Location> (<Date>2004</Date>); <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> 5, <Location>Sharjah</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location> (<Date>2003</Date>), 5/U.A.E., The Art of the Five from the <Location>United Arab Emirates</Location> at the Ludwig Forum for International Art, Aachen, <Location>Germany</Location> (<Date>2002</Date>).

Abdullah Al-Ogaili ,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdullaalogaili.html</Address>
Abdullah Al-Ogaili is a professional photographer who's work was selected for the Al Mohtaraf publication Young <Origin>Saudi</Origin> Lenses (<Date>2011</Date>). A large and colorful image of Al Salam Park in <Location>Riyadh</Location> and a smaller still life of four traditional pots both celebrated the decorative side of human life. A similar observation when studying work the artist has posted on Flickr. Finding beauty in everyday spaces, such as in a hospital operation room, is an art not many people master. Al-Ogaili does however. Add a slight touch of color to your life and the artist might come and take your portrait. He has won at least one prize abroad with his portrait photography and shows a number of serious portraits of shaikhs and business leaders online. The portrait that we enjoyed the most was that of a man and a collection of parrots. (AH, <Date>8 May 2013</Date>).

Abdullah Hammas,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdullahhammas.html</Address>
Abdullah Hammas (Abha, 1953) was a prepschool art teacher for 31 years after graduating from the <Organization>Riyadh Institute of Arts</Organization> in <Date>1973</Date>. He is one of seven artists supported by the <Organization>Al Mansouria Foundation</Organization> and is credited by them to be among the first painters to have pushed the limits of traditional and decorative painting and to have embarked on an abstract quest to link colours and materials to his homeland.
The square paintings he mostly makes are colourful and sometimes adapted to the venture where they are sold. In Riyadh they are mature and serious in nature and do not venture beyond abstract forms. In Al-Khobar he is on show in the Arab Heritage Gallery with a slightly later birthdate (<Date>1955</Date>) and with brighter colours, clearer lines and human forms. There too are for sale his Abha panels which are vertical columns measuring 30x245 cm that contain 8 small but very bright paintings. 
Hammas has had many personal exhibitions in galleries in KSA and has also ventured out to <Location>Paris</Location> and <Location>Rabat</Location>. His paintings have found their way to public collections in the <Location>Middle East</Location>, <Location>Europe</Location> and the <Location>U.S.A.</Location>

Abdullah Nawawi,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdullahnawawy.html</Address>
Abdullah Nawawi is a painter of colourful abstraction from <Location>Jeddah</Location>, who is (<Date>2009</Date>) manager of the <Organization>Plastic Art Committee</Organization> of the <Organization>Ministry of Culture</Organization> and <Organization>Information</Organization>'s <Organization><Origin>Saudi Arabian</Origin> Association of Arts</Organization> and <Organization>Culture</Organization>. He also stated that his country needed two large gallery's in <Location>Riyadh</Location> and <Location>Jeddah</Location> to build permanent collections. he compliments the government fro financing artists and buying art for embassies abroad.

I selected the collage like paintings here because they betray knowledge and adaption of such artists as Michaelangelo and Delacroix. (<Date>2009</Date>).

Abdulnasser Al-Amri,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdulnasseralamri.html</Address>

Although Al-Amri painted he told Arab News he concentrates on the concept of his painting and thinks it is unfortunate that not more styles of modern art are exhibited in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. (<Date>2009</Date>).

Abdulnasser Gharem's,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-abdulnassergharem.html</Address>
Abdulnasser Gharem's (<Date>1973</Date>) mission is to restore behaviour to a higher standard, remembered from the past, while taking into account new technologies and insights. The artist from the town of <Location>Khamis</Location> Mushait is a luitenant-colonel of artillery (now in administration), who aims at the brains and not the bone structure of life's realities. Do not put your trust in concrete, when planning battles of the future, is what Gharem says by selecting his own ground to fire from with weapons of his choice. The training shows. The 'art people' call it performance art. People of performance might call it art of survival.
Gharem entered the field at the <Location>Sharjah</Location> <Date>2007</Date> biennial documenting a 'survival' performance Flora and Fauna (<Date>2006</Date>) in which he wrapped himself in plastic with a tree on a busy road in the town of <Location>Abha</Location>. He stayed in his greenhouse for several hours living of the oxygen that the tree was meant to produce. The foreign imported Conocarpus Erectus tree is much used in city landscaping in the <Location>Middle East</Location> and elsewhere, but is said to have a disastrous effect on the local tree population. Dealing directly with ecological concerns of urban planning the performance in a much broader sense may have reflected on the dangers of thoughtless adoption of foreign ideas.
'People at first thought he was crazy,' is what Gharem told Henry Hemming in an interview for the <Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization> (<Date>2008</Date>) exhibition. But then they started to appreciate his operations on the roads of <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. 'Their minds are not closed so they came over to ask about it.' Reforming people's ideas about art away from copying Italians may be collateral damage his work inflicts.
Another maneuvre of speed and impact was in support not of flora but of Homo Erectus himself. In Manzoa (<Date>2007</Date>) Gharem moved himself around for a day and night in a so called 'unorganized residential district' from which both the residents and houses were to be removed for new development. The name of the performance is Arabic for 'removal.' It was written on the houses to announce their fate and that of their residents and the artist had it written on his shirt during the performance.
From chance of seeing a broken bridge and learning its history Gharem welded his conceptually most voluptuous work. Al-Siraat was made in the night of <Date>August 19, 2007</Date> when the artist and his assistents covered the whole bridge with one word: al-siraat (the path). The bridge, which is in a ravine in the Tihama region, had been abandoned since it collapsed in <Date>1982</Date>. Its tragic history is that it was used by people, trusting the concrete, as a refuge to shelter from an expected flash flood. From the idea that even concrete roads and bridges can't be trusted Gharem crossed over to associate the bridge with 'the path' in the spiritual sense of the word. 'It is about the choices you make in life, and whether or not you follow the straight path,' is what he said about it. The work was documented by photography and in a video with a touch of irony.
Al-Siraat became part of a controversy in the <Origin>British</Origin> press when it was reported that the work had not been included in the <Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization> exhibition by a decision unclearly defined as having been taken by either a sponsor, guest curators or The <Organization>School of Oriental and African Studies</Organization>.
In both a visual and conceptual parallel to Al Siraat Gharem produced an alternative work of art for the exhibition intended to convey a similar message. For his Restored Behavior (<Date>2008</Date>) series the artist went on a humoristic adventure of subverting bureaucracy by buying in shops all over <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location> as many office stamps as he could find. Taking out the rubber letters and numbers, glueing them on boards and then painting over them a yellow road line he created anew an image of 'the path.' Not having yourself stamped but painting your own way over stamps is not unlike 'not trusting concrete.' In the paintings the bridge crossing the ravine was changed by Gharem into a Pedestrian Crossing. And like the bridge the crossing collapsed: the two stripes of the Zebra contained an image of the Twin Towers at the moment of impact of the second airplane. As a final salvo of his serious intentions Gharem produced an oversized and useable stamp which read in both hope and irony and in both Arabic and <Origin>English</Origin>: 'Have a bit of commitment, Amin.' With it were three road lights to guide you in the dark. Using science in darkness may be the concept.
His motto: 'I will'

Abdulnasser Gharem,http://nadour.org/artists/abdulnasser-gharem/</Address>
Art of Survival – this stands as a kind of preliminary statement to all the work of this artist born in <Date>1973</Date> in <Location>Khamis Mushait</Location>, <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. Abdulnasser Gharem is surely the only artist to be both a leading figure on his country’s emerging art scene and a major in the <Origin>Saudi</Origin> army.
His story began in <Date>2003</Date> when Abdulnasser Gharem, an army recruit, enrolled in the Al-Miftaha <Location>Arts Village</Location> in <Location>Abha</Location>, <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. Founded a few years earlier by Ahmed Mater, this institution soon became the nerve centre of the new art scene that was represented in the <Date>2004</Date> exhibition Shattah, which captured the renewal of the <Origin>Saudi Arabian</Origin> scene.
From now on, Gharem began using the street as his studio, working in response to his local context. In numerous performances and site-specific installations he drew attention to ecological, geographical, urban and societal issues, recording his actions on video or in photographs. At the same time he was working on a series of stamp paintings in which major events are juxtaposed with the excesses of a bureaucratic system that seems capable of expressing itself only by rubberstamping.
Acclaimed by international critics and now recognised in the <Location>Middle East</Location>, his work was presented at the 53rd <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization> in <Date>2009</Date> and at the 8th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> in <Date>2007</Date>. His works have been seen in <Location>Venice</Location>, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>Berlin</Location> and <Location>Riyad</Location> as part of exhibitions organised by <Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization>.

Adam Henein,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Adam-Henein.aspx</Address>
Adam Henein was born in <Location>Cairo</Location> into a family of silversmiths from Asyut and grew up in the neighborhood of Bab al-Shaariyya. He was eight years old when he discovered the <Organization><Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Museum of Antiquities</Organization> during a class visit, which he would later recall as a turning point in his life. At the age of twenty, he decided to become a sculptor and joined the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. After he graduated in <Date>1953</Date>, he traveled to Upper <Location>Egypt</Location> and spent several months at the <Location>Luxor</Location> Atelier established in <Date>1941</Date> by the Alexandrian painter and diplomat Mohammed Naghi (<Date>1888 - 1956</Date>) to promote the study of ancient <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> art as part of the curriculum of art schools in <Location>Egypt</Location>.
In 1957, he received a scholarship for two years to pursue his studies at the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Munich</Location>. During one of his exhibitions in <Date>1960</Date>, he met the anthropologist Afaf al-Dib, who became his wife and supporter as both manager and critic at the beginning of his career. Henein established his home and studio in <Date>1968</Date> in a mud brick house built by architect Ramsis Wissa Wassef (<Date>1911 - 1974</Date>) in the village of <Location>Harraniyya</Location>. In <Date>1971</Date>, Henein and his wife moved to <Location>Paris</Location>, where they stayed for twenty-five years. During that period, he dedicated himself to his art in his studio in the fifteenth arrondissement near Porte de Sèvres. By the time he returned to <Location>Egypt</Location> in <Date>1996</Date>, Henein was an internationally recognized artist. <Date>From 1989 to 1998</Date>, he worked with the <Organization>Ministry of Culture</Organization> in restoring the Sphinx in Giza. In <Date>1996</Date>, he founded the <Organization>Aswan International</Organization> Sculpture Symposium, an annual workshop and exhibition inviting sculptors from around the world to experiment and create works from the local granite.
Adam Henein is one of the most prominent contemporary sculptors of the Arab World. Throughout his career, he produced a considerable number of large and small-scale pieces, using a variety of materials, such as granite, bronze, plaster, limestone and terracotta. His early works embody the graceful solidity of ancient <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> statuary and express a sense of simplicity in the treatment of mass and volumes. They recall ancient sculptures, such as the scribe commonly known as the "Sheikh el-Balad," now at the <Organization><Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Museum of Antiquities</Organization>, as well as the works of Mahmoud Mokhtar (<Date>1891 - 1934</Date>). During the 1960's, Henein sculpted a series of animals, such as birds, cats, dogs, owls, goats, horses and donkeys, expressing just their minimal and essential lines and features. 
The beginning of the <Date>1970</Date>'s marked an important evolution in his art, as a result of being exposed to the work of modern sculptors in <Location>Paris</Location>, such as Brancusi. Even though Henein never belonged to a specific movement, he was inspired by their freedom of interpretation. During the <Date>1980</Date>'s, abstract forms, pure volumes and the dynamic of movement characterize his sculptures, centered on the themes of sun and moon disks, as well as vertical ascension. In the <Date>1990</Date>'s, he worked on several outdoor large-scale sculptures, including The Ship, conceived as a metaphorical alternative to the museum space. Overall, his work embodies a sense of simple monumentality and timelessness.
Henein has held many individual exhibitions in <Location>Cairo</Location>, <Location>Alexandria</Location>, <Location>Amsterdam</Location>, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>Paris</Location>, and <Location>Rome</Location>, and participated in numerous group exhibitions around the world. His works can be seen at his Museum in <Location>Harraniyya</Location> inaugurated in <Date>January 2014</Date>, the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> Art in <Location>Cairo</Location>, as well as at Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>, which includes his monumental sculpture of The Ship located in front of its entrance.

Adeel Uz Zafar,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/49-adeel-uz-zafar/overview/</Address>
Adeel uz Zafar is known for his unique and meticulous scratching technique. His early practice involved engraving exposed photographic sheets with a paper cutter which was the base of his empirical observation and the development of his technique. Today Zafar works in minute detail on a large scale of black plastic vinyl sheets featuring gauzed stuffed animal toys completely alien to traditional <Origin>Pakistani</Origin> society. Zafar's work is both terrifying and amusing. His subject matters wrapped in bandages evoke childhood anxiety, turning comforting objects into monstrous figures. He gives his work a sinister feel by bandaging his objects and hiding them from view hinting to the loss of innocence and to the disintegration of the socio-political framework in <Location>Pakistan</Location> and to the pain that results.
Adeel uz Zafar was born in <Location>Karachi</Location>, <Location>Pakistan</Location> in <Date>1975</Date>. In <Date>2012</Date>, Zafar showed at Pulse Art Fair, <Location>NY</Location> and took part in a group exhibition titled Stop, Play, Pause, Repeat at <Organization>Lawrie Shabibi</Organization>. Most recently, the artist has been invited by the Parramatta Artist Studios in collaboration with <Organization>Cicada Press</Organization> (COFA, UNSW) for an international print making residency from <Date>15 April</Date> - <Date>17 May 2013</Date>.

Adel Abdessemed,http://nadour.org/artists/adel-abdessemed/</Address>
Since the end of the ‘nineties, Adel Abdessemed has tackled the “problem areas” of our multicultural and globalised world with great intelligence. He confronts politics in a very personal way in order to highlight questions of morality and identity, both in the West and in the Muslim world.
His work, which includes installations, videos, photography, sculpture, drawings and book-work, is always visually effective without being at all literal. A blend of references to everyday situations with literary, mythological and philosophical allusions and symbols, his art holds for him the power to transform society in the sense that it in fact opposes a resistance to the conventional or the norm.
Of Kabyle descent, Adel Abdessemed was born in <Date>1971</Date> in <Location>Constantine</Location>, <Location>Algeria</Location>. He studied Fine <Organization>Art</Organization> at <Location>Batna</Location> and then in <Location>Algiers</Location>. Forced into exile in <Date>1994</Date> by mounting Islamist violence, he trained at the <Organization>College of Fine Art</Organization> in <Location>Lyon</Location>. In <Date>2001</Date>, he took part in the International Studio Programme at the <Organization>PS</Organization>1 <Organization>Contemporary Art Centre</Organization> in <Location>New York</Location>.
Many museums and modern art centres all over the world have devoted solo exhibitions to the artist: MAMCO in <Location>Geneva</Location>, the Magasin de <Location>Grenoble</Location>, the Kunstverein in <Location>Heidelberg</Location>, the <Organization>Institute of Art</Organization> in <Location>San Francisco</Location> as well as the <Organization>Parasol Unit Foundation</Organization> for <Organization>Contemporary</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>London</Location>. From <Date>2001</Date> Abdessemed has also contributed to a number of biennials and triennials, which includes those in <Location>Yokohama</Location>, <Location>Tirana</Location>, <Location>Venice</Location>, <Location>Istanbul</Location>, <Location>Lyon</Location>, <Location>Havana</Location> and <Location>Sydney</Location>.

Adel Abidin,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/71-adel-abidin/overview/</Address>
Abidin is a visual artist whose projects, whilst focused on global social, political, and cultural issues, traverse a complex landscape of identity, memory, exile, violence and war. Taking specific actions or objects out of their initial context he turns them on their head, creating ironic, darkly humorous and often absurdist responses, exploring issues such as cultural alienation and distorted realities. His video and sculptural installations often reference pop culture, racial stereotypes and traditional icons, designing tense situations of confrontation and dialogue that truly engage the viewer.
 In <Date>March 2013</Date> <Organization>Lawrie Shabibi</Organization> hosted the critically acclaimed solo exhibition 'Symphony' curated by Basak Senova, which included the ambitious sculpture Al Warqaa commissioned by the <Organization>Barjeel Art Foundation</Organization>. The same month he held a solo exhibition 'Blueprint' at <Organization>Maraya Arts Centre</Organization>, curated by Sara Raza. In <Date>2011</Date> he was part of <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> 10 and his video installation Three Love Songs was a highlight of the inaugural exhibition at <Organization>Mathaf Arab Museum of Arab Art</Organization>, <Location>Doha</Location>, 'Told/Untold/Retold' curated by Sam Bardouil and Till Fellrath.  
Adel Abidin (b. <Location>Baghdad</Location>, <Date>1973</Date>) received a bachelor's degree in Painting from the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> in <Date>2000</Date> and a Master's degree in <Organization>Media and New Media</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization> from the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Helsinki</Location>, <Location>Finland</Location> in <Date>2005</Date> where he continues to live and work.
Abidin has exhibited in numerous group and solo exhibitions, in <Date>2014</Date>: 'Between Us, Video <Organization>Art</Organization> from the <Location>Middle East</Location> and <Location>North Africa</Location> in a Global World', <Organization>Etopia Center</Organization> for <Organization>Art and Technology</Organization>, <Location>Zaragoza</Location>; 'Cover-up!', Al Sultan <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Kuwait</Location>; 'Life is Short, Let's Have an Affair', Muu <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Helsinki</Location>; 'Simple past, perfect futures', Le CENQUATRE-<Location>PARIS</Location>, <Location>Paris</Location>; 'Music Palace', <Organization>Boghossian Foundation</Organization>, Villa Empain, <Location>Brussels</Location>;  'Shifting Identities', MACRO, <Location>Rome</Location>; 'Collective Reaction', <Organization>Station Museum</Organization>, <Location>Houston</Location>; '<Organization>Arab</Organization> Contemporary', <Organization>Louisiana Museum of Modern Art</Organization>, Humlebaek; 'Here and Elswhere', <Organization>New Museum</Organization>, <Location>New York</Location>; 'Songs of Loss and Songs of Love', <Organization>Gwangiu Museum of Art</Organization>, <Location>South Korea</Location>; 'Late Modern and Contemporary <Organization>Art</Organization>', <Organization>National Gallery of Victoria</Organization>, <Location>Melbourne</Location>. Previously he has taken part in The <Organization>Helsinki KIASMA Museum of Contemporary Art</Organization>, The <Organization>DA</Organization>2 Domus Atrium <Date>2002</Date> <Organization>Centre of Contemporary Art</Organization> (Salamanca), Location One <Organization>Gallery</Organization> in <Location>New York City</Location>, <Organization>Arab</Organization> Express, <Organization>Mori Art Museum</Organization>, <Location>Tokyo</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>), the 17th <Organization>Sydney Biennale</Organization>, Aksanat (İstanbul), ' I Love to Love', Forum <Location>Box</Location> <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Helsinki</Location>; the <Organization>Biennale</Organization> of Contemporary <Organization>Art</Organization> of <Location>Bosnia</Location>; <Organization>Hauser & Wirth Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location>; <Organization>Singapore Art Museum</Organization>; <Organization>Museum of Anthropology</Organization>, <Location>Vancouver</Location>; MOCCA, <Location>Toronto</Location>; Mead Gallery, <Location>UK</Location>; Espace at Louis Vuitton, <Location>Paris</Location>; <Organization>MAC-VAL Museum</Organization>, <Location>Paris</Location>; the 10th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> and 52nd <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization>, where he represented <Location>Finland</Location> and the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> Pavilion at the 54th <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization>; held solo shows at L'<Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization>, <Location>Paris</Location>; Kunsthalle Winterthur, <Location>Switzerland</Location>; Darat al-Funun; <Location>Amman</Location> and Wharf: <Organization>Centre d'Art Contemporain</Organization> de Basse, <Location>Normandy</Location>. 
His works are in the collections of public institutions and major private collections  including the <Organization>National Gallery of Victoria</Organization>, <Location>Melbourne</Location>, <Location>Australia</Location>; <Organization>Sharjah Art Foundation</Organization>, <Location>Sharjah</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location>; <Organization>Mathaf</Organization>: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization>, <Location>Doha</Location>, <Location>Qatar</Location>; Kiasma, <Location>Helsinki</Location>, <Location>Finland</Location>; Espoo <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> (EMMA), <Location>Helsinki</Location>, <Location>Finland</Location>; <Organization>Mori Art Museum</Organization>, <Location>Tokyo</Location>, <Location>Japan</Location>; Nadour Collection and Kamel Lazaar Collection.

Adham Wanly,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Adham-Wanly.aspx</Address>
Ibrahim Adham Wanly was born in <Date>1908</Date> in the neighborhood of <Date>Muharram</Date> Bey in <Location>Alexandria</Location>. His father, Ismaïl Bey Mohammed Wanly was of <Origin>Turkish</Origin> origin and his mother, Ismat Hanem al-Daghistani, was from Caucasia. <Organization>Adham</Organization> grew up, with his four sisters and his elder brother Seif in an aristocratic intellectual francophone environment and was educated by private tutors in the family palace of Urfan <Organization>Pacha</Organization>. <Organization>Adham</Organization> worked as the director of the book warehouse at the <Organization>Education Authority</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>.
Wanly first studied oil painting with his brother, Seif, in the studio of the <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter Arturo Zanieri (<Date>1870 - 1955</Date>) who had also been the teacher of Alexandrian painter <Organization>Mahmoud</Organization> Saïd (<Date>1897 - 1964</Date>). In 1929, the <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter, Ottorino Bicchi (<Date>1878 - 1949</Date>), educated at the Academy in <Location>Florence</Location>, opened a studio in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and the Wanly brothers were among his first students. When Bicchi closed his studio and returned to <Location>Italy</Location> before the Second World War, the Wanly brothers together with their friends, the painter Ahmad Fahmi and the filmmaker Mohammed Bayoumi, opened their own studio in <Location>Alexandria</Location> in <Date>1935</Date>.
During the 1950's, <Organization>Adham</Organization> and his brother traveled to many European countries including <Location>France</Location>, <Location>Italy</Location> and <Location>Spain</Location>, where they sketched and painted numerous landscapes, as well as ballet, opera and theater performances. In 1957, the Wanly brothers were appointed as professors at the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location> founded the same year by the sculptor Ahmad Osman (<Date>1907 - 1970</Date>). Two years later, they were appointed by the <Organization>Ministry of Culture</Organization> to participate in recording the Nubian architectural heritage in <Location>Aswan</Location> before the area was due to be flooded by the construction of the High Dam . During that mission, along with many artists and professors of their generation, they produced numerous paintings and sketches of the Nubian vernacular villages and ancient temples. Adham Wanly died in <Date>1959</Date> at the age of fifty-one in al-Moassat hospital in <Location>Alexandria</Location>. After his death, the street next to his studio in <Location>Alexandria</Location> was named after him.
Adham Wanly, like his brother Seif, was a prolific artist. His early works are influenced by his <Origin>Italian</Origin> teacher, Ottorino Bicchi, who was close to the <Origin>Italian</Origin> macchiaioli, a group influenced by the <Origin>French</Origin> impressionist movement and the École de Barbizon. Bicchi introduced the Wanly brothers to outdoor painting and capturing the light, colors and shades of nature. <Organization>Adham</Organization> was later influenced by modern pictorial trends, such as cubism and fauvism. Together with his brother, he developed a passion for performance arts, such as circus, ballet and theater and captured the vibrant and dynamic movements of the performers on stage.
<Organization>Adham</Organization> also painted numerous landscapes of Alexandria, as well as views of <Location>Cairo</Location> and many European cities. With his brother Seif, he participated regularly in the Salons in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and <Location>Cairo</Location>, as well as in the Alexandria Biennale. In addition to being a painter, he was also a talented caricaturist and during the 1930's, he regularly published his satirical drawings in <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> newspapers and reviews, such al Ruz al-Yusuf. His works can be seen at the Seif and <Organization>Adham Wanly Museum</Organization> hosted in the villa of the <Organization>Mahmoud Saïd Museum</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> Art in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>, as well as in numerous private collections around the world.

Adila Laidi-Hanieh,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/l/laidi-hanieh-adila</Address>
Adila Laidi-Hanieh edited in <Date>2008</Date> the book <Location>Palestine</Location>: We Lack for Nothing Here (<Location>Palestine</Location>: Rien ne nous Manque ici, Cercle d’Art, <Location>Paris</Location>), a cultural review of contemporary <Location>Palestine</Location>, which commissioned texts and art work from confirmed and emerging artists, critics, novelists, poets, and visual artists from <Location>Palestine</Location> and elsewhere. <Date>From 1996 to 2005</Date>, she ran the <Organization>Khalil Sakakini Cultural Center</Organization> in Ramallah where she curated the <Date>2001</Date> memorial exhibition 100 Shaheed-100 Lives. She taught Palestinian contemporary art and modern Arab intellectual history at <Organization>Birzeit University</Organization>, and is currently a cultural studies PhD candidate at <Organization>George Mason University</Organization>.
<Date>March 2009</Date>

Ahmad Amin Nazar,http://ivde.net/artists/ahmad_amin_nazar_1/biography</Address>
Amin Nazar (b. 1955, <Location>Iran</Location>) studied fine art in <Location>Tehran</Location>, and after eight years in <Location>Cologne</Location>, <Location>Germany</Location>, where he joined the <Organization>Society of Painters</Organization> of <Location>Cologne</Location> and was widely exposed to Western art, returned to <Location>Iran</Location>. Upon his return, he began predominantly working in etching, exploring relationships between miniaturist traditions and <Origin>Iranian</Origin> literature, and went on to develop a masterful draughtmanship. His work manifests the discordance between traditions, both from <Location>Iran</Location> and the West, and modernity. Persian epics, legendary figures, social leaders and macho wrestlers are transformed into disturbed, witty, violent and sensual studies, ink drawings and acrylic masterpieces. The artist has taught drawing to younger generations of <Origin>Iranian</Origin> artists at <Organization>Tehran University</Organization> as well as privately for many years.
Amin Nazar belongs to a lost generation of <Origin>Iranian</Origin> artists who, due to historical circumstances, were drowned out in the midst of ideological, political, cultural and violent turmoil. As a result, he became profoundly reclusive, seeking refuge and absolute release in his studio, and in his raw, instinctive works.
Despite shying away from the public eye, Amin Nazar’s works are surfacing internationally, most recently with the acquisition of the <Organization>British Museum</Organization> of two works on paper of wrestlers, one of which was exhibited as part of the ‘Fair Play: heroes, athletes and princes in Islamic art’ exhibition, <Date>2012</Date>.

Ahmad Morshedloo,http://nadour.org/artists/ahmad-morshedloo/</Address>
Ahmad Morshedloo carefully composes large-scale oil paintings as well as pen or charcoal drawings woven with meticulous lines and hatchings. Ahmad Osman,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Ahmad-Osman.aspx</Address>
Ahmad Osman was born in the small village of <Location>Eneiba</Location> near <Location>Aswan</Location> in Nubia. He studied at the <Organization>School of Decorative Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> under the <Origin>English</Origin> painter and decorator William Arnold Stewart (<Date>1882 - 1953</Date>). After graduating in <Date>1927</Date>, he worked with the Mission of the <Organization>University of Pennsylvania</Organization> as the registrar for the archaeological excavations in <Location>Palestine</Location>. In 1928, he received a scholarship to study in <Location>Rome</Location>, where he first took classes at the Scuola Libera del Disegno del Nudo before entering the sculpture section of the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization>. After receiving his diploma in <Date>1932</Date>, he traveled to <Location>Florence</Location> to specialize in decorative sculpture at the Regio Instituto d'Arte. The following year, he returned to <Location>Egypt</Location> where he was appointed professor of sculpture at the <Organization>School of Applied Arts</Organization> in Giza (former School of Decorative <Organization>Arts</Organization>). At that time, the School was directed by the artist Mohammed Hassan (<Date>1892 - 1961</Date>).
In 1937, Osman was named director of the sculpture section of the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. The same year, he participated in the decoration of the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Pavilion at the Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques appliqués à la Vie moderne in <Location>Paris</Location>, headed by the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> politician and collector Mohammed Mahmoud Khalil (<Date>1877 - 1953</Date>). In 1938 he exhibited at the fifteenth <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization> together with artists Mohammed Naghi (<Date>1888 - 1956</Date>) and Mahmoud Saïd (<Date>1897 - 1964</Date>), where <Location>Egypt</Location> was represented for the first time. Osman left his position at the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> in <Date>1957</Date> to establish the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location> of which he became the first director.
Besides his occupations as an artist and teacher, he was involved in the safeguarding of the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> cultural heritage. In 1954, he participated in the relocation of the colossal statue of Ramses II from Mit Rahina (<Location>Memphis</Location>) to Bab al-Hadid square in front of <Location>Cairo</Location> railway station. He also participated in Unesco's Nubian campaign from 1959, by developing techniques for cutting and reassembling the stone blocks of the <Location>Temple</Location> of Abu Simbel.
Ahmad Osman was one of the most prominent <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> sculptors of his generation. While his early works employ characteristics of <Origin>Italian</Origin> classicism, towards the end of the 1930's he started sculpting a series of bronzes representing busts of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> peasant women. These sculptures are characterized by their realism in depicting the features of the peasants and daily rural activities. They embody the simplicity and joyfulness of rural life, which he often expressed through a smiling <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> peasant. Osman also specialized in ornamental sculptures and was commissioned to decorate several public buildings. In 1936, together with his colleague, the sculptor Mansour Farag, he created the reliefs to decorate the entrance gate of the Zoological <Location>Garden</Location> in Giza designed by architect Mustafa Fahmi (<Date>1886 - 1972</Date>). In 1947, he sculpted the bronze reliefs decorating the pedestal of the monument to commemorate Ibrahim Pasha on the <Organization>Opera</Organization> square in <Location>Cairo</Location>, which was created by the <Origin>French</Origin> sculptor Charles Cordier (<Date>1829 - 1905</Date>).
Under Gamal Abdel Nasser, Osman was commissioned to sculpt the exterior façades of the <Organization>Officers Club</Organization> in Zamalek and the <Organization>Armed Forces Club</Organization> in Heliopolis, as well as the monumental stylized bronze eagle above the entrance of the <Location>Cairo</Location> Tower in <Date>1961</Date>. Osman was also a talented painter and produced a series of feminine and masculine nudes with charcoal, as well as several portraits, genres he developed while studying at the Scuola Libera del Disegno del Nudo. In his drawings, Osman reflects his background as a sculptor, by applying clear lines and shades on sculptural volumes. His works can be found in private collections, the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> Art in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Agriculture Museum</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and the Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>.

Ahmed Cherkaoui,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Ahmed-Cherkaoui.aspx</Address>
Ahmed Cherkaoui was one of the leading modernist painters of <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> art in the period after the country gained its independence in <Date>1956</Date>. Born in a small town, Boujad, located in the Chaouia plain, Cherkaoui descended, from his father's side, from "a famous family of mystics" called the "Sufi brotherhood of the Cherkaoua." The brotherhood was founded in <Date>1566</Date> during the reign of the Saadian sultans. His mother was of Amazighi origin, belonging to the Zayanes tribe from the Middle Atlas. The tribe was known for women's traditionally made handcrafts and wool weaving.
Cherkaoui studied graphics at the École des Metiers d'Art de <Location>Paris</Location> <Date>from 1956 to 1959</Date>, and continued his studies at the Aujame Atelier at the École Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-<Organization>Arts</Organization> de <Location>Paris</Location> for one year. In 1961, during the political and cultural thaw following the death of Stalin, Cherkaoui moved to <Location>Warsaw</Location> where he studied at the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization>. Later Cherkaoui returned to <Location>Paris</Location>, where he won a research grant from <Organization>UNESCO</Organization> to study signs and symbols in Amazighi art and Arab-Islamic calligraphy. During the early sixties, he held his first one-man show at the Atelier de Lucienne Thalheimer in <Location>Paris</Location> where he lived and worked.
Cherkaoui created large-scale abstract and symbolic canvases which negotiated an amalgam of references, ranging from Amazighi art, talismanic symbols to Roger Bissière, Paul Klee and Surrealism. The surface of these canvases are covered with burlap onto which Cherkaoui painted black-striped symbols crafted within an oval structure and laid at intervals with bright colors. The Maghreb, "the place of the setting sun," and more specifically the Amazighi tradition of the bare geometric sign are all intrinsic to the artist. Since his young age, his fascination with signs stemmed from his curiosity about the shapes and meaning of his mother's tattoos. Later on, he embraced the teachings and philosophy of Paul Klee, who wrote, "Man is not a completed product…We must…be open-minded…approach life like a child…of creation, of the creator's," and made them a guiding rule of his own spirit.
The desire to paint for Ahmed Cherkaoui is partially attributed to his interest in calligraphy and the motifs of popular talismans, and partly to his exposure to 20th century <Location>Western Modern</Location> art. Consequently, Cherkaoui's works reveal a concrete manifestation of a tangible interplay between tradition and modernity, negotiating both the aesthetic and abstract nature of signs and symbols which govern both Islamic art and new innovative techniques. However, Cherkaoui's resort to signs consists of far more than merely presenting their decorative function. He used a system of geometric signs and ciphers, including triangles, circles, lozenges, dots and broken and curved lines. These signs voice stories about a particular social system that are open to interpretation. As such, his creative artwork presented intriguing and visually complex forms which highlight his profound interest in national heritage.
In 1964, Cherkaoui held an exhibition at Jeanne Castel's Gallery in <Location>Paris</Location>, and other exhibitions in <Location>Rabat</Location>, <Location>Tangier</Location> and <Location>Casablanca</Location> in <Location>Morocco</Location>, where he explored and developed a personal modern style, he expressed in crude jute collages. After his collages, he went through a phase that he referred to as "tachiste" or formlessness, where he emphasized the value of color.
During the early sixties, his artwork depicted various forms drawn from outlines of tattoos, pottery, jewelry, weaving and motifs on handicraft ware, combining both bright and earth colors to highlight the cultural characteristics of his country of origin (al-Maghreb—"sunset in the sea"). While dark colors dominated his paintings before 1965, his colors afterwards became lighter and more lustrous with greater awareness of the use of space and additional media such as fiber, gouache and watercolor.
Cherkaoui's works received recognition early on as he won the bronze medal at the 10th "Salon Interministériel" in <Date>1962</Date> and took part regularly in the Salon de Mai in <Location>Paris</Location>. He participated in many solo exhibitions including his one-man show at the Ursula Girardon's Gallery in <Date>1962</Date> in <Location>Paris</Location>; and numerous collective exhibitions, including "20 Peintres étrangers" in the Parisian Musée de l'Art Moderne in <Date>1963</Date>.
Cherkaoui taught drawing classes at the <Organization>Technical College</Organization> in <Location>Beaumont</Location>-sur-Oise. He was generally associated with a small group of painters in <Location>Casablanca</Location> including Houssein Tallal and Andre Elbaz although he was never part of the <Organization>Casablanca School</Organization>. Cherkaoui traveled frequently between <Location>Europe</Location> and <Location>North Africa</Location>, and died suddenly due to complications from an appendectomy in <Date>1967</Date> after coming back to <Location>Casablanca</Location>, <Location>Morocco</Location>.
After his death, his work was represented in a series of retrospective shows entitled Hommage à Cherkaoui organized at the Biennale de <Location>Paris</Location> and also at the Salon of Sacred Art in <Location>Paris</Location>; followed by the Biennale Exhibit of <Location>New Delhi</Location> in <Date>1968</Date> in <Location>India</Location>. His works were also featured at the interférences Poetes-Peintres group show at the Daniel Templon Gallery, one of Cherkaoui's watercolor works accompanying the poem 'talisman' written by Jean Guichard Meili in <Location>Paris</Location> in <Date>1969</Date>.

Ali Al-Ruzaiza,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-alialruzaiza.html</Address>

Ali Al-Tokhais,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-alialtokhais.html</Address>
Ali Al-Tokhais (<Date>1956</Date>) is a sculptor by the incident of his birth in Al-Dawadmi. Al-Dawadmi, or 'The High of the <Location>Najd</Location>,' is a hill top town, west of Riyadh, where it is said that a tradition of sculpture has continued over the ages after introduction in the 15th century. They have been farming the rock is what comes to mind, if rock is indeed what the <Location>Najd</Location> hills are made off. <Location>Rock</Location> is the artist's preferred medium on which he concentrates striving for absolute proficiency. The result of this, the rock which went through his hands, mind, heart and fingers has been on show to the public in the <Location>Middle East</Location> and other countries around the globe at frequent exhibitions since <Date>1985</Date>. A large selection of his works can be seen on his own website. And this website is worth visiting for another reason. Ali Al-Tokhais is a professor of sculpture and shows with pride pictures of his students with their work.Al-Tokhais has said that the Arabic alphabet is a silent influence in his work that by itself is abstract. But the abstraction is taken away again by contemplation while the rock is revealing its new form or perhaps as an afterthought. So the works of rock find themselves entrusted with titles which carry meaning. And sometimes, as is probabaly the case with Penetration, the rock is trusted with the nation itself.

Atta Sabri,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Atta-Sabri.aspx</Address>
Atta Sabri (<Date>1913 - 1987</Date>) is considered one of the early pioneers of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> modern art, honored alongside Faiq Hassan and Hafidh al-Droubi. In many ways, Sabri's career mirrors that of his contemporaries. He was educated in the arts abroad and his works show a blending of western art techniques with an <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> essence. The artist is well-known for his pleasing representations of the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> countryside. Done with a subtle skill, Sabri's canvases exhibit the beauty of the landscape and the customs of its inhabitants.    
Sabri completed his early education at the <Location>Dar</Location> al-Mualimin or the "<Organization>House</Organization> of Teachers" in <Location>Baghdad</Location> in <Date>1934</Date>. He then went on to teach at local schools. Like other artists of his generation, Sabri won a government-sponsored scholarship to pursue the arts in <Location>Europe</Location>. He travelled to <Location>Rome</Location> to study at the Accademia di Belle Arti in <Date>1937</Date>, but was forced to return home at the outbreak of World War II. During the years <Date>between 1940 and 1944</Date>, Sabri was employed at the <Organization>Department of Antiquities</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. In 1946, Sabri was again presented with the opportunity to study art abroad and finished his BFA in <Location>London</Location> at <Organization>Goldsmiths College</Organization> and the <Organization>Slade School</Organization>. After graduating in <Date>1950</Date>, he held a professorship at the <Organization>Institute of Fine Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>, among other institutions. Sabri taught until 1960 and later became Inspector of Fine Arts.
Coupled with Sabri's institutional affiliations, he was also an active member of several important art groups. He was a founding member of the <Organization>Society of the Friends</Organization> of <Organization>Art</Organization> and was active in the <Organization>Society of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> Plastic</Organization> Artists. He was made a fellow of the latter in <Date>1972</Date>. Sabri was one of the pioneer artists to be showcased at the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> artist pavilion during the 1931 Industrial and Agricultural Fair in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. This was a watershed exhibition for Atta Sabri and his colleagues as it exposed the public to contemporary <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> art for the first time. Sabri also participated in the 1950 First <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> <Organization>Art</Organization> Show in <Location>London</Location>. In <Date>1973</Date>, the painter was invited by the <Origin>German</Origin> university, <Organization>Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg</Organization>, to contribute to their craft conference. Subsequently, Sabri contributed to several exhibitions at the <Organization>National Museum</Organization> of Modern <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>, especially <Date>between 1977 and 1980</Date>. In <Date>1979</Date> the museum hosted a major retrospective of Sabri's work.
The painter's style remained fairly consistent with a blending of realist and impressionistic qualities. The quiet, blooming crannies in and around <Location>Baghdad</Location> were Sabri's favored subjects. He also painted sweeping vistas that often contrasts a rocky outcrop with a smooth valley. He rarely focused on individuals, unless composing a portrait. Instead, he centered his canvases on the qualities of the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> environment varying his brushstrokes to reflect movement in the scenery.
When Sabri does focus on human activity the scenes are usually composed as windows into timeless traditions. The viewer stands aloof while passively watching a group of figures interact. Whether it is a cluster of women bathing or musicians playing, a sense of local custom is conveyed through distinctive dress and a ritualized treatment of the portrayed event. There is an overall simplicity and serenity in Sabri's work that can be seen in a number of artists from his generation who were seeking to engage the natural aesthetics of their homeland. 
A number of Atta Sabri's pieces, including his lively rendering of musicians and dancers, were looted from the <Organization>National Museum</Organization> of Modern <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. The artist's son Salam Atta Sabri, the director of the museum and an artist in his own right, has dedicated himself to raising awareness of the fate of these works and is working towards their recovery.

Basmah Felemban,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-basmahfelemban.html</Address>
Basmah Felemban (<Date>1993</Date>) is a graphic designer with the slightly loose touch that betrays the real artist. She landed her work Jeem in the <Organization>British Museum</Organization> at a sideshow to the <Date>2012</Date> Hajj exhibition and on her blog in <Date>December 2011</Date> she was kind enough to allow the world a sneak preview of 'the making of Jeem' showing us how she wrestled with stencils to separate light and darkness on an octangular piece of wood, creating and image which looks like at least two works of art, intimately attached to each other for a fate of eternal friction. She mentioned online her interest in Islamic art and Jeem reflects exactly that, but even more so the work left us with the impression that the very best things might well happen outside the greater plan of known geometry. The people she most admires in the field of art? Leonardo da Vinci and Banksy. Felemban finished highschool in <Date>2011</Date> and describes herself now, for those who twitter, as an 'amateur artist.' An opinion with which we are inclined to strongly disagree, if not Da Vinci would have said exactly the same about himself. In her frequent writing on blogs she takes an interest in what other artists do and make. Her frank contribution 'Let the walls speak' for pan-arabic Mashallah News reported on the growth of street art in her country and made an interesting read. (<Date>2012</Date>) ***After writing the above, the artist informed us of the concept of Jeem, which is the first letter of both 'janna' (heaven) and 'jaheem' (hell). The artist based the design on each of the two squares in this octangular work on one of these words using the geometric kufi typeface creating a 'complex contrast' as they overlap. We would say she delivered her concept exactly right and trusted chance to help her deliver. (<Date>2012</Date>)

Fayyazi struggled to show her work amid an atmosphere of stuffy traditionalism, academicism, and the influx of ‘90s conceptual art from abroad. She entered 2,000 ceramic cockroaches into <Location>Tehran</Location>’s 6th Biennial of Contemporary Ceramic Art, despite an attempt by several members of the committee to oust her work from the show. She cast and fired terracotta dogs (‘Road Kill’, <Date>1998</Date>), modelled on dead dogs found on the highways in <Location>Tehran</Location>, and then placed her creations onto streets around the city, much to the consternation of onlookers.

César Gemayel,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Cesar-Gemayel.aspx</Address>

Subsequent to his premature death due to a heart attack in <Date>1958</Date>, the <Organization>Sursock Museum</Organization> in <Location>Beirut</Location> honored Gemayel's memory at the 1964 Salon d'Automne.

Daoud Corm,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Daoud-Corm.aspx</Address>
Born in Ghosta in <Location>Mount</Location> <Location>Lebanon</Location>, Corm and his family resettled soon afterwards in his mother's home village of <Location>Ghazir</Location>. His beginnings as an artist can be dated back to 1861, when two <Origin>Italian</Origin> Jesuit priests discovered Corm's drawings on some rocks. Mistaking the young boy's depictions of birds for three-dimensional reality, the priests were mesmerized by Corm's natural talent and offered him a position teaching drawing at the local Jesuit missionary school in exchange for <Origin>Italian</Origin> language lessons. After nearly a decade teaching in the school, sometime in <Date>the late 1860s</Date> Corm sold several paintings to the <Organization>Maronite Church</Organization> in <Location>Mount</Location> <Location>Lebanon</Location> to pay for a ticket to <Location>Rome</Location> to study at the Accademia di San Luca under artist Roberto Bompiani.
In 1878, Corm chose to settle in <Location>Beirut</Location>. Then part of the Ottoman Empire, the city had undergone radical transformations over the <Date>previous decade</Date> as it emerged as a commercial, political, and cultural hub in the region. In addition to a population surge following the 1860 civil war in <Location>Mount</Location> <Location>Lebanon</Location>, <Location>Beirut</Location> had grown substantially due to a number of infrastructural projects jointly sponsored by the Ottoman and European governments. In turn, throughout the nineteenth century, a host of families had migrated to <Location>Beirut</Location> from <Location>Aleppo</Location>, <Location>Damascus</Location>, <Location>Tripoli</Location>, Acre, Sidon and <Location>Mount Lebanon</Location> to join a growing community of Damascene merchant families. It was from this newly emerging upwardly mobile urban class of merchants, intellectuals, and politicians—known historically as members of al-nahda—that Corm would cultivate a patron base.
Working mainly in oil on canvas, along with pastel on paper, Corm depicted <Location>Beirut</Location>'s elite in his signature style: a pared down, formal, three-quarter length portrait against a dark background with an attention to the individual's social and professional standing. In many ways, Corm's work drew on conventions for portraiture previously established both in oil painting and photography, a medium popular among elite at the time. Perhaps Corm's two most recognized portraits are those of Bustros al-Bustani (<Date>1894</Date>) and Pope Pius IX (early 1870s), which served as Corm's calling card.
Corm's patrons were not limited to <Location>Beirut</Location> and <Location>Mount Lebanon</Location>. Before establishing his atelier in <Location>Beirut</Location>, Corm spent a period of time in <Location>Belgium</Location> after being commissioned by Leopold II to paint portraits of the Royal Family of <Location>Belgium</Location>. In 1887, he traveled to Alexandria to capture with his brush the leading governors there as well as members of the nobility. In 1894, the Khedive Abbas II invited Corm again to <Location>Egypt</Location> to paint the ruler's portrait.
In addition to his portraits, Corm created a substantial body of religious works, the majority of which were commissioned by the <Organization>Maronite Church</Organization> and many of which remain in churches throughout <Location>Mount Lebanon</Location>. In fact, before Corm, oil painting was limited to clerics in the church, many of whom had been trained by <Origin>Italian</Origin> missionaries and clerics at the <Organization>Maronite College of Rome</Organization>, established in <Date>1584</Date> to strengthen ties between the <Location>Vatican</Location> and the region's Christian communities. These cleric-painters, as they have come to be known, include Musa Dib (d.1826), who studied at the <Organization>Maronite College of Rome</Organization>, and his nephew Kan'an Dib (d. 1873), who along with Corm trained with Constantin Giusti, an <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter who had come to <Location>Mount Lebanon</Location> with the Jesuit missionaries in <Date>1831</Date>. Thus, although Corm's academic style may have been outdated in <Location>Europe</Location>, his historical significance lies in his ability to forge a local market for oil portraits, previously reserved for religious figures. Moreover, the presence of still life, landscapes, and genre scenes within his oeuvre suggests an on spec market for works on canvas and paper.
In 1912, Corm expanded his artistic enterprise and its public appeal when he opened Maison d'Art, an art supply store centrally located near <Location>Beirut</Location>'s post office. The store's commercial success indicated a growing public interest not only in art viewing but also in art making.
Corm exhibited his work abroad in <Location>Egypt</Location> and <Location>Europe</Location>, most notably at the 1889 <Location>Versailles</Location> Exhibition in <Location>France</Location> and at the 1900 <Location>Paris</Location> Exhibition, where he received the Prize of Honor of Excellence. Additional recognition of his career includes receipt of the <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> Order of Merit and the Ottoman Medal of Glory. Corm died in <Date>1930</Date>.

Dia Aziz Dia ,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-diaazizdia.html</Address>
Dia Aziz Dia is a painter and sculptor from <Location>Jeddah</Location> who was one of the first to attend the academy of fine arts in <Location>Rome</Location> and resisted being for ever a full time teacher and ignoring the human face and the natural environment as a source of inspiration. 
In his own clever words on his website he explains he thought art an attempt to reveal the secret that was hidden behind appearance:
"Thus, he constantly tried to depict the human face because he considered it the key to understanding the person and a way to question his or her secrets and inherent potential. This could be carried out through capturing the details of the face in a process that combined drawing and erasing. It resulted in an abstract face, not in the usual sense of abstraction, but in the sense of denying the details that were not relevant to the notion that the artist wanted to capture. The artist focused only on the meaningful fragments, which were the expression of the world that he was trying to depict."
Hence the editors of this dictionary come to the conclusion that the excellent painting to the left by Diaz in the best tradtition of the <Origin>Italian</Origin> renaissance is not H.M. King Faisal but an abstraction of Diaz. (<Date>2008</Date>).

Within his work, Djamel Kokene explores the tensions between language, thought and representation. Thus, he stages the written word it in many of his works, sometimes associated with objects, always in a strong conceptual stance. By drawing themes from the heart of contemporary society, the artist also readily deals with notions of identity, nationality and community, challenging them with the notions of nomadism and displacement.
Born in Ain El Hamman in <Location>Algeria</Location> in <Date>1968</Date>, Djamel Kokene has been living in <Location>France</Location> since <Date>1978</Date>.He graduated in Fine Arts, Philosophy and Aesthetics (with a cinema specialisation), and Hypermedia - New technologies (MFA, University <Location>Paris</Location> 8 - St Denis). He also attended classes at the Ecole Supérieure des Beaux-Arts in <Location>Paris</Location>.
Whilst reflecting the artistic practices, the question of the modes of production and teaching of art, from the beginning of his artistic activity the artist came up with various devices and concepts having a strong evolutionary and mobile dimension: thus since <Date>2000</Date>, he has been developing the concept of “Trainee -Artist” as well as “<Organization>Mobile-School</Organization>”, successively activated in <Location>Algiers</Location>, Bourges and <Location>Cairo</Location>.
In <Date>2002</Date>, he initiated the collective structure Laplateforme, a mobile laboratory for reflection and research on contemporary artistic creation of the <Location>Mediterranean</Location> area, willing to escape the NORTH-SOUTH authority for a dynamics open to the world.
