Driss Ouadahi,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/42-driss-ouadahi/overview/</Address>
Driss Ouadahi takes as his subject matter the built environment of urban alienation - sterile modernist public housing developments, wire netting and underground passageways. Ouadahi paints works of paradoxical beauty using this stark urbanism as his springboard.
Currently Ouadahi works in three milieu- landscapes, fences and underpasses. Persistent in each are his core concerns of geometric abstraction, transparency and the implication of the veil.
His large formal landscapes are montages of spaces and places he knows, with human-scale details often omitted. His labyrinthine layering of planes creates space and perspective that is both familiar and confusing. The accuracy Ouadahi's execution belies the fragility of the structures he paints. Ouadahi's fences recall the wire-netting common in the metropolitan suburbs of <Location>France</Location> and <Location>Algeria</Location>. They delimit zones into which entrance is not permitted and demarcate privileged zones. Ouadahi's underpasses are the most illusionistic and are based on actual subways in <Location>Germany</Location>.
Born in <Location>Casablanca</Location>, <Location>Morocco</Location>, of <Origin>Algerian</Origin> parents in <Date>1959</Date>, Driss Ouadahi grew up in <Location>Algeria</Location>. He studied at the Ecole Superieure des Beaux Arts d'<Location>Alger</Location> before enrolling and subsequently graduating from the Kunstakadamie <Location>Düsseldorf</Location>, the city where he now lives and works. Ouadahi has exhibited in solo exhibitions in <Location>New York</Location>, <Location>San Francisco</Location>, <Location>Düsseldorf</Location>, <Location>Germany</Location>, and Istres, <Location>France</Location>. He has also taken part in a number of group exhibitions, most recently in the 11th edition of the Biennale de l’Art <Origin>Africain</Origin> Contemporain, <Location>Dakar</Location>; 25 Ans De Créativité Arabe, Institute De Monde d’Arab, <Location>Paris</Location>; Le Retour, 3ème <Organization>Festival International</Organization> d'Art Contemporain d'<Location>Alger</Location>; Magreb: Dos Orillas, Círculo de Bellas Artes, <Location>Madrid</Location>; Future of a Promise at <Location>Venice</Location> Bienale 54, <Organization>Cairo Biennial</Organization> 12, and <Organization>CU Art Museum</Organization>, <Organization>University of Colarado</Organization> in <Location>Boulder</Location>.

Fahd Al-Khalif,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-fahdalkhalif.html</Address>
Fahd Al-Khalif (<Date>1972</Date>) is a most generous of painters dealing with mostly the figurative world with all insights of Parisien abstraction from Cezanne to Matisse. And in this you can't help noticing how often he uses light blue, actually seems to adore the colour or to find it necessary. Al-Khalif is a true colorist not just painting the world but laying a reef of paintings over <Location>Jeddah</Location> as if he regrets that coral and fishes were left to the sea and below its surface and birds to the sky. As a master of art education and head of such education in <Location>north Jeddah</Location> his proficiency in handling oils and perhaps acrylic paint should be judged self evident, but surprising is how many paintings he shows in his presentation on facebook. They number hundreds and with consistency of vision and of life, sometimes changing the subject to calligraphy or horses. Occasionally Al-Khalif explores a naïve realism or his usual abstract style with more subdued colours. Some of his works appear to be wallpaintings by themselves or to have been assembled with square canvasses brought together to match. All these are styles and themes not unusual in the country, but Al-Khalif easily convinces as being master of any caravan.Al-Khalif mentiones many exhibitions in <Location>Jeddah</Location> and many in countries in <Location>Europe</Location> representing his country. Out of hundreds of his paintings I selected a few special images, which perhaps don't give an idea of his most frequent themes and style, but which celebrate the diversity and richness of <Location>Jeddah</Location> life as a result of its position as port to <Location>Makkah</Location>. (<Date>November 4, 2010</Date>).

Fahrelnissa Zeid,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Fahrelnissa-Zeid.aspx</Address>
Born into a prominent Ottoman family with an avid love for books and art, Fahrelnissa Zeid was exposed since her birth to her brother's brushstrokes and the oil paintings of her mother, Sara Ismet Hanim, on silk clothes hanging on the walls of her home. Zeid began painting in her early childhood and drawing portraits at the age of twelve. Her father, Mohammad Shakir Pasha, was a diplomat, general, photographer and historian. Zeid along with many members of her family were considered models of Ottoman intellectualism.
Zeid was among the first women to attend the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Istanbul</Location> in <Date>1920</Date>, where she studied under the <Origin>Turkish</Origin> painter Namik Ismail. In 1928, she travelled to <Location>Paris</Location> and trained in the studio of Stahlbach and Roger Bissière at the Académie Ranson.
Throughout her career, Zeid participated in almost 50 exhibitions in <Location>Europe</Location>, <Location>U.S.A.</Location> and the <Location>Middle East</Location>. Her <Location>New York</Location> debut came in <Date>1950</Date> when she exhibited a series of large abstract canvases at the Hugo Gallery followed later on by numerous international shows (See Exhibitions below). Zeid's paintings are included in the collections of several museums, including the <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> of <Location>Paris</Location>, museums of <Location>New York</Location>, of <Location>Cincinnati</Location>, of <Location>Edinburgh</Location>, of <Location>Pittsburgh</Location>, <Organization>Museum of Painting</Organization> and <Organization>Sculpture</Organization> of <Location>Istanbul</Location>, <Organization>Museum of Hittite Art</Organization> of <Location>Ankara</Location>, Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> and private collections.
Fahrelnissa Zeid died in <Date>1991</Date> when she was eighty-nine, and was buried in the Royal Mausoleum, Raghdan Palace in <Location>Amman</Location>, <Location>Jordan</Location>. She left behind an immense visual legacy that present a variety of narratives about the development of Modern <Organization>Art</Organization>.

Faiq Hassan,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Faiq-Hassan-Alawi-al-Janabi.aspx</Address>
aiq Hassan (<Date>1914 - 1992</Date>) is often referred to as the father of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> modern art.  During his artistic career he took on many roles within the burgeoning <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> art scene, including educator and founder. In the crucial decades of <Date>the 1940s</Date> and 50s, Hassan was devoted to the creation of an art form that would express the growing feelings of national pride amongst <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> citizens. He was also interested in developing his own technical skill and that of his students. In later decades, Hassan would remain a leading artist in <Location>Iraq</Location> and his artistic legacy continues to be a powerful influence.
Born in <Location>Baghdad</Location> in <Date>1914</Date>, Hassan remembers his childhood as a series of art experiments, as he would master one media and move on to the next. A typical experiment involved mud from the <Location>Tigris River</Location> sculpted in the shape of horses and people. He did not consider himself bright in the traditional sense as he neglected his schoolwork. His talent for art-making, however, developed with ease and he was encouraged by his teachers. One teacher in particular, the artist Muhammad Khidir, became Hassan's mentor and artistic example. He considered Khidir a master of color subtleties, whose work would later point the way for Hassan's own investigations into color theory.
Hassan's artistic aptitude was awarded in <Date>1933</Date> when he became the second recipient of a government-funded scholarship to study art in <Location>Europe</Location>. He travelled to <Location>France</Location> and enrolled at the Ècole Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-Arts. In <Location>Paris</Location>, Hassan had a fairly traditional education in the arts. He participated in art history and studio classes while completing art projects based on copying master works. Hassan was also introduced to important figures of European modernism. He was especially impressed with artists like Matisse and Delacroix, paying specific attention to their use of color. Like many art students, Hassan spent his years in <Location>Paris</Location> synthesizing aspects of his education and life experiences into a workable artistic practice. Thus, these were days of exploration and a growing awareness of the international art scene.
Hassan returned to <Location>Baghdad</Location> after receiving his degree in <Date>1938</Date>. Soon after, he accepted a position at the <Organization>Institute of Fine Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> as the director of the <Organization>Department of Painting</Organization> and <Organization>Sculpture</Organization>. During his tenure at the institute, which continued until 1962, Hassan introduced courses based on Western painting techniques, as well as classes for the study of Islamic and Arab folk arts, like pottery and metalwork. He also went to great lengths to develop the efficacy of the department by training future teachers and procuring basic art supplies and gypsum models. In conjunction with his job as an administrator, Hassan was an involved teacher. He taught courses on color theory, perspective, anatomy, and design, as well as classes in art history. He encouraged his students to search their local surroundings for inspiration while honing their technical skills. Hassan took student development as a personal responsibility and made it his duty to oversee the first generation of artists to graduate from the institute. Over the <Date>next decade</Date>, the institute became the center of artistic activity and Hassan's reputation as a leading figure in <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> art education was firmly established.

Faisal Khudaidi,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-faisalkhudaidi.html</Address>

Faisal Samra,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-faisalsamra.html</Address>
Faisal Samra moves in front of a camera recording in black and white. We do not recognize him and only see a man's upper body from behind with a white sheet pulled over it. His face is and will remain hidden througout the performance. He nevertheless turns to face his viewers and picks up the loose ends of the sheet and starts winding them around his head. This goes on for a while with both or changing hands. When the sheet is all wrapped around the head and shoulders, he doesn't stop but continues only to wrap things differently and more firmly, sometimes passing stages that look like he has a bird's beak or is a severly wounded hospital patient. After a while he simply walks away with the sheet still in place. Such is the video installation Samra presents on his website as Distorted Reality (improvisation).
Samra believes he is arming people against the beautified 'made-up images' which are produced by ad-men and news editors to flatter and deceive us into making the wrong choices. He thinks these image producers wage a ruthless war on us and on many levels, but he has said in an interview that it was the role of the media in justifying the actual 'War on Terror' that made up his mind to start the body of work that is Distorted Reality. He uses digital photography, computer graphics and video to record these improvised and mostly very similar performances. They are also presented in a photographic format as a triptych. The cloth or cloths may be more colourful and he may add a number of props, but they all tell of a struggle with images we hold close to our heads. A skinned lamb appears in one of them. He has been quoted as saying that this was a memory from watching a lamb being slaughtered with Eid Al-Adha when he was only four years old and starting to draw. Samra's own distorted realities are not about beautifying the worse but perhaps a better which is to question our resistance against images. 
Faisal Samra (<Date>1956</Date>) was born and lives in <Location>Bahrain</Location>. He has the <Origin>Saudi Arabian</Origin> nationality and has worked in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location> for a number of years after graduating with honours from the <Organization>Ecole National</Organization> Superieure des Beaux Arts in <Location>Paris</Location> in <Date>1980</Date>. He has been a fine arts and graphics consultant with the <Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization>. He has explored Islamic design in Marocco and lived and worked in <Location>Lebanon</Location> and <Location>Jordan</Location>. He ventured upon his DistortedRealities after having been artist in residence (<Date>2005</Date>) at the <Organization>Cité International</Organization> des Arts in <Location>Paris</Location>. Earlier work of Samra involved among other things canvas 'released' from the frame and wrapped around wire mesh. This older work is included in the Al-Mansouria foundation collection. Samra is the <Origin>Saudi Arabian</Origin> artist best known in the international circuit. He has in <Date>2008</Date> shown his work in the <Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization> exhibition in <Location>London</Location> and on the <Organization>Singapore Biennale</Organization>.

Farhad Ahrarnia,http://edgeofarabia.com/artists/farhad-ahrarnia</Address>
Farhad Ahrarnia was born in <Date>1971</Date> in <Location>Shiraz</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>. He lives and works between <Location>Sheffield</Location> and <Location>Shiraz</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location> and graduated in Experimental and Documentary Film Theory and Practice from the <Organization>Northern Media School</Organization>, <Organization>Sheffield Hallam University</Organization>, <Location>England</Location>.
His practice exists at the cusp of craft and informal architecture, whereby he applies the core principles of architecture as a means to probe the semiotics of culture and power in society. Ahrarnia applies these codes within his hand-embroidered practice and acute needlework, which he layers upon and punctures into the surface of iconic imagery.

Farhad Moshiri,http://www.thethirdline.com/artists/farhad-moshiri/biography/</Address>
Farhad Moshiri was born in <Location>Shiraz</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>, and graduated from the <Organization>California Institute of the Arts</Organization> (<Organization>CalArts</Organization>) in <Date>1984</Date>. Living between <Location>Tehran</Location> and <Location>Paris</Location>,  Farhad has developed a personal language in which to discuss commonalities in <Origin>Iranian</Origin> and Western cultures. Inspired by Pop art, Farhad overturns both pop culture and highbrow imagery by transforming it into figurative artwork. His pieces are made using everyday objects as well as sparkly, luxurious materials such as pearls, crystals, sequins, and gold leaf. Though his work appears to be playful and decorative, beyond the shimmering surfaces Farhad casts a more cynical and often critical eye. He addresses the flaws of contemporary <Location>Iran</Location> all while toying with its traditional forms; and acknowledges the appeal of the Western world in addition to its limitations.

Farid Belkahia,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Farid-Belkahia.aspx</Address>
One of the foremost modernist artists in <Location>Morocco</Location>, Farid Belkahia began his training at the Ecole Nationale des Beaux-Arts of <Location>Paris</Location> <Date>from 1954 to 1959</Date>. He continued his studies in <Location>Prague</Location> until returning to <Location>Morocco</Location> in <Date>1962</Date> to become director of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in <Location>Casablanca</Location>, a position he retained until <Date>1974</Date>. Belkahia turned away from oil painting and easels in <Date>the early 1960s</Date> and began working primarily with large-scale hammered copper. While retaining multiple dimensions, the copper was meant to be hung on walls and was used to create bas-reliefs. Since <Date>the mid-1970s</Date>, Belkahia is best known for the work he has done with leather, which he treats using traditional techniques and stretches over shaped supports. He then paints the leather with naturally occurring dyes such as henna.
The process of the work on both copper and leather is for Belkahia an important aspect of the creation of his art, and his work typically highlights not just the organic shapes that make up the content of the work, but the texture and dimensionality of the materials themselves. He has a consistent and carefully theorized taxonomy of symbols, shapes, and materials that resurface throughout his oeuvre. Belkahia's work typically uses sinuous, organic shapes that recall bodies or corporality. Many of his works use triangles, arrows, and hands, and often involve questions of sexuality. He often employs Tifinagh letters from the Amazigh alphabet and symbols culled from traditional visual culture within <Location>Morocco</Location>, derived from rugs, tattoos, and architecture. Part of the interest of his work, however, is the way in which these symbols are re-constituted and re-imagined to become an integral part of his modernist visual vocabulary.
Belkahia was an active voice in the debates around post-colonial artistic modernism in <Location>Morocco</Location>, and contributed to   the leftist cultural and intellectual journal Souffles when it first came out. For Belkahia, using the cultural heritage of <Location>Morocco</Location> in his shapes, materials, and technique was a way of rooting international modernism within the local context. Under his leadership, the <Location>Casablanca</Location> Ecole des Beaux-Arts became known for advancing a pedagogy that turned away from the inherited <Origin>French</Origin> model of easel paintings and still lifes, instead highlighting <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> visual culture and architecture. The pedagogy of the art school was closely linked to the artists' broader activities. With the artists Mohammed Melehi and Mohammed Chebaa (both of whom taught at the school), he formed the <Location>Casablanca</Location> group that first exhibited together in <Location>Rabat</Location> in <Date>1966</Date>. In 1969, these artists along with three other professors from the school organized the "exposition manifeste" in Djemaa al-Fna in <Location>Marrakech</Location>, an open-air exhibition that sought direct contact with a larger public outside of official arts spaces. Later that same year, a similar exhibition was held in the Place du 16 Novembre in <Location>Casablanca</Location>.
Belkahia has had multiple personal exhibitions at major art venues in <Location>Morocco</Location>, including the national gallery, Galerie Bab Rouah, in <Location>Rabat</Location>, the Galerie L'Atelier in <Location>Rabat</Location>, the Cultural Moussem of Asilah, the <Organization>Batha Museum of Fes</Organization>, and the Galerie Delacroix in <Location>Tangier</Location>. His work was represented in  major early exhibitions of <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> modern art, including "<Date>2000</Date> ans d'art au <Location>Maroc</Location>" (Galerie Charpentier, <Location>Paris</Location>) and the 1963 <Organization>Rencontre International</Organization> in <Location>Rabat</Location>, as well as the <Location>Paris</Location> Biennale (1959 and 1961), the Festival of Negro Arts in <Location>Dakar</Location> (<Date>1966</Date>), the Panafrican Festival in <Location>Algiers</Location> (<Date>1967</Date>), and the First Arab Biennial in <Location>Baghdad</Location> (<Date>1974</Date>). More recently, his art was included in the exhibitions "Présences artistiques du <Location>Maroc</Location>" (Maison de la Culture, <Location>Grenoble</Location>, <Date>1985</Date>), "Quatre peintures du <Location>Maroc</Location>" (<Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization>, <Location>Paris</Location>, <Date>1991</Date>), "Interventions" (Mathaf, <Date>2009</Date>), and at the <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> (Johannesberg), the Haus der Kulturen der Welt (<Location>Berlin</Location>), and the Biennales of <Location>Venice</Location> and <Location>Lyon</Location>.

Firoz Mahmud,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/m/mahmud-firoz</Address>

Gamal el-Sigini,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Gamal-el-Sigini.aspx</Address>
Gamal el-Sigini was a sculptor and medalist born in the neighborhood of Bab al-Shaariya in <Location>Cairo</Location>. He grew up near the Khan al-Khalili market and was impressed as a child by the craftsmanship of the metalworkers and goldsmiths established in this area. He joined the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> in <Date>1933</Date>, where he studied under the <Location>Saint Petersburg</Location> born <Origin>Swedish</Origin> sculptor Boris Frödman-Cluzel (<Date>1878 - 1959</Date>). In 1937, el-Sigini won the Mahmoud Moukhtar Prize for sculpture, which was created by intellectual and feminist Huda Shaarawi in <Date>1935</Date> to commemorate the death of the renowned sculptor, Mahmoud Mokhtar (<Date>1891 - 1934</Date>). El-Sigini graduated in <Date>1938</Date>, and in <Date>1945</Date> founded the Group Sawt al-Fannān (The Voice of the Artist) that promoted young <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> artists and inspired the art critic Muhammad Sidqi al-Gabakhangi to establish a monthly art review with the same name.
El-Sigini traveled to <Location>Paris</Location> at his own expense and discovered the works of Rodin, Brancusi, Bourdelle and Maillol. In Egypt, he was a member of the <Organization>Group of Modern Art</Organization> founded in <Date>1947</Date> with his contemporaries; Hamed Owais, Gazbia Sirry, Zeinab Abdel Hamid, Salah Yousri and Youssef Sida. The same year, el-Sigini received a scholarship to pursue his studies in metalwork and sculpture in <Location>Rome</Location>. When he returned to <Location>Egypt</Location> in <Date>1951</Date>, he established his studio in the neighborhood of Zamalek and was appointed as a professor of sculpture at the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. In 1958, he moved to Alexandria to head the department of sculpture at the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> just after its creation by sculptor Ahmad Osman (<Date>1907 - 1970</Date>). El-Sigini left this post in <Date>1964</Date>, when he was named director of the section of sculpture at the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. In 1969, because his works and those of his contemporaries were not commissioned for public spaces, he threw a number of his sculptures into the <Location>Nile</Location> to express his frustration. El-Sigini traveled to <Location>Spain</Location> for his last exhibition at the Center for <Location>Mediterranean</Location> Studies in <Location>Barcelona</Location>, where he died in <Date>November 1977</Date> at the age of sixty.
Gamal el-Sigini produced numerous works, using a diversity of materials, such as bronze, stone, copper, wood and leather. He developed an original technique of hammered red copper for executing low-reliefs inspired by ancient <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> art. From the 1950's, he sculpted social realist works dealing with intensely idealistic and patriotic themes. Although the message of his works was often political, el-Sigini created a poetic style characterized by the introduction of symbols, such as the dove or the snake, as well as his own calligraphy using the signs of an imaginary language. He sculpted allegorical reliefs of several places in <Location>Egypt</Location>, such as the <Location>Nile</Location>, Alexandria or <Location>Cairo</Location>, and often interpreted the image of motherhood as a representation of his homeland.
A recurrent subject in his work used as a symbol of <Location>Egypt</Location> is the carūsa, a bridal sugar-doll traditionally sold on the occasion of the celebration of the birth of the Prophet (mawlid al-nabawī). After the defeat of the Six-Day War in <Date>1967</Date>, el-Sigini, like many artists of his generation, expressed his disillusion and despair in his work. He conveyed this through the figure of a mutilated or hanged carūsa. El-Sigini produced several statues of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> public figures and in <Date>1958</Date>, won the governmental competition for the monument of the poet Ahmad Shawqi (<Date>1868 - 1932</Date>) to be placed in the gardens of the Villa Borghese in <Location>Rome</Location>. Two copies of this sculpture stand <Date>today</Date> in <Location>Cairo</Location> in front of the poet's Museum and inside the <Organization>Opera</Organization> <Organization>House</Organization>.
Besides being a sculptor, el-Sigini was a talented medalist and produced numerous medals in copper, silver and gold for various official occasions, such as the medals of the Alexandria Biennale from 1955 until the end of the <Date>1970</Date>'s. He also designed projects for monuments, such as the reliefs for the monument of the Unknown Soldiers in Port Saïd and a monument of the <Date>October</Date> Victory, which was intended to be placed at the entrance of the <Location>Suez Canal</Location> but was finally not executed. El-Sigini is the author of a series of paintings inspired by rural life, sail boats and the figure of the carūsa. His works can be seen at the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Opera</Organization> <Organization>House</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the gardens of the Villa Borghese in <Location>Rome</Location>, as well as in the Mathaf <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>.

Georges Daoud Corm,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Georges-Corm-1.aspx</Address>
George Daoud Corm was a distinguished painter and francophone poet and writer. In both his artwork and writings, Corm expressed a dedication to the classical tradition of European humanism and Christian ethics.
The son of painter Daoud Corm, Georges D. Corm was born into an artistic family and expressed an equal interest in painting and writing. Although he published his first poem in <Date>1915</Date>, Corm eventually chose to train as a professional visual artist, attending the Ecole Nationale Superieure des Beaux-<Organization>Arts</Organization> <Date>from 1919 to 1921</Date>. Upon his return to <Location>Beirut</Location>, Corm received immediate recognition for his paintings, having been honored with the Gold Medal at the 1921 <Location>Beirut</Location> Exhibition Fair. A year later, he won a competition for his proposal for the <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> Medal of Merit.
Devoted to <Location>Lebanon</Location> and its cultural enrichment as a nascent nation, Corm worked diligently to promote the arts. He served as a founding member of the committee for the <Organization>Museum of Antiquities</Organization> (<Date>1922 - 1928</Date>), jury member for both the <Organization><Origin>Lebanese</Origin> National</Organization> Conservatory of <Organization>Music and Committee</Organization> for the <Organization><Origin>Lebanese</Origin> National</Organization> Anthem, and as secretary for the 1926 International Archeological <Organization>Congress</Organization> in <Location>Beirut</Location>.
In 1928, with his marriage to Marie Bekhit, Corm left <Location>Beirut</Location> to live for a period of time in <Location>Egypt</Location>, first in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and later Cairo. Active in the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> art scene, Corm helped establish in <Date>1934</Date> the "Atelier," a collective dedicated to the promotion of arts and letters.
Corm and Marie returned in <Date>1956</Date> to <Location>Beirut</Location>, by which time recognition of his artistic accomplishment was both local and international. Corm had become an officer of the <Organization>Academy of France</Organization> in <Date>1936</Date> and was elected as an Honorary Member of the <Organization>Royal Society of Arts</Organization> in <Location>London</Location> in <Date>1955</Date>. He became an Officer of the <Organization><Origin>Lebanese</Origin> National</Organization> Order of the Cedar in <Date>1958</Date> and received numerous awards and honors throughout his lifetime.
Corm's paintings, predominantly oil on canvas and pastel on paper, document the importance of portraiture in <Location>Lebanon</Location> throughout the first half of the twentieth century, a market which his father painter Daoud Corm had worked to establish. The subjects of George Corm's portraits range from royalty and figures in high society, who commissioned his work, to everyday people, including several fellaheen, or peasants. He also completed a significant number of self-portraits, the most interesting of which capture Corm in his position as a painter and document an increasing awareness of the social status of the artist in twentieth century <Location>Lebanon</Location>.
In many ways, Corm's academic style recalls the work of his father, particularly in those pieces in which the artist sets the figure against a simple, darkly shaded background. However, Corm's formal language also moves away from the conventions of the previous generation as witnessed in his use of a lighter palette and looser brushwork. Such aesthetic shifts are most evident in Corm's still life and landscapes. Moreover, Corm's oeuvre includes a substantial number of nudes, a staple of European academic painting and a genre favored by this generation of <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> artists, including Corm's great contemporary, the painter César Gemayel (<Date>1898 - 1958</Date>). Corm's most distinctive work is in the genre of landscape. In addition to a series of more conventional landscapes of <Location>Lebanon</Location>'s mountain ranges and coastline, Corm began during the early fifties to experiment with landscapes infused with spirituality, otherworldliness, and hidden symbolism.
Throughout his career as a painter, Corm continued to write and publish poetry, essays, and criticism. In 1966, he published his most well-known piece, Essai sur l'art et la civilization de ce temps, in which Corm articulates an aesthetic position in the midst of a radically divided cold war culture. Critical of both <Origin>American</Origin> consumerism and Marxist Communism, Corm advocates a return to a classical European tradition of Humanism, rooted in Christian ethics. Corm's deep commitment to humanism and Christianity is evident in his paintings, which consistently feature the human figure as well as what critics have termed, "paysages d'âme," or spiritual landscapes.
Corm exhibited extensively in <Location>Beirut</Location> and <Location>Europe</Location>, and participated in in the 1966 Spring Salon in <Location>Paris</Location>. He died in <Location>Beirut</Location> on <Date>December 13, 1971</Date>. He was honored with a retrospective of his work in <Date>1981</Date> at the <Organization>Chamber of Commerce and Industry</Organization> in <Location>Beirut</Location> and in <Date>2013</Date> with the exhibition, "<Origin>Lebanese</Origin> Painterly Humanism: Georges D. Corm," at the <Organization><Origin>American</Origin> University of Beirut Art Gallery</Organization>.

Georges Sabbagh,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Georges-Sabbagh.aspx</Address>
Georges Hanna Sabbagh was born in <Date>1887</Date> into a wealthy <Organization>Catholic</Organization> family of Syro-<Origin>Lebanese</Origin> origin established in <Location>Alexandria</Location>. He was educated at the Collège des Pères Jésuites in <Location>Cairo</Location> before his father, Hanna Sabbagh Bey, one of the stakeholders of the Heliopolis urban development project, sent him to <Location>Paris</Location> in <Date>1906</Date> to study law. During the First World War, <Date>between 1914 and 1915</Date>, Sabbagh enrolled in the <Origin>British</Origin> army. On his return to <Location>France</Location>, in <Date>1916</Date> he married the art historian and political activist Agnès Humbert (<Date>1894 -1</Date> 963), with whom he had two sons, Pierre and Jean. The same year, he spent several months in the Silencio villa of Maurice Denis located in the small village of <Location>Perros-</Location>Guirec in <Location>Brittany</Location>, the sole region of the Nabis and the painters of the École de Pont-Aven.  In 1917, Sabbagh held his first individual exhibition at the Galerie Chéron in <Location>Paris</Location>, which was a success. From then on, he became a renowned painter in <Location>Paris</Location> and was in touch with many of the artists working during the interwar period in the <Origin>French</Origin> capital, such as Modigliani, Jules-Emile Zingg, and Yves Alix and Henry de Waroquier.
In 1920, on the death of his mother, he returned to <Location>Egypt</Location> for the first time after more than ten years in <Location>Paris</Location>. While in <Location>Egypt</Location>, he produced several paintings addressing the themes of motherhood and family. He returned to <Location>France</Location> in <Date>1922</Date> and traveled regularly to Crozant, to visit his friend, the painter Armand Guillaumin (<Date>1841 - 1927</Date>). In 1928, he built a house in Ploumanac'h in <Location>Brittany</Location> close to the villa of Maurice Denis that inspired several of his paintings. Sabbagh became a <Origin>French</Origin> citizen in <Date>1930</Date>. He left <Location>France</Location> to return to <Location>Egypt</Location> in <Date>1936</Date> and lived there until 1945. During that period, he produced many landscapes, townscapes as well as still lifes. In 1951, he traveled to <Location>Switzerland</Location> where he held exhibitions in <Location>Geneva</Location> and Lausanne and died in <Location>Paris</Location> the same year, on the <Date>9th of December</Date>.
Georges Sabbagh spent most of his life in <Location>Paris</Location>, where he built his career. Although he was very attached to his <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> origins, he considered himself a painter of the École de <Location>Paris</Location>. He was a prolific artist, who produced over a thousand oil paintings as wel​l as many engravings. His early paintings are marked by the lessons of the Nabis, particularly by his teacher and friend, Maurice Denis, who initiated him into the emotional power of color and symbolism. Sabbagh, along with some of his contemporaries working in <Location>Paris</Location>, such as his friends Yves Alix and Jules-Emile Zingg, belonged to what the critic Jean Cassou called "the sacrificed generation." These artists assimilated the experiences of the Nabis, the Cubists and the Fauves, while searching for a new form of Realism. In 1918, he paid tribute to his forefathers, by representing Cézanne and Van Gogh in his painting entitled Les joueurs de cartes.
Overall, Sabbagh remained independent and original in his pictorial style, by continuously following modern trends while expressing the powerful light and colors of his country of origin. He painted many portraits of his contemporaries, friends, and family, as well as marines of <Location>Brittany</Location> and landscapes of the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin>, <Origin>French</Origin> and <Origin>Swiss</Origin> countryside. During his lifetime, Sabbagh held twenty-eight individual exhibitions and participated in more than 130 collective exhibits. He held one of his last exhibitions at the Galerie Motte in <Location>Geneva</Location> in <Date>1951</Date>. After his death, many retrospective exhibitions where organized in his honor and in <Date>1981</Date>, Pierre and Jean Sabbagh dedicated a monograph to their father that shed light on his life, work and career. His works can be seen in many collections around the world, including the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Mohammed Mahmoud Khalil Museum</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> and the Mathaf <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>. In <Date>2013</Date>, several works of Georges Sabbagh were presented in the exhibition "Tea with Nefertiti" held at Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location> and at the <Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization> in <Location>Paris</Location> under the title "Le Théorème de Nefertiti."

Gita Meh,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/m/meh-gita</Address>
<Origin>Iranian</Origin> artist Gita Meh uses visual and written language as tools to form a space for human interaction and cultural integration, goals that originate from her own personal history and experience of migration and intercultural negotiation.
While working with a range of media including painting, sculpture and installation, she is perhaps best known for her performance work. For the <Date>2009</Date> <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization>, Meh recreated Soffreh, an installation and performance piece where a table is covered with a 'cloth' made of sugar and a meal prepared. The audience are invited to join in the feast and to draw in the sugar while sharing their experiences, conversation and ultimately friendship. In Farsi, soffreh means tablecloth, and for Meh, this work 'becomes a prayer place, a dance place, a home place, it becomes belonging. It reflects the architecture of my past in a personal context.'
Meh investigates issues of place, space, pleasure and identity in work that draws on her own experience of the duality of Middle Eastern and Western cultures, then reconstructs and reinforces the best of both traditions.

Golnaz Fathi,http://www.thethirdline.com/artists/golnaz-fathi/biography/</Address>
A trained calligrapher, Golnaz Fathi has turned the literary art-form on its head by skillfully transforming known language into form and composition. She first discovered calligraphy while studying graphic design at <Location>Tehran</Location>’s <Organization>Azad University</Organization>, which she later left to train for six years at the <Organization>Calligraphy Association of Iran</Organization>. Practicing the script for over seven hours a day eventually paid off – she was the first woman to win an award for Ketabat (a genre of calligraphy) – but she soon tired of the discipline’s rules and regulations. Hence, she created a new form of expression in her paintings; an imaginary language deeply rooted in Persian tradition while simultaneously hinting at a social renaissance.
Her paintings carry traces of meaning that have no known coded alphabet. The strength of her work stems from the drive to express emotions that cannot be pinned down into words. Golnaz's works succeeds where language fails. 
Golnaz has exhibited in a number of international shows, including at The <Organization>Art</Organization> of Writing, <Organization>Art</Organization> Forum of <Location>Wiesbaden</Location>, <Location>Germany</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>); Transvangarde, Contemporary <Organization>Art</Organization> from Around the World, <Date>October</Date> <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>); Ride Like the Wind, <Organization>Sultan Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Kuwait</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>) and participated in the International Woman Artists’ Biennial, <Location>South Korea</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>). Golnaz received the Young Global Leader <Date>2011</Date> award and her works are housed in the collections of <Organization>Brighton & Hove Museum</Organization>, <Location>England</Location>; <Organization>Carnegie Mellon University</Organization>, <Location>Doha</Location>, <Location>Qatar</Location>; Asian Civilization’s Museum, <Location>Singapore</Location>; The <Organization>British Museum</Organization>, <Location>London</Location>; <Organization>Museum of Islamic Art</Organization>, <Location>Malaysia</Location>; and <Organization>Farjam Collection</Organization>, <Location>Dubai</Location>. She currently lives and works in <Location>Tehran</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>.

Hafidh al-Droubi,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Hafidh-al-Droubi.aspx</Address>
Hafidh al-Droubi (<Date>1914 - 1991</Date>) is primarily remembered for his work as an educator and developer of art pedagogy in <Location>Iraq</Location> during the mid-twentieth century. Yet he was also an active painter who possessed a talent for capturing the beauty of everyday life through a sophisticated manipulation of form and color. Al-Droubi is considered one of the pioneers of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> modern art as he made several early contributions to its development. 
Al-Droubi began his formal education in the arts at the Accademia Reale in <Location>Rome</Location>, becoming one of the first <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> artists to study abroad. He would later earn a degree from <Organization>Goldsmiths College</Organization> in <Location>London</Location> in <Date>1950</Date>. After his studies in <Location>Rome</Location>, he returned to <Location>Iraq</Location> and became an active participant in the burgeoning art scene. During the formative years between studying in <Location>Rome</Location> and <Location>London</Location>, Al-Droubi took several steps to professionalize art practice in <Location>Iraq</Location>. In 1941, he established <Location>Iraq</Location>'s first free artist studio, which gave aspiring artists a space to learn and practice art-making. In the subsequent decade, Al-Droubi opened similar artist studios at the Faculty of <Organization>Arts</Organization> and Sciences at <Organization>Baghdad University</Organization>, where he could supervise and encourage emerging talent. Many other studios like these opened around <Location>Baghdad</Location>, each headed by established artist. This system proved highly effective as many notable <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> artists received their early training from these ateliers.
Hafidh al-Droubi was a crucial figures in the development of modernism in <Location>Iraq</Location>, especially in the realm of art education. In the course of a career that included service in important positions like the Deanship of the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> and the Chair of the <Organization>Society of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> Plastic</Organization> <Organization>Arts</Organization>, he demonstrated a deep commitment to providing knowledge and resources for succeeding generations. Indeed, he was instrumental in instilling the value of art education among his student and colleagues. 
Al-Droubi's work can be appreciated <Date>today</Date> in many settings around the world, including museums, government buildings, and universities; foremost among these sites is Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>, <Location>Qatar</Location> and the <Organization>Jordan National</Organization> Gallery of Fine <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>Amman</Location>, <Location>Jordan</Location>. His works were also held at the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. Many of these were looted from the museum's collection and have yet to be recovered.

Haleh Redjaian,http://ivde.net/artists/haleh_redjaian/biography</Address>
Haleh Redjaian (b. <Date>1971</Date>, <Location>Frankfurt</Location>) lives and works in <Location>Berlin</Location>.
Redjaian’s works on paper, textiles and site-specific wall installations are grounded in geometry, but she uses its rules to reshape and retrace the apparent order of angles and lines. Her compositions subtly belie their own errors and form what she calls a ‘natural abstract language’.
Redjaian believes that these works, nimble yet systematic, refer in part to the manner in which people create, adapt to and deviate from order in their lives. She will often base her drawings on a precise background, such as grid paper, and weave graphite into its rigid structures with rough shadings and free-radical lines. Conversely, Redjaian may overlay two pieces of grid paper, drawing directly onto their discordant lines, creating a paradoxical order in the result.
A similar approach can be seen in the artist’s textiles, for which she appropriates carpets made in <Location>Kerman</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>, and lightly stitches patterns onto them. The irregularities in these hand-knotted carpets contrast with the long, smooth lines of thread she stitches over the top. A conversation of abstraction takes place within the threads of the fabric, between these two hand-made yet very different systems.
Redjaian’s recent solo exhibitions include; Same Same but different, (<Date>2013</Date>) at Vincenz Sala, <Location>Berlin</Location>, and <Date>Friday</Date> Night Lights, Sox, <Location>Berlin</Location>. She also participated in Blossom on the tree you know how I feel (<Date>2013</Date>), a dual exhibition with Henry Kleine at <Date>September</Date>, <Location>Berlin</Location>. Her first exhibition at <Organization>Gallery Isabelle van den Eynde</Organization> is as part of <Location>Nice</Location> Drawings (<Date>2015</Date>).

Altındere is also publisher and editorial team member of art-ist <Organization>Contemporary Art Magazine</Organization> in <Location>Istanbul</Location>.

Halla Bint Khalid ,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-hallabintkhalid.html</Address>
Halla Bint Khalid is an author and illustrator of children's books in both Arabic and <Origin>English</Origin>, with her own publishing house: DarJerboa Children's Books in <Location>Riyadh</Location>. She is also an established painter and has since <Date>1988</Date> become experienced in many techniques, using oilpaint, watercolour, both dry and oil pastel, gouache and acrylic. Her paintings, of which we found images online, show her working in the realistic manner of a storyteller of the past and memory. We were charmed by a passing guard in front of the windows of a nineteen fifties automobile, with only partly visible on the back seat an image of former king AbdulAziz, who was given the nick name 'Al Shuyook,' because he was not only sheikh of his tribe, but as king also head of all tribes. On her facebook page the artist made it known that she made the painting using a model for the guard and that moving outside with the model, having him stand in the sun, added to her grasp of reality, when his eyes and face reacted to the sun. Another realistic image made by the artist, which could be seen on her facebook page, is of a portrait of a man whom she describes as the 'milk brother and chaperone' of her mother. (<Date>2012</Date>)

Hamed Nada,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Hamed-Nada.aspx</Address>
Hamed Nada was born in the neighborhood of al-Khalifa near the Citadel in <Location>Cairo</Location>. As the son of a sheikh, he was raised in a religious environment and was profoundly influenced in his childhood by the everyday life of the areas of al-Khalifa and Sayyida Zeinab. In the beginning of the 1940's, he was a student at the <Organization>Secondary School of Hilmiyya</Organization> (then Faruk <Organization>Ist School</Organization>) where he developed an interest in art, psychology and philosophy. During that time, he met the painter and pedagogue Hussein Youssef Amin (<Date>1904 - 1984</Date>) who was teaching drawing in secondary schools. Amin had rejected the academic system of the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> and adopted a new method of art education, based on the individual development and freedom of expression of his students. This experience gave birth to the <Organization>Group of Contemporary Art</Organization> in which many of Amin's pupils such as Hamed Nada, Abdel Hadi el-Gazzar, Ibrahim Massouda, Maher Raif, Kamal Youssef, Salim el-Habashi, Samir Rafi and Mahmoud Khalil were included. The group held its first exhibition in <Date>May 1946</Date> at the Lycée <Origin>Français</Origin> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, presenting around 200 works mostly portraying popular life in <Location>Egypt</Location> and touching on social concerns.
In 1948, Nada joined the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, where he studied under the painters Ahmed Sabry (<Date>1889 - 1955</Date>) and Youssef Kamel (<Date>1891 - 1971</Date>) and graduated in <Date>1951</Date>. During his studies, he contributed as an illustrator and critic to the literary review, Al-Thaqafa, together with prominent writers and poets such as Taha Hussein and Louis Awad. In 1956, he was a member of the <Location>Luxor</Location> Atelier, which was created in <Date>1941</Date> by <Organization>Alexandrian</Organization> painter Mohammed Naghi (<Date>1888 - 1956</Date>) to promote the study of ancient <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> art by art students. Nada stayed in <Location>Luxor</Location> for one year, observing and studying the frescoes and reliefs of the temples in the <Location>Valley</Location> of Thebes. When he returned to <Location>Cairo</Location> in <Date>1957</Date>, he was appointed professor of painting at the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> in Alexandria the year it was founded by the sculptor Ahmad Osman (<Date>1907 - 1970</Date>). In 1960, Nada received a scholarship to study mural painting at the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> of <Location>San Fernando</Location> in <Location>Madrid</Location>. After obtaining his diploma in <Date>1961</Date>, he was appointed as a professor at the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> and became the head of the painting department in <Date>1977</Date>. He continued to work part-time as a teacher after his retirement in <Date>1984</Date> and died on the <Date>27th of May 1990</Date> after a fall in his studio in al-Ghuriyya during a power shortage.
Hamed Nada is one of the most prominent painters of the <Organization>Group of Contemporary Art</Organization>. He was one of the first modern <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> artists, along with his colleague and friend, the painter Abdel Hadi al-Gazzar, to introduce superstitious symbols and to express human psychology and unconscious fear in his paintings. His early works are strongly influenced by the social environment of the popular areas of <Location>Cairo</Location>, from which his teacher, Hussein Youssef Amin, encouraged him to draw his inspiration. Nada developed a symbolist pictorial universe nourished by legends of storytellers, popular beliefs and superstitions, as well as the magical and mysterious world of djins. His works from the 1950's depict interior scenes of poor communal households, expressing the intimacy of human resignation and fatalism. As a metaphor of the human soul, the cat, the lamp and the chair are recurrent symbols in his paintings. During the 1960's, after closely studying the arts of Ancient <Location>Egypt</Location> while a resident at the <Location>Luxor</Location> Atelier, Nada's work started to unfold into two -dimensional spaces animated by stylized and distorted human figures. He also used brighter colors to represent scenes of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> daily life and political subjects. In these works, one can sometimes discern the influence of Ragheb Ayad (<Date>1892 - 1982</Date>), though Nada brought the representation of popular culture to a symbolist and universal level by painting poetic tales of the intimate lives of working-class Egyptians. His works can be seen at the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>, Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>, as well as in numerous private collections all around the world.

Hamed Owais,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Hamed-Owais.aspx</Address>
Mohammed Hamed Owais was born in <Date>1919</Date> into a peasant family in the small village of <Location>Kafr</Location> Mansour in the governorate of Beni Soueif. There, he received his primary and secondary education before working as a metalworker. He soon realized he was not fit for this profession and moved to <Location>Cairo</Location>, where he joined the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization>. After he graduated in <Date>1944</Date>, he pursued his studies at the <Organization>Institute of Art Education</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, where he was trained by the pedagogue and critic Youssef el-Afifi. He received his diploma in <Date>1946</Date> and in the following year, he founded the <Organization>Group of Modern Art</Organization>, together with other artists of his generation, such as Gamal el-Sigini, Gazbia Sirry, Zeinab Abdel Hamid, Salah Yousri and Youssef Sida.
<Date>From 1948 to 1955</Date>, Owais worked as a drawing teacher in the <Organization>Farouk Ist Secondary School</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>. He traveled to <Location>Italy</Location> in <Date>1952</Date> and visited the <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization> where the works of <Origin>Italian</Origin> Social Realist artists were being exhibited. In 1958, he was appointed a professor at the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location> just after it was founded by the sculptor Ahmad Osman (<Date>1907 - 1970</Date>). In 1967, Owais received a scholarship to continue his studies at the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> of <Location>San Fernando</Location> in <Location>Madrid</Location> where he received his diploma in <Date>1969</Date>. <Date>From 1977 to 1979</Date>, he served as the head of the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>. He died in <Location>Cairo</Location> in <Date>2011</Date>, at the age of ninety-two.
Hamed Owais is one of the leading Social Realist painters in <Location>Egypt</Location>. His work embodies the struggle of the people of the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> working class: peasants, fishermen, laborers, factory workers, craftsmen, barbers, builders and market sellers. He was one of the first <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> artists to address the question of unemployment and the everyday life of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> laborers in the 1940's and 1950's. His work was strongly influenced by the ideas of the <Organization>Group of Modern Art</Organization>, whose members rejected Surrealism, as they believed that art should touch the masses and clearly reflect social ideologies. Owais, like other artists of his generation, such as Gamal el-Sigini, was a partisan of the ideals of the 1952 revolution, which he expressed in his works. He admired the European modernists such as Picasso and Matisse and found affinity with <Origin>Mexican</Origin> Social Realists, such as the muralists Diego Rivera (<Date>1886 - 1957</Date>) and David Alfaro Siqueiros (<Date>1896 - 1974</Date>).
Owais developed a clear and direct style portraying the life of the average <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> worker. His peasants or fishermen are massive and muscular, which reflects the strength of his social convictions. Their large bodies often seem to be enclosed in the reduced space of the canvas that appears as a metaphor of the social boundaries of the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> society. When he moved to Alexandria, Owais was influenced by the abundance of light and vibrant colors of the <Location>Mediterranean</Location> port, as well as by the work of Alexandrian painter Mahmoud Saïd (<Date>1897 - 1964</Date>). Although Hamed Owais is commonly associated with the socialist ideology of the Gamal Abdel Nasser era, his original style and work overall reflect his humanist character.
Owais' work can be seen in the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>, as well as in Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>. Although Hamed Oweis is one of the most prominent <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> artists of his generation, only a few studies have as yet been devoted to his life and work, which merit being documented in greater depth.

Hend Al-Mansour,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-hendalmansour.html</Address>
Hend Al-Mansour (<Date>1956</Date>) is an installation artist who works often with silk screen prints. She was born in Hofuf in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location> and emigrated to the <Location>U.S.A.</Location> in <Date>1997</Date> after a career in medicine. She has a master of fine arts from <Organization>Minneapolis College of Art and Design</Organization> (<Date>2002</Date>) and lives in <Location>St. Paul</Location>, <Location>Minnesota</Location>.
She writes that she uses art to achieve social change, exploring belief systems, especially those dealing with women, while cultivating the independence of Arab art from Western art and its distinction from other Middle Eastern and Islamic identities.
'My work is often a portrait of a woman,' Al-Mansour writes on her website. 'I make drawings of stylized figures and faces representing those women and integrate them with Islamic ornamentation. I then silk screen them onto fabrics, often using henna and dye and often repetitively. I use large sheets of silk, wool, canvas, or other cottons. Then I build shrines and tents with these fabrics, creating spaces in which the viewer walks barefoot.'

Hesam Rahmanian,http://ivde.net/artists/hesam_rahmanian/biography</Address>
Hesam Rahmanian (b. <Location>Knoxville</Location>, <Date>1980</Date>) lives and works in <Location>Dubai</Location>.

From this simple bricolage, Rahmanian searches for ways that he can develop his impressions, either on canvas or as assemblage, with a playfulness and spontaneity that is faithful to his initial glimpse. This first-thought-best-thought way of working has emerged steadily from the artist’s early painting series’, which were underpinned by metaphor and social commentary.

In <Date>2014</Date>, Rahamanian and the Haerizadehs participated as a collective in the <Organization>Robert Rauschenberg Foundation</Organization>’s residency programme in Captiva, <Location>Florida</Location>.

Hojat Amani,http://www.artclvb.com/artist/hojat-amani</Address>
Hojatollah Amani was born in <Location>Lorestan</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>, in <Date>1978</Date>. Having grown up in a large family, Hojat rarely had the time to pursue his artistic interests, and struggled to express himself creatively. However, things changed for the young artist when he pursued a degree in painting at the <Organization>University of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Esfahan</Location>, and later, a Master of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> from <Organization>Tehran University</Organization>.
Amani's <Organization>angels</Organization>, in all their colours and forms, are laden with the rich folklore, mythology, and imagery of his native <Location>Iran</Location>. From the winged disc of the Farvahar, to the angelic deities (Yazatas) featured prominently in Zoroastrianism and pre-Islamic <Location>Iran</Location>, winged beings and the concept of <Organization>angels</Organization> itself - thought to have originated in <Location>Iran</Location> - have played a central role in the <Origin>Iranian</Origin> psyche for centuries.

Huda Lutfi is a cultural, feminist historian by professional training whose work in the field of the visual arts translates these affiliations in multiple complex ways. In her artwork, Huda excavates and makes vocal the silenced voices and marginalized spaces that cross various historical and cultural contexts mapping, as it does the politics of her engagement both as a historian and as an artist. Cultural hybridity is Huda's genealogy; it lies at the heart of her work enabling her to travel among and dialogue with many artistic traditions with which she shares the desire to liberate the human spirit and imaginary while tracing an inner meditative state of being.
<Location>Cairo</Location> is one of the main sources that inspire Huda's work living and working as she does within the ancient metropolis. In her art work she reinvents <Location>Cairo</Location> through its found objects collected over the years from some of the city’s main “repositories” from Suq al-Imam in <Location>Cairo</Location>’s <Location>City</Location> of the Dead to the downtown Azbakiyya bookstalls, that represent <Location>Cairo</Location>’s cosmopolitan and global culture all the way to Tahrir itself during <Location>Egypt</Location>’s ongoing revolution. Huda's more recent work in photo montage bears testimony to the extent to which Cairenes’ lives, in the everyday and in revolt have impacted her artistic vision and further sharpened her politics of visual engagement.

Huda Totonji,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-hudatotonja.html</Address>
Huda Totonji might exist in an imagined space somewhere in between <Location>Washington</Location> and <Location>Jeddah</Location>. This is a space where masculine poetry is mastered by learning and examination and from where travel is possible in both directions. In <Location>Jeddah</Location> the artist may land herself as a philosophical doctor of visual technology and in <Location>Washington</Location> she may arrive as a true master of calligraphy. She has earned both these qualifications. The artist-researcher and teacher will not have herself pinned down in a single category. She 'chooses to bounce between image and text,' is what she writes on her website, and to this should be added that she believes good restaurants should manage to serve a large menu. Her art ranges from painting in several genres, such as portrait, landscape, still life and calligraphy, to mixed media installations and performances. In none of it however she will represent women 'physically' as was often done in the history of western figurative art. <Organization>Her George Mason University</Organization> master thesis installation Birdwatcher (<Date>2004</Date>) seemed to mock such orientalist paintings as Ingres's Grande Odalisque or anything of the like by Matisse and other artists who are central to the western canon of art. In fact Orientalism itself might qualify as 'birdwatching' if you come to think of it. Huda Totonja would have disappointed the oriental minded gentlemen in their <Location>London</Location> and Parisian chambers and clubs. Her giant birdcage was empty and only feathers and hairpins were left for such eager-to-collect and very civilised men. So was it about <Location>Iraq</Location> and <Location>Afghanistan</Location>? The artist probably never intended it to be like that. But, whoever thought that there would be a giant bird of wings, bones and flesh to be caught in that war, might have better reviewed Totonja's empty cage first. This is what she says: that the female vision is central to what she makes.

Iman Raad,http://ivde.net/artists/iman_raad/biography</Address>
<Origin>Iranian</Origin> artist Iman Raad (born <Location>Mashad</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>, <Date>1979</Date>) draws on ancient visual heritages from <Location>North Africa</Location>, the <Location>Middle East</Location> and <Location>central Asia</Location> to weave vivid embroideries, drawings and designs that reconcile traditional mystical and imagined talismans and folkloric tales with contemporary existence. Raad transforms the meaning of the demon texts, transforming the setting of the words to his colourful and richly sources visual language. He mocks, taunts, and challenges, presenting playful offerings of hope as well as despair and criticism.

Janet Hagopian,http://www.artclvb.com/artist/janet-hagobian</Address>
The experience of being caught in three cultures not wholly different, and yet not the same, dominates my creative work. Each of my pieces offers a glimpse into the social and religious realities that shape my identity, and those of the Armenian women living in the <Location>Middle East</Location>. In my work, I pay a great deal of attention to the structures of forms, shapes, and colours, which create the inhabitable space that begins to resemble stories and life experiences behind the composition. The idea is to allow viewers to detach themselves from notions of normality, and question their reason for existence. These shapes symbolise the idea of isolation conferred by this perspective.My pieces are composed of various layers that convey the concept of the painting. My imagination explores and displays shape variations in order to communicate strong compositions. Painting such shapes are challenging, but viewing them allows audiences to observe without feeling any restrictions or constraints.

Javad Azimi (b. <Date>1977</Date>, Gorgan, <Location>Iran</Location>) studied at the <Organization>Art University of Tehran</Organization> and subsequently returned to his hometown in <Location>Northern Iran</Location> to live and work. Azimi grew up surrounded by nature, and the landscapes of his region, colourful and ever-changing, are a vital source of inspiration in his painting.
Besides the influence of natural environments, Azimi’s work reveals his profound absorption with his cultural heritage, from the crafts of Gorgan and Qajari painting to Seljuki art and architecture.
Azimi presents two bodies of work in this exhibition. The first group, a series of still lifes, are celebratory banquets of elaborate decoration, bejeweled with hints of the artist’s inspirations, yet primitive and instinctic in their hand-painted appearance. The second body is a collection of paintings of fragile sleeping women who lie stranded, in a state of abandon. They, as with the still lifes, hover isolated in spaces that suggest emptiness and tranquility simultaneously.

Jilali Gharbaoui,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Jilali-Gharbaoui.aspx</Address>
Jilali Gharbaoui began taking painting classes while in secondary school in <Location>Fes</Location>, at the Académie des Arts. With the support of the novelist Ahmed Sefrioui, director of fine arts in <Location>Rabat</Location>, Gharbaoui was able to receive a scholarship to study at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts of <Location>Paris</Location>, where he took classes with Jean Souverbie and often visited the atelier <Location>La Grande</Location> Chaumière. He studied an additional year in <Location>Rome</Location>, and often returned to <Location>Paris</Location>, where he was introduced as part of the "groupe des informels" at the Salon Comparaison in <Date>1959</Date> by art critic Pierre Restany. He was particularly influenced by classical Flemish painting after a trip to <Location>Amsterdam</Location> in <Date>1962</Date>. Gharbaoui suffered from severe mental illness, and was hosted on multiple occasions by Father Denis Martin at the monastery of Toumliline in the Middle <Location>Atlas Mountains</Location>. In <Date>the late 1960s</Date>, major <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> art collector Abderrahman Serghini bought a large part of his works and studio. Like other <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> artists at the time, Gharbaoui's extensive travels were motivated by the lack of infrastructure and support for the arts in <Location>Morocco</Location>, and he was outspoken about these issues in print, as in the 1967 "fiches et questionnaires" in the leftist cultural journal Souffles. In <Date>1971</Date>, Gharbaoui's body was found on a public bench in the Champ de Mars. His body was repatriated to <Location>Morocco</Location> by André Malraux, and he is buried in <Location>Fes</Location>.
In Gharbaoui's short lifetime, he played a major role in furthering the debates around <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> modernism. Along with Ahmed Cherkaoui, Jilali Gharbaoui is considered one of the founders of modernism in <Location>Morocco</Location>. While Gharbaoui felt himself and his art to be deeply influenced by <Location>Morocco</Location>, particularly by the colors of <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> earth, it was not in the direct and traceable way of Cherkaoui's work. Many contemporaneous <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> artists, such as Farid Belkahia and Mohammed Melehi, worked to root their modernist abstractions in the signs and symbols of <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> visual culture. Unlike his contemporaries, however, Gharbaoui distanced himself from these debates, centering his work on the gesture of painting itself. Although Gharbaoui worked with both sculpture and painting, he is best known for the striking colors and violent brush-strokes of his gestural abstractions on canvas, paper, and wood. Very early works by Gharbaoui are relatively representational or focus on geometric abstraction, but later works are easily identified by a consistent style of loose abstract work that focuses on the movement of the brush itself. The paintings deliberately highlight the hand of the artist and often build up texture through thick layers of paint, showcasing both the interplay of colors and lines as well as the materiality of the paint itself.
During his lifetime, Gharbaoui exhibited widely in <Location>Morocco</Location> and internationally, in <Location>Egypt</Location>, <Location>France</Location>, <Location>the Netherlands</Location>, the <Location>United States</Location>, and <Location>Brazil</Location>. As part of the "groupe des informels," Gharbaoui participated in an exhibition that moved to <Location>Japan</Location>, <Location>Mexico</Location>, and <Location>Germany</Location>.  Particularly since <Date>the 1990s</Date>, Gharbaoui's importance has been celebrated through a number of exhibitions and books. Gharbaoui was the focus of a <Date>1993</Date> retrospective at the <Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization>, as well as the monograph Fulgurances Gharbaoui by Yasmina Filali, published the same year in <Location>Casablanca</Location>. A film on Gharbaoui was additionally commissioned by Filali and the <Organization>IMA</Organization> by Faten Safieddine. Within <Location>Morocco</Location>, the <Organization>Museum Bank</Organization> Al-Maghrib (<Date>2011</Date>) and the Villa des Arts/Fondation ONA of <Location>Rabat</Location> and <Location>Casablanca</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>) have also hosted large retrospectives of Gharbaoui's work.

Jorge Tacla’s paintings from the Escombros series represent a space of social rupture. Motivated by the bombings in <Location>Beirut</Location> in <Date>2006</Date> and in <Location>Oklahoma City</Location> in <Date>1995</Date>, this series emerges from the joints of a new architecture arising in the wake of catastrophe, be it natural or man-made. Jowhara Al-Saud ,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-jowharaalsaud.html</Address>
Jowhara Al-Saud (<Date>1978</Date>) is one of those people who have lived 'out of <Location>Jeddah</Location>' in <Location>America</Location>. In <Location>Massachusetts</Location> she was thoroughly educated in the arts and most interestingly started with film theory to end with mixed media at the school of The <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Boston</Location>. Presently her <Origin>American</Origin> home appears to be <Location>New York</Location>.Al-Saud's work can be seen on her own website and on sites of several galleries in <Location>London</Location>, <Location>New York</Location> and soon in <Location>Berlin</Location> and even Amsterdam. Of these websites only the artist's own site allows us to have a look at older work like White Trash Barbie and a harrowing fantasy of <Location>Orlando</Location> Barbie murders in what looks like a set designed for the Thunderbirds starring in a Hitchcock movie.
On her website Al-Saud allows us not only older work, but also more words than galleries usually find necessary. They are about her current project, which is a series by the name of 'Out of line.' Again, it looks like a storyboard, but this time the movie is not about reality dolls but about the real lives of <Origin>Saudi</Origin>'s whose pictures have been brought in line with demands of censorship on showing personal imagery. For this the artist has removed their skin and faces. The people in the images may however not really be bothered by any official censorship. Foreign stamps and airmail letters imply they are mostly 'out of border' living <Origin>Saudi</Origin>'s, which raises a question. Is it the official, sometimes silly, censorship in KSA that Al-Saud was dealing with or is it perhaps the universal struggle every artist has with telling all without implicating family and friends, who prefer privacy over the stage? It seems that where the official censor stays within the borders of KSA this unofficial one reaches far beyond such lines.About the adapted work the artist writes: 'when reduced to sketches, the images achieved enough distance from the original photographs that neither subjects nor censors could find them objectionable. For me, they became autonomous, relatable, pared down narratives.' And she adds a note on photography in general: 'I try to undermine any documentary authority it may possess as a medium.' 
It does confuse: narratives without authority. We may get lost or put our trust in the titles the artist has given her images. Some of them like <Organization>Clowns & Jokers</Organization> and The Harrowing Adventures of.. appear rooted in the exercise of bringing Barbie dolls to reality, but now reflect behaviour of perfectly normal people, who may prefer to live within their borders. (<Date>25 June 2010</Date>)

Kassab Bachi
,http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=182155/nArtist,</Address> born <Location>Damascus</Location>, <Location>Syria</Location>, 1934.
