Khalid al-Jader,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Khalid-al-Jader.aspx</Address>
Dr. Khalid al-Jader (<Date>1922 - 1988</Date>) was a highly active participant in the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> modern art movement. He held several prominent positions and memberships in art institutions and organizations throughout his distinguished career. Al-Jader's work is known for its rural landscapes and village vistas rendered in sweeping brushstrokes. He was attracted to Impressionism and his pieces exhibit many of its aesthetic devices. However, his exploration of style and subject matter transcended these aesthetic similarities to produce what the Palestinian writer, Jabra Ibrahim Jabra, calls a distinct <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> nature.
A gifted student, Al-Jader studied at the <Organization>College of Law</Organization> and the <Organization>Institute of Fine Art</Organization> concurrently, graduating in <Date>1946</Date> with degrees in art and law. He then travelled to <Location>Paris</Location> on scholarship to study at the Ècole Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-<Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Date>1954</Date> and earned a Ph.D. in the History of Islamic <Organization>Art</Organization> from the Sorbonne. While in <Location>Paris</Location>, Al-Jader joined the Salon de <Location>Paris</Location>.  
Upon returning to <Location>Baghdad</Location>, Al-Jader accepted the deanship at the <Organization>Institute of Fine Arts</Organization> where he stayed for several years. In 1962 under the supervision of the president of <Organization>Baghdad University</Organization>, he founded the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> along with his colleagues Dr. Aziz Shalal Aziz and Dr. As'ad Abdul Razak, and later worked as its dean. Through these administrative activities, Al-Jader demonstrated his engagement in the development of an institutionalized form of art education in <Location>Iraq</Location>. Concurrent with his academic positions, Al-Jader served as chair of the <Organization>National Committee</Organization> for Plastic <Organization>Art</Organization> with <Organization>UNESCO</Organization>.
Al-Jader was equally dedicated to his own artistic practice. His style throughout is so consistent that taken together they amount to a vision of <Location>Iraq</Location>. His loose, rough brushstrokes are accentuated by his use of contrasted, vibrant colors. Al-Jader's markets, streets, and villages are rendered with frenzied daubs of thick paint, making the canvas pulsate with latent energy. The human figures that populate his scenes are part of this rhythm as they conduct their daily lives. Their vitality merely adds to an already dynamic landscape. Although this dynamism was ever-present in Al-Jader's work, it reached a fever pitch in his later paintings with his scenes almost completely abstracted by conflicting strokes of the paintbrush. The seeming chaos of Al-Jader's canvases belies an underlying organization that hints at the precision with which the artist executed his canvases. Each color swath is deliberate in application and each figure is carefully placed to create an expert composition.
Al-Jader participated in many important artists' societies, including the Pioneers, the Impressionists, and the <Organization>Society of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> Plastic</Organization> Artists. He also spent time as the head of the <Organization>Society of <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> Artists</Organization>. The painter was also a prolific exhibitor participating in several group exhibitions all over the world. These included Al-Wasiti Festival, the first Arab Biennale, and shows in <Location>Paris</Location>, <Location>Cairo</Location>, <Location>Brussels</Location>, <Location>Berlin</Location>, the <Location>United States</Location>, <Location>India</Location>, <Location>Poland</Location>, and <Location>Russia</Location>. He also mounted a number of one-man exhibitions in <Location>Baghdad</Location> (1955, 1957), <Location>Berlin</Location> (<Date>1959</Date>), <Location>Prague</Location> and <Location>Bucharest</Location> (<Date>1960</Date>), <Location>Denmark</Location> (<Date>1965</Date>), and <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location> (<Date>1968</Date>). Thus his work was both domestically and internationally visible.   
Al-Jader is valued as a meticulous painter. He also demonstrated this thoroughness in his administrative duties. He was known to have held his students and faculty to a very high standard, a standard that he no doubt applied to himself. His work can be appreciated <Date>today</Date> at Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location> and the <Organization>Jordan National</Organization> Gallery of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Amman</Location>.

Lawrence Abu Hamdan ,http://galerinon.com/lawrence-abu-hamdan</Address> 
<Location>London</Location> based artist Lawrence Abu Hamdan’s work attempts to measure the contemporary relationship between listening and politics, borders, human rights, testimony, truth and international law, through the production of longer narrative audio documentaries and essays, audio-visual installations, graphic design, sculpture, photography, workshops and performance.
His work with sound and its intersection with politics originates from a long running engagement with DIY music and events and out of this developed an approach to the politics of amplification which borrows from many disciplines. Most recently the artist has been formally engaged with the radio documentary/essay working on a trilogy of works with radio producer Russel Finch which attempt to inhabit, appropriate and push the limits of audio aesthetic practice and journalism.
As an artist whose fascination with and sensitivity to the types of listening operative in todays legal and political forums his work attempts to enter these forums themselves. Lina Gazzaz,,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-linagazzaz.html</Address>

Lulwah Al-Homoud,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-lulwahalhomoud.html</Address>
Lulwah Al-Homoud is designing a new path from the roots of our earliest thinking to the present and, who knows, the end or a final idea. She does so without talking and without the help of preachers or diplomats. She simply uses mathematics, Islamic mathematics and mathematics which were there already, to recalculate the essential words of creation. 'She calls it The Language of Existence,' somebody wrote, so it is, if she did so. Its alphabet exists of the 99 most beautiful names of Allah, which Al-Homoud is 'deconstructing and recallibrating' into patterns reminicent of Islamic geometry. The new patterns interestingly include, from the moment of the first human cell devision, all brothers born before and after Abraham. So we see, believe and calculate her work.
The way in which the artist works, from an understanding that Arabic letters have proportions which represent mathematical codes, is to use these codes to deconstruct or break letters into simpler lines as building material for new geometrical designs. For the computation of the break Al-Homoud went looking for codes by writing on ancient 'Vedic squares' from <Location>North India</Location>. Such squares contain a multiplication system, which she altered to fit better the growth and development of humanity. She changed the numerical progression of 1 to 9 in the square's first row and column to a progression of 1,2,4,6,8,16,32,64 etc in reference to human cells which multiply and grow by devision, as often religions do too. The Vedic square then needs mergers, because like humans it allows no more than one digit in its own cells. So 16 becomes 7, 32 becomes 5 and 64 becomes 10 and then 1. Just one. Try this yourself: numbering 64 religions and then recomputating them into 1. And if you skip the math but employ preachers and diplomats, then you understand why there is art. If just to think of an idea and not immediately abandon it.
The end result of The Language of Existence is a computer generated geometrical design, which was recallibrated from the deconstructed words and silkscreen printed on paper (editions of 20, 118,8 x 89,8 cm). By the end of <Date>2008</Date> the artist could show around 14 finished names of the most beautiful 99 ones. 
Coming from the very different visual tradition of calligraphy Al-Homoud's art is similar in it's basic act to what Mondrian or Malevich have done with their western figurative world. Her recallibrated The Last would survive well in the company of Malevich's ultimate vision <Location>Black Square</Location>.
Al-Homoud is from Riyadh, where she majored in sociology at <Organization>King Saud University</Organization>, and was the first <Origin>Saudi</Origin> to complete a MA at <Organization>Central St Martins College of Art</Organization> and Design in <Location>London</Location>. She has had lessons in calligraphy from Rashid Butt and was inspired by Ahmed Moustafa to learn about a 10th century theoretical system of calligraphy. In <Date>2006</Date> she participated in a <Organization>British Museum</Organization> managed project to have Arab artists work in schools. She spent six weeks at a school in <Location>London</Location> 'Exploring Calligraphy and Arab design.' She has participated in and co-curated the <Date>2008</Date> <Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization> exhibition in SOAS <Location>Brunei</Location> Gallery. Her work was chosen by Christie's in <Date>April 2009</Date> for their <Location>Middle East</Location> auction in <Location>Dubai</Location>.

Maha Al-Khalawi,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-mahaalkhalawi.html</Address>

Maha Malluh,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-mahamalluh.html</Address>
Maha Malluh is an artist, born from the traditional region of <Location>Najd</Location>, who has met the challenges of modernity that have come so overwhelmingly to <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. She has exhibited her art since <Date>1976</Date> and has in later years acquired a <Organization>BA</Organization> in <Origin>English</Origin> literature and a Californian certificate in design and photography.
Continuous in her artwork, that started with collages and developed into photograms, is her use of symbolic and real imagery to express her opinion about life in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. Sometimes loudly, as is the case with her photograms showing 'babies' which have titles such as Overpopulation and Bad news. Sometimes less outspoken, when she combines images of traditional make-up tools with modern MacDonalds advertising.
'To control both quality and content,' she writes on her website, she built her own darkroom in <Location>Riyadh</Location> to develop and print her images. They are black and white, but rampant with colour waiting to be seen or just recognized. Sometimes there are limits to what a photogram will show: the ears of Minnie Mouse do not do well in black and white. So we are left with Mickey only. It is The Mouse from her series Capturing Light (<Date>2005</Date>). A <Origin>Saudi</Origin> mouse with <Origin>American</Origin> ears, being fed from two bottles of milk. Captured.
In <Date>2007</Date> Malluh staged an event in Galerie O for which her work was mass produced on bags in a drive not only to capture light but also the eyes and minds of young people and moving them away from Luis Vuitton to ideas of a serious nature. And perhaps the sunset.
Maha Malluh believes that <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location> in this hectic world needs art more than ever to move and arrest the eye - the core business of real artists. (<Date>2009</Date>).

Mahdi Al Jeraibi,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-mahdialjeraibi.html</Address>
Mahdi Al Jeraibi (<Date>1969</Date>) works as an art teacher in <Location>Mecca</Location> where children write and scratch, but hardly draw on their school desks. Really, I wondered: who or what for 25 years made these children not mix rabbits and automobiles with their doodle writing and daydream scratching? It is what we should do: wonder and ask. It is the artist who wants us to. About the school desks which he collected and presented as readymades for the audience to place on a wall. 'ALL WERE HERE,' it read about the desks and note that the exhibition was in <Location>Jeddah</Location> and not in <Location>Mecca</Location>. The artist wants dialogue about our memories. He presumes we can do so in a Socratic manner, disagreeing and convincing each other, using points of reference which work for us all. He wants us to explain and argue about traces of our past, which he simply picks up from the floor or out of the school's backyard. In a way he wants us to go back in time as if we were to cut off our hair; and then he will collect it and remind us that we will grow it back again, unable to change its colour or substance. It changes only slowly with the passing of generations. So is there no point in painting it for any future? Actually there is. Dark haired people who paint their hair blond, lure their partner's blond hair genes into changing direction. So I read somewhere in a scientific paper. In the end the dialectic argument aims to convince. But on the rational level, in the educated world, in the world of Mahdi Al-Jeraibi, in the world of <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>'s first conceptual artist, we should be optimistic about the potential of art to achieve faster results. Convincing in Al Jeraibi's <Location>Mecca</Location> is possible on, well, a moments notice, simply by listening and allowing yourself to be convinced. Of his art perhaps. Of his sombre Zincographs which are as far removed from golden palms in <Location>Dubai</Location> hotels as one can possibly imagine. They are of the moon, rather than of the sun - there is no real zinc involved - shining a dark light on the crossing over of religious rituals of pilgrims, superstitions which survive in <Location>Mecca</Location> and a fear we have of a know known future of using DNA to recreate. The Zincographs are sculptered paintings: large wooden frames in which the artist has fixated hair he has collected of a variaty of people in a thick plate of hot wax. They are reminicent of ancient <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> wax portraits to a conceptual mind only. The hair he used he collected both from anonymous pilgrims - beware of <Location>Mecca</Location> barbers selling clones - and from individuals he knows well and managed to convince. As one of them is said to be his wife, there is a question that arises in the mirror of memories. Will Al Jeraibi, when his wife's hair is eventually used to clone, be the first Pygmalion to have succeed in giving true life himself to a women of his perfect imagination? We should grant her that. The artist himself is the object of imagination too. The Foundation Al Mansouria who has supported him against the dragons of misunderstanding and disinterest has put him forward as a 'model for the quest of the young and serious.' We should grant them that too. (<Date>September 30, 2009</Date>).

Manal Al Dowayan,http://nadour.org/artists/manal-al-dowayan/</Address>
In her photographic series and more recently her installations, Manal Al-Dowayan examines the <Origin>Saudi</Origin> identity.  Questions raised by her work concern the female condition, symbols of community loyalties, technological changes and the relationship to the world that these imply.  Her art combines a graphic yet refined aesthetic: elegant portraits of women, neon writing, what would seem glamourous motifs (jewels, doves, tattoos).  But an incongruous element will always be thrown in to disturb these studied seductive scenes: (workman’s tools in the series I am,) or the direct use of a paint bomb and a stencil (And We Had No Shared Dreams).
Manal Al-Dowayan was born in <Date>1973</Date> in <Location>Dhahran</Location>, in the East of <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>.  Whilst studying advanced computing (in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>, then Boston and <Location>London</Location>), she learnt how to shoot and develop photographs. Having worked for a long time as an engineer for a national oil company, in a very confined and predominantly male environment (only 3% of <Origin>Saudi</Origin> women are active in the professional world) she now devotes herself entirely to her artistic practice.
Her artworks have been promoted by institutions such as the <Organization><Origin>British</Origin> Council</Organization> and the <Organization>United Nations</Organization>.  She was in residence in <Date>2009</Date> at the <Organization>Delfina Foundation</Organization> in <Location>London</Location>, and has taken part since <Date>2008</Date> in the project “<Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization>” with which she has shown at the <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization> in <Date>2009</Date> and <Date>2011</Date>, in <Location>Berlin</Location> and <Location>Istanbul</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>) as well as in <Location>Dubai</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>).  She has participated in exhibitions such as Self Representation in the Arabian Gulf in <Location>Doha</Location>, <Location>Qatar</Location>, in <Date>2007</Date>, Reorientations in <Location>Brussels</Location>, in <Date>2008</Date>, at the <Organization>Barjeel Foundation</Organization> in <Location>Sharjah</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location> in <Date>2010</Date> and in Strike Oppose in <Date>2011</Date>, Fluid Form I, in <Location>Seoul</Location>, <Location>Korea</Location> in <Date>2010</Date>, Freedom to Create at <Location>Sarajevo</Location> in <Date>2011</Date>.

Manal Dowayan,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-manaldowayan.html</Address>
Manal Dowayan (<Date>1973</Date>)from <Location>Dhahran</Location> is not the only artist who has enjoyed looking at boats moving on an <Location>Amsterdam</Location> canal as is evident in her photo series <Date>Summer</Date>. She is surely, however, the only such artist who can and will say: I am a citizen of <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>, not speaking on her own behalf, but informing the world of her private experiences in the general context of being a professionally working woman in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. She does so with several series of black and white photographs of women she meets dealing with their <Origin>Saudi</Origin> heritage and daily life. I am a Mother and I am a Petroleum Engineer are self evident titles in her I am series. Dowayan, being a freelance photographer with an education in information technology, works for an oil company. She is now its creative director. In her series Beyond the veil and The Choice again women pose in front of Dowayan's camera. The choices Dowayan deals with are not mentioned but shown and numbered. The Choice V shows, for example, a woman in traditional dress holding a tennis racket. Or in Choice II, perhaps the most daring in terms of the question it seems to ask, a female hand holds a pen which has just crossed out a word on a page full of repetition. Her photographs are very popular with collectors, is what I was told by <Organization>Edge of Arabia</Organization>, in which exhibition she participated in both <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>) and <Location>Venice</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>). A The Choice photo of a <Origin>Saudi</Origin> woman holding a steering wheel was printed in <Origin>Dutch</Origin> magazine Kunstbeeld as an iconic image of the exhibition, providing well for the notions people have in <Location>the Netherlands</Location> about <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. But, one should also have a look at her close up of feet dancing in <Origin>Spanish</Origin> Scenes and admire simply the elegant black and white forms beyond any context of meaning; fingers that fly like swans and do not point to any future. On the future of art in <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location> however, Dowayan has sound ideas which she expressed in Arab News. She told the paper that there should be more patronage of the arts in the Kingdom itself and not just by a government system of prizes. The country needs homegrown private foundations to sustain the arts and crafts. Says Manal Dowayan, who listens well to King Abdullah. The custodian of mosques said of <Origin>Saudi</Origin> women: that they are citizens of <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. And some of them even travel to <Location>Amsterdam</Location>. (<Date>2009</Date>).

Mariam Ghani,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/g/ghani-mariam</Address>
Mariam Ghani uses video, installation, performance, photography and text to explore notions of place, identity, community and history in work that often has an aspect of public dialogue or engagement.
Her collaboration with Erin Ellen Kelley for the 9th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> (<Date>2009</Date>) was no exception. Smile, you're in <Location>Sharjah</Location> is a study of the patterns and rhythms of human movement in the shared spaces of the city. Occasionally Ghani and Kelly will intervene to highlight certain aspects of this social choreography but the final result is a work that gives a sense of the currents and connectivity underpinning and sustaining the life of <Location>Sharjah</Location>.
Ghani’s work has been screened and exhibited internationally and some projects such as <Location>Kabul</Location>: Partial Reconstructions (<Date>2002-07</Date>) and Index of the Disappeared (<Date>2004</Date>-ongoing), span several years. Her work has been shown widely in exhibitions and screenings including at Futura, <Location>Prague</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), CEPA <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Buffalo</Location>, <Location>New York</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), Momenta Art, <Location>Brooklyn</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), <Location>Beijing</Location> <Organization>Biennial</Organization> (<Date>2009</Date>), <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> (<Date>2009</Date>), Creative Time, <Location>NY</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>), <Organization>National Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Washington</Location> DC (<Date>2008</Date>), and <Organization>Tate Modern</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2007</Date>).
Ghani has a <Organization>BA</Organization> in Comparative Literature from NYU (<Date>2000</Date>) and an MFA from the <Organization>School of Visual Arts</Organization>, <Location>New York</Location> (<Date>2002</Date>). She teaches at <Organization>Cooper Union</Organization> and in the Art and Public Policy programme at NYU. She has been awarded the NYFA and Soros New Americans Fellowships as well as numerous grants and residencies in the <Location>US</Location> and <Location>Europe</Location>, most recently the LMCC Swing Space Residency, <Location>Governors Island</Location>, (<Date>2010</Date>). Mariam Ghani was born in <Location>New York</Location>, <Location>USA</Location>, in <Date>1978</Date> and is based in <Location>Brooklyn</Location>.

Marwan Sahmarani is primarily a painter whose works relate to art history, with its timeless and recurrent themes, but also to contemporary life and to his own experiences. His works draw from both his Western cultural education and to his oriental identity, blending Islamic and  Mesopotamian art and iconography with that of ancient <Location>Greece</Location>, <Location>Rome</Location> and the great masters of the <Location>Western Renaissance</Location>. Diverse themes including politics, sociology, war and sexuality, and allusions to his  cultural background and experience of war and exile are all dealt with in his work. Sahmarani uses oil, ink and  watercolor as his primary mediums of expression and has created a unique language that is at once raw, and bare as it is sumptuous.

He has had solo exhibitions in <Location>Beirut</Location>, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>Montreal</Location> and <Location>Dubai</Location> and group exhibitions in <Location>Washington</Location> and <Location>Mexico</Location>.  His works have also featured in 'Told/ Untold /Retold' at Mathaf, <Location>Doha</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), 'All  about <Location>Beirut</Location>' at Kunsthalle whiteBOX, <Location>Munich</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>) and the 'The Feast of the Damned' at the <Organization>Museum of Art</Organization> and Design, <Location>New York</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>).  In <Date>2010</Date> Sahmarani was the recipient of the <Organization>Abraaj Capital</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization> Prize and his work 'The Feast of the Damned' was showcased at <Organization>Art Dubai</Organization> that year.

Moataz Nasr,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/n/nasr-moataz</Address>

Mohamed Bourouissa,http://nadour.org/artists/mohamed-bourouissa/</Address>
Since <Date>2002</Date>, Mohamed Bourouissa has been developing a fine art photography practice but also drawing and video works deeply rooted in social reality. Primarily working around representations of a contemporary urban environment, the artist is interested in geographical and social spaces usually represented by stereotypes. Suburbs (Périphérique, <Date>2005-2008</Date>), prison (Temps mort, <Date>2009</Date>) or television (the Ecran series, <Date>2007</Date>).

Mohammed Ben Ali Rbati,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Mohammed-Ben-Ali-Rbati.aspx</Address>
If not the very first, Mohammed Ben Ali Rbati is certainly one of the earliest modern <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> painters. He is often referred to as an easel painter, though he eschewed canvas for watercolors on paper.  Much of the history of modern painting in <Location>Morocco</Location> began with Rbati. Little has been written about him, and much of the information is contextual. It is clear that he received early support by European artists in <Location>Tangier</Location>, where he was based for most of his life. Many European painters came through <Location>Morocco</Location> and especially Tangier in the nineteenth and early twentieth century. <Location>Tangier</Location> was, at the time, an international zone, and was therefore a place conducive to international encounters. In 1903, Rbati became the cook for Sir John Lavery, a portrait painter from <Location>Ireland</Location>, who discovered that Rbati was a talented painter that practiced watercolor painting in his spare time with care and attention to detail. Rbati had his first exhibition at the Goupil Gallery in <Location>London</Location> in <Date>1916</Date>. Although Rbati had no formal arts training, his exposure to painting and the availability of watercolors in <Location>Tangier</Location>, thanks to the sizeable <Origin>British</Origin> population, awakened within him a desire to paint the daily scenes by which he was surrounded. 
Rbati's figurative watercolors on paper focus on <Location>Tangier</Location>, its Kasbah, and its inhabitants. The paintings depict an extensive cross-section of the local population, showing men gathered around musicians or snake charmers, halqas (story-telling circles) in the Kasbah, and people walking through the streets, as well as scenes in cafes, at festivals, and in lavish interiors. Figures are often simplified and demarcated with clear strokes, the folds of djellabas suggested by well-placed lines, highlighting the brightness of the multiple colors. Many of the watercolors feature large groups of men or women, and the focus is often more on the larger scene than on individualizing details. The geometric lines of city walls, mosques, or intricate geometric tiling contrast with the curved and flowing lines of the figures in their traditional dress. In many examples of Rbati's work, the plane of the picture is entirely flat, with no reference to dimensionality, and the paintings sometimes include decorative borders. However, there are also numerous examples of watercolors that go beyond a flat plane in order to document more closely the scenes the artist witnessed. In these, shadows are clearly placed under each figure, showing the artist's experimentation and study into ways of showing light and multi-dimensionality. While often described in terms of the spontaneity of his expression, the varied treatment of the picture plane suggests the artist's interest in deliberately simplifying the forms as part of a style, not as a default. Rbati consistently signed the front of his canvases, always in Arabic.
Rbati is often left out of histories of painting in <Location>Morocco</Location>, which in general focus more on the latter half of the twentieth century. However, as a 1918 exhibition of easel paintings at the Hotel Excelsior in <Location>Casablanca</Location> suggests, there were visiting and local artists working in <Location>Morocco</Location> through the protectorate era (<Date>1912 - 1956</Date>). There are a few examples of self-taught figurative <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> painters whose works have been preserved. Many of these artists captured daily life and locales, including Abdeslam El Fassi Ben Larbi, who painted daily scenes in <Location>central Marrakech</Location>. Early painting in <Location>Morocco</Location> is not a well-documented field, but Rbati's place in many national and international collections pays tribute to his important foundational role.

Mohammed Ghani Hikmat,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Mohammed-Ghani-Hikmat.aspx</Address>
In 1953, Mohammed Ghani Hikmat graduated from the <Organization>Institute of Fine Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. He then travelled to <Location>Rome</Location> to train at the Accademia di Belle Arti, graduating in <Date>1959</Date>. While in <Location>Italy</Location>, he also studied metals at the Instituto di Zaka in <Location>Florence</Location>, specializing in casting bronze. He subsequently taught sculpture at the <Organization>Baghdad Institute of Fine Art</Organization> and the <Organization>College of Architectural Engineering</Organization> at the <Organization>University of Baghdad</Organization>.
During his career, Hikmat was a prolific creator and exhibitor, and an active participant in the growing <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> art scene. He held several solo shows in <Location>Rome</Location>, <Location>San</Location> Remo, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>Beirut</Location>, and <Location>Baghdad</Location>. He also participated in most major national exhibitions in <Location>Iraq</Location>. He was a member of the <Organization>Society of the Friends</Organization> of <Organization>Art</Organization> and later the Al-Zawiya group headed by Faiq Hassan. Significantly, Hikmat was also an influential member of the <Organization>Baghdad Group of Modern Art</Organization> (BGMA). Founded by his teachers and friends, Jewad Selim and Shakir Hassan Al-Said, the BGMA was arguably the most important artist society in modern <Location>Iraq</Location> and was dedicated to the idea that <Location>Iraq</Location>'s heritage held a preeminent place within its modern art practice.
Hikmat embraced these ideals within his own work, drawing subject matter and stylistic inspiration from medieval Islamic art and literature, as well as from Mesopotamian figuration. A number of his most famous works represent subjects from the well-known collection of Arab folktales, One Thousand and One Nights. One such work is The Fountain of Kahramana that depicts the heroine pouring oil into jars occupied by a number of Ali Baba's forty thieves. Another is the sculptural duet of Scheherazade and Shahrayar (<Date>1971</Date>). In this representation of the main characters of 1001 Nights, the figures are rendered with robust monumentality and strong, sinuous forms that harken back to Assyrian statuary. 
Along with his own art production, Hikmat also assisted in major public works initiated by other prominent members of the artistic community. Foremost among them was Jewad Selim's <Location>Monument</Location> of Freedom for which Hikmat assisted and supervised the casting process in <Location>Florence</Location>. He also took over the project when Selim died prematurely in <Date>1961</Date>. Another project was the much contested Arch of Victory which stood for decades as a symbol of Saddam Hussein's dictatorship. Hikmat completed the massive installation when its original sculptor Khalid al-Rahal passed away in <Date>1987</Date>. Despite the connection to the Hussein regime, any plans to dismantle the installation are still being hotly debated.
In <Date>2003</Date>, just before the invasion of <Location>Iraq</Location>, Hikmat fled to <Location>Amman</Location>, <Location>Jordan</Location> where he continued to work. In <Location>Amman</Location>, the sculptor often played host to prominent musicians, writers, and artists. Although the <Origin>Jordanian</Origin> capital provided him with a haven, as it did for many other <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> cultural figures, Hikmat always felt a strong pull towards his birthplace, often referring to <Location>Baghdad</Location> as a beautiful woman. He returned to <Location>Baghdad</Location> directly after the invasion to find his home much changed. Typical of the cultural destruction sustained in <Location>Baghdad</Location> was the defacement of Hikmat's prized monument, Scheherazade and Shahrayar, as looters cut off the king's left hand. The sculptor mourned over the destruction of other public sculptures that he had worked so diligently to complete. These were statues that could not be replaced. He also had to come to terms with the disappearance of close to 150 of his own works, representing the breadth of his career, after the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> was looted.
Hikmat, acutely aware of his role as a protector of <Location>Iraq</Location>'s cultural past and present, began a campaign to recover art works that had been looted. He founded the Committee for Recovering <Location>Iraq</Location>'s Culture with the aim of buying back works that had surfaced on underground markets. Through these efforts, he was able to recover at least 100 works, including Jewad Selim's Motherhood in <Date>2003</Date>. In this, Hikmat became a mobilizing force amongst his students and colleagues in the preservation of <Location>Iraq</Location>'s cultural heritage.
His second return to <Location>Iraq</Location>, in <Date>2010</Date>, was at the behest of the mayor of <Location>Baghdad</Location> who wished to commission the sculptor to complete a series of monuments for the city. Hikmat agreed and began work on four new sculptures to be erected in various sites in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. This was to be Hikmat's last project, yet the sculptor would not live to see it come to fruition. To the sorrow of many, Mohammad Ghani Hikmat passed away <Date>September 12th, 2011</Date> after suffering from kidney failure at the age of 82. His son is overseeing the completion of the monuments that Hikmat began working on before his death.

Mohammed Kazem,http://www.taymourgrahne.com/artists/mohammed-kazem</Address>
Mohammed Kazem was born in <Location>Dubai</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location>, in <Date>1969</Date>. A trained musician as well as an artist, Kazem studied painting at the <Organization>Emirates Fine Arts Society</Organization>, in <Location>Sharjah</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location>, attended <Organization>Al Rayat Music School</Organization>, in <Location>Dubai</Location>, and recently received his MFA at the <Organization>University of the Arts</Organization>, <Location>Philadelphia</Location>, <Location>PA</Location>. A pioneering conceptual artist, influenced by his close friend and mentor Hassan Sharif, his work touches on current global transformations in the social, political, and natural environments, and explores abstract ideas about the body, movement, space, and the natural elements. Kazem often works on simultaneous projects over extended periods of time, observing the transformations of his surroundings and the effects of time. In his photographic series Photographs with Flags, Kazem photographs himself next to flags in the desert that mark imminent construction projects, the artist’s body and physical presence bearing witness to the social and environmental change about to occur. Similarly, Kazem’s Window series documented the construction of a high-rise building from his window over the course of two years, as it slowly began to block his view and even the sky. Even within his iconic scratch paintings, time, space, and the body are all present. Since <Date>1990</Date> Kazem has been scratching the surface of paper in varying abstract compositions, capturing and incorporating sound, light and movement embodied on the page, which also changes and is dependent on the changing light of its surroundings.‘I am fascinated by collecting and documenting information about seemingly unimportant objects, traces of our present, within a particular environment,’ the artist writes.
Kazem’s exploration of his surroundings involves categorization and measurement of the unquantifiable, extending to his frequent use of GPS as a medium for recording. 
Selected to represent the <Location>United Arab Emirates</Location> in <Date>2013</Date>’s <Location>Venice</Location> Biennial, the artist presents an immersive video and GPS installation of his ongoing series Directions, in which the viewer stands at the center of a room surrounded by a moving projection of the sea. Curator Reem Fadda describes it as “intended to recreate an immersive experience of what it is to be lost at sea, to what the waters unafraid, to cross the physical barriers and roam the borders of ideas freely.”

Mohammed Melehi,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Mohammed-Melehi.aspx</Address>
Mohammed Melehi studied at the <Organization>École des Beaux-Arts</Organization> (<Date>1953 - 1955</Date>) in Tétouan, <Location>Morocco</Location>, before leaving to study abroad at the École supérieure des Beaux-<Organization>Arts</Organization> Isabel de Hungria (<Date>1955</Date>) in <Location>Seville</Location>; the École supérieure des Beaux-<Organization>Arts</Organization> <Location>San Fernando</Location> (<Date>1956</Date>) in <Location>Madrid</Location>; the <Organization>Académie des Beaux-Arts</Organization> (<Date>1957 - 1960</Date>) and the Instituto Statale d'Arte (<Date>1960</Date>) in <Location>Rome</Location>; the École nationale des Beaux-<Organization>Arts</Organization> (<Date>1960 - 1961</Date>) <Location>Paris</Location>; and finally was a recipient of the <Organization>Rockefeller Foundation</Organization> scholarship to study at <Organization>Columbia University</Organization> (<Date>1962</Date>) for two years before returning to <Location>Morocco</Location> in <Date>1964</Date>.
Melehi became a professor of painting, sculpture and photography at the <Organization>École des Beaux-Arts</Organization> of <Location>Casablanca</Location> (<Date>1964 - 1969</Date>), at that time directed by Farid Belkahia. Melehi, along with Belkahia and Mohammed Chebaa, formed the <Location>Casablanca</Location> group with an exhibition in <Location>Rabat</Location> in <Date>1966</Date>. In addition to a new modernist style in their personal work, the group was also known for a pedagogy that focused on rooting modernism in local visual culture. In 1969, these artists as well as other professors from the <Organization>Casablanca École des Beaux-Arts</Organization> organized the "exposition manifeste," an outdoor exhibition in Djemaa al-Fna in <Location>Marrakech</Location> in order to connect to a larger public outside of official exhibition spaces.
Beyond his painting, the breadth of Melehi's career has been striking, in his teaching, publishing, and policy roles, and as a graphic designer. His poster for the 1966 <Location>Rabat</Location> exhibition is currently in the collection of the <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>New York</Location>. Melehi was an active member of the group associated with the leftist cultural journal Souffles <Date>from 1966 to 1969</Date>, and designed its original iconic cover. <Date>From 1972 to 1977</Date>, Melehi was founder and director of the cultural journal Intégral. In <Date>1974</Date>, he co-founded and became the director of the publishing house Shoof. In <Date>1978</Date>, Melehi and Mohammed Benaïssa co-founded the Al Mohit association and the Cultural Moussem of Asilah, an arts festival known for its outdoor murals that continues to be held every year. Melehi was arts director at the <Organization>Ministry of Culture</Organization> (<Date>1985 - 1992</Date>) and Cultural Consultant to the <Organization>Ministry of Foreign Affairs</Organization> and <Organization>Cooperation</Organization> (<Date>1999 - 2002</Date>) in <Location>Morocco</Location>. 
Melehi is known as a leading modernist in <Location>Morocco</Location>. Since <Date>the 1960s</Date>, he has been elaborating a body of work based around the recurrent motif of waves. The canvases are consistently hard-edged and optic abstractions – the lines are clean, the colors are clearly delineated, and the brushstrokes and movements of the paintbrush are not visible. The waves themselves are often reconfigured, turned vertically to become flames, or cutting across the canvas on an angle. The waves have been linked to the waves on the beaches of Asilah, Melehi's hometown, the gesture of writing Arabic calligraphy, and, in their meditative consistency, to transcendence and prayer. Over time, he has stayed constant to this project, reconfiguring similar elements in his research into color and form, while continually varying small details, orientation, and color combinations, as well as adding other abstract shapes or symbols. He has also re-worked his waves in other media, as in a sculpture in <Location>Mexico</Location> in <Date>1968</Date> for the International Meeting of Sculptors, in posters and murals, or integrated into architectural projects.
Melehi has exhibited widely both nationally and internationally. He was part of significant early exhibitions of <Origin>Moroccan</Origin> modernism, including the second Alexandria Biennale (<Date>1958</Date>), the first and second editions of the Biennale des Jeunes in <Location>Paris</Location> (1959, 1961), and the Festival of Negro <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Dakar</Location> (<Date>1966</Date>). He was also involved in significant pan-Arab exhibitions including the Al-Wassiti Festival in <Location>Baghdad</Location> (<Date>1972</Date>) and the <Organization>PLO</Organization> "International <Organization>Art</Organization> Exhibition for <Location>Palestine</Location>" (<Date>1978</Date>). He has had numerous solo exhibitions including those at the national gallery, Galerie Bab Rouah, in <Location>Rabat</Location> (1965, <Date>1997</Date>), the <Organization>Bronx Museum</Organization> in <Location>New York</Location>, and a retrospective at the <Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization> in <Location>Paris</Location>, as well as at Galerie L'Atelier (<Location>Rabat</Location>) and the <Organization>Sultan Gallery</Organization> in <Location>Kuwait</Location>. He was a guest of honor at the 3rd <Location>Sharjah</Location> Biennale in <Date>1997</Date> in the <Location>UAE</Location>.

Mohanna Durra,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Mohanna-Durra.aspx</Address>
Born in the capital of <Location>Amman</Location> in <Date>1938</Date>, Mohanna Durra is a pioneer in <Location>Jordan</Location>'s modern art movement. Well known for his portraits, Durra is also recognized as one of the first painters in <Location>Jordan</Location> to experiment with abstract compositions during the early sixties.
After graduating from the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> in <Date>1958</Date>, Durra returned to <Location>Amman</Location>, where he taught art, first in an elementary school and later at the Teacher's College. At the latter institution, Durra formed a formative friendship with the <Origin>Italian</Origin> violinist and self-taught painter Armando Pron. The comradery was influential to Durra's understanding of the connection between music and visual abstraction, a formal relationship often noted by his international and local critics.
Mohanna Durra's artistic achievements have been recognized by numerous prestigious awards, including the following: the first State Appreciation Award for contributions to cultural developments in <Location>Jordan</Location> (<Date>1977</Date>); the Gold Medal of <Organization><Origin>Italian</Origin> Ministry of Cultural Heritage</Organization> (<Date>1978</Date>); and the Golden Pioneer Medal and Appreciation Award of the <Organization>Union of Arab Artists</Organization> (<Date>1980</Date>). Previous to these, in <Date>1965</Date>, Durra became a decorated knight of the Holy Order of <Location>San</Location> Silvestro by His Holiness Pope Paul VI. In <Date>2002</Date>, the Postal Authorities of <Location>Jordan</Location> issued a 200- fils postage stamp printed with one of his paintings in honor of Durra. He has held numerous group and solo exhibitions throughout the Arab world, <Location>Europe</Location>, the former <Location>U.S.S.R.</Location> and the <Location>U.S.</Location> His work is held in collections worldwide, including the <Location>Vatican</Location>, the <Organization>Imperial Court of Japan</Organization>, the <Organization>Jordan National</Organization> Gallery of Fine Art, and <Organization>Georgetown University</Organization> in <Location>Washington</Location>, <Location>D.C.</Location> He lives and works in <Location>Amman</Location>.

Hatoum’s work is an outstanding example of the interweaving of ethical, political and aesthetic issues, whose beauty lies in the wit, economy, risk-taking and even mischief-making with which these issues are conflated . . . .In Hatoum’s deceptively simple works, defiance cannot easily be separated from vulnerability, order from chaos, beauty from revulsion, the brain from the body, the self from the other, affirmation from negation, form from content, light from dark.
Guy Brett, Itinerary, Contemporary Artists: Mona Hatoum, <Organization>Phaidon Press</Organization>, <Date>1997</Date>

A practicing artist since <Date>the 1970s</Date>, Hatoum works with a wide and often unexpected range of materials and mediums to explore issues that often have conflict at their core. Political, emotional and even aesthetic conflicts are summoned up by Hatoum’s uncanny transformations of the materials and objects of daily life.
This is seen in work such as Marble Slicer, a giant egg slicer with a human sized bowl exquisitely rendered in white marble and steel (<Date>2002</Date>), Cage-a-deux, an oversized birdcage for human occupation (<Date>2002</Date>) and her more recent work Nature morte aux grenades, where a rolling steel hospital table is covered with colourful and tempting glass ornaments all in the shape of hand grenades (<Date>2006-07</Date>). Political issues underlie the three map works she has shown in <Location>Sharjah</Location>. Included in the 8th <Organization>Biennial</Organization> in <Date>2007</Date> was Hot Spot (<Date>2006</Date>), a human-scaled steel globe where continents marked in red neon glowed like heated iron, and Projection (<Date>2006</Date>), a delicately drawn wall map adopting the more accurate ‘Peters’ projection of the world. In Disorientations II, Hatoum recreated her haunting <Date>1996</Date> work Present Tense, in which the cantonized pockets of Palestinian territory that emerged from the map of the <Date>1993</Date> <Location>Oslo</Location> Accords are represented by bars of <Location>Nablus</Location> soap. 
One of the most internationally recognised of artists from the <Location>Middle East</Location>, Mona Hatoum studied at the <Organization>Byam Shaw School of Art</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>1975-79</Date>) and the <Organization>Slade School of Art</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>1979-1981</Date>). She has also participated in international group exhibitions and biennials including the <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization> (<Date>1995</Date> and <Date>2005</Date>), the <Organization>Biennale of Sydney</Organization> (<Date>2006</Date>), <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> (<Date>2007</Date>) and <Organization>Documenta</Organization> (<Date>2002</Date>). Mona <Origin>Saudi</Origin>,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/136-mona-saudi/overview/</Address>

Her forms are full of vitality, beauty and a clear sense of equilibrium. <Origin>Saudi</Origin> created her first sculpture in stone in <Date>1965</Date>, named Mother/Earth. Mouna Karray,http://nadour.org/artists/mouna-karray/</Address>
The photographer Mouna Karray strives to make places and everyday objects “speak”. Should her chosen medium halt “at the surface” of things ontologically, the artist seeks to restore the complexity of the spaces that she encounters (be they domestic or urban, private or public) by going beyond superficial appearance and definition. In order to document the” real”, but above all to make the sense and identity of it apparent, the artist works in series. This exploratory method allows for expansion: from motivation to context, from anecdote to memory. On several occasions, in order to tackle the sensitive territory of the personal, Mouna Karray has expanded into other media: for example in the installation El’mech’ed, <Date>2004</Date> and the sound piece An object on the Shore, <Date>2007</Date>.

The artist has also taught photography and curated exhibitions In <Location>Tunisia</Location>. She has been received as resident at the <Organization>Centre d’Art Vivant at Rades (Tunisia)</Organization> in <Date>2004</Date>, at the <Organization>Cite Internationale des Arts (Paris)</Organization> in <Date>2005</Date>, and at the <Organization>Civitella Ranieri Foundation (Umbria</Organization>, <Location>Italy</Location>) in <Date>2007</Date>.

She has also taken part in international shows in <Location>Europe</Location> and in <Location>Africa</Location>: The “Rencontres africaines de la photographie” in <Location>Bamako</Location>, the 30th Pontevedra Biennial in <Location>Spain</Location> and the 2nd Lumumbashi Biennial in the <Location>Democratic Republic</Location> of <Location>Congo</Location>.

Muhamad Haider,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-muhamadhaider.html</Address>
Muhamad Haider is a painter from <Location>Jeddah</Location> and president of the <Origin>Saudi</Origin> <Organization>House</Organization> of Artists. The galleries on his website show a variety of approaches to the art of catching our eye, that the artist used over changing periods of time. In the first gallery are images of his early works which were made before <Date>1999</Date> when he was endeavouring to paint reality. Then his second gallery (<Date>1999-2001</Date>) is more interesting. While some <Origin>Saudi</Origin> artists seem to make this conscious decision to paint in an abstract style, it is evident from his work that Haider went to the <Location>Jeddah</Location> coastline and bathed his eyes in the chaotic behavior of waves that meet the shore. From this his painting may have turned to abstraction by a longing to join the swim. Great painters like William Turner would have given a nod of approval. But this avenue Haider did not pursue for long. In <Date>2002</Date> he turned into the desert with a style of slight abstraction with references to <Origin>Saudi</Origin> traditions and religion. What abstraction is there in an Arab horseguard, but for speed and what more abstraction is needed than the truth in an image of Kaaba? After <Date>2005</Date> Haider leaves this style again and comes up with a range of experiments. But he keeps with him his deconstruction of a traditional ornament. Have a look at the journey of the triangles in his paintings and how the black ones keep their distance and stick together.

Nargess Hashemi,http://ivde.net/artists/nargess_hashemi/biography</Address>
The works of Nargess Hashemi are intimate observations of the dualities that permeate her daily existence in <Location>Iran</Location> using a diverse range of techniques and materials including monoprinting, macramé, graph paper and acetate.
Hashemi’s style has developed from the largely figurative works depicting intimate, domestic and celebratory scenes of her earlier series to her most recent work in which she uses graph paper to experiment with more abstract, geometric compositions. Despite this new direction the central themes of the artist’s work remain. Her preoccupation with the familial routines and habits that she has grown up with are always evident in her work, they reflect a conflicted sense of belonging and detachment, nostalgia and uneasiness, comfort and entrapment.
The use of pattern is another dominant element almost always present in Hashemi’s work. From the kitsch wrapping paper used as the background in her Wrap Me Up in You Series, to the complex bands of repetitive, brightly coloured shapes occupying the minute 1 mm x 1 mm squares of graph paper in her Home and Carpet series, she uses pattern in its many varying forms as both literal and abstract manifestations of the influence of environment and tradition.

Nicky Nodjoumi,http://www.taymourgrahne.com/artists/nicky-nodjoumi</Address>
Born in Kermanshah, <Location>Iran</Location> in <Date>1942</Date>, Nicky Nodjoumi experienced the Islamic Revolution of <Date>1979</Date> from the perspective of a young artist, astutely aware of the political and social upheavals of this tumultuous period in <Location>Iran</Location>’s history. Earning a Bachelor’s degree in art from <Organization>Tehran University of Fine Arts</Organization> before relocating to the <Location>United States</Location> in <Date>the late 1960s</Date>, Nodjoumi received his Master’s degree in Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> from The <Organization>City College of New York</Organization> in <Date>1974</Date>. This political engagement has continued to the present day. His nuanced figurative paintings engage in political discourse with a light, satirical touch, layering his personal heritage and lived experiences in <Location>Iran</Location> and the <Location>United States</Location> into scenes that resonate beyond specific historical contexts or geographical boundaries.
Nodjoumi’s works are conceived of as theatrical stages, where compositions of figures both serious and ridiculous, in the words of Phong Bui, “house meanings without irony, narratives without stories, humor without morality, above all creating a space that heightens the awareness of old and new history.” Serious in subject matter and witty in execution, these rich and diverse characters enliven Nodjoumi’s narratives and allude to collective experiences underpinned by socio-political struggles, articulating the full spectrum of feelings from aggression to victimhood. In conjunction with his solo exhibition at Taymour Grahne Gallery in <Date>September 2013</Date>, his work was also part of <Location>Iran</Location> Modern, which opened at the <Organization>Asia Society</Organization> in <Location>New York</Location>. The artist lives and works in <Location>Brooklyn</Location>.

Nil Yalter,http://www.galerist.com.tr/en/artist/nil-yalter/biography//nNil</Address> Yalter (born 1938, <Location>Cairo</Location>), a pioneer in the <Origin>French</Origin> feminist art movement of <Date>the 1970s</Date> was educated at <Organization>Robert College</Organization>, the prestigious <Origin>American</Origin> secondary educational institution in <Location>Istanbul</Location>. The Headless Woman or the Belly Dance, <Date>1974</Date>,is a classic of early feminist art.   In <Date>1978</Date>, she mounted a performance and installation acting out everyday life in a harem using a few pieces of furniture and utensils as part of  A Day of Actions, held in the studio of one of the other members of the collectif. Niyaz-Azadikhah,http://ivde.net/artists/niyaz_azadikhah/biography</Address>
Niyaz Azadikhah (b. <Date>1984</Date>, <Location>Tehran</Location>) lives and works in <Location>Tehran</Location>.
Azadikhah creates wry, graceful commentaries on life in modern-day <Location>Iran</Location>. In her animations, doll-like figures of chador-clad women slowly morph and mutate, rosary beads bloom into flowers and bikini-clad women wrestle on a barren beach of blank paper. As each tightly-controlled frame unfurls, Azadikhah illustrates her observations on a patriarchal ideology and futile behavioral patterns.
In Line 1, for instance, Azadikhah takes us inside the women’s carriage of the <Location>Tehran</Location> metro. The scene centers around an itinerant underwear seller touting her wares to the women, who respond with varying degrees of interest. All are unified in their appearance, yet she highlights the internal desires and attitudes that make each an individual. The subtleties of this scene offer Azadikhah’s observations on human nature and the social structures we operate within.
Azadikhah has participated in the exhibitions What Lies Beneath I (<Date>2011</Date>) and <Location>Nice</Location> Drawings (<Date>2015</Date>) at <Organization>Gallery Isabelle van den Eynde</Organization>. She has also participated in exhibitions at Jorjani <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Tehran</Location> (<Date>2014</Date>), Parallel <Location>Vienna</Location> (<Date>2013</Date>), The <Location>Garden</Location> of Eden at <Organization>Palais de Tokyo</Organization>, Galerie <Location>Utopia</Location>, <Location>Paris</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>), and was a finalist in the <Organization>MOP</Organization> CAP prize in <Date>2011</Date>.

Oraib Toukan,http://nadour.org/artists/oraib-toukan/</Address>
Oraib Toukan works across media in photography, video, text and installation, often using politics and current affairs as source material. She often presents wry and playful critique in the form of subtle interventions with institutions ranging from Wikipedia to Christie’s.
Her works tend to start-off from appropriating a singular map, document, letter, found footage or a photograph. She directly draws from real life instances where absurdity is, or becomes the form. For example in The New(er) <Location>Middle East</Location> (<Date>2007</Date>) she appropriated known topographical works and replaces their mere representational qualities with interactivity. She literally cuts up what has become almost iconographic territory based on a found <Location>US</Location> army map, into new strange magnetic forms for audiences to piece back together on a magnetic wall. Instead, even stranger new territories are formed by them. For another two years, and inspired by ideas of mimicry, she likewise coached real life experts into interviews, corporate presentations, and advertising proposals for selling whole nation states under a company called <Organization>Nayruz Holdings</Organization>.
Oraib Toukan was born in <Location>Boston</Location> in <Date>1977</Date> and was raised in <Location>Amman</Location>, <Location>Jordan</Location> where she has lived most of her life. She has interdisciplinary degrees in <Organization>Geography and Information Systems</Organization> (MSc) combined with Fine Arts and Photography (MFA) from <Organization>Bard College</Organization>. In <Date>2008</Date> she received a full two-year Fellowship Award from Jacob Javitz, as well as MAWRED, YATF, and AFAC production grants for work on trying <Location>Lebanon</Location> and <Location>Israel</Location> for food theft, auctioning off nation states instead of art objects, and re-presenting diplomatic gifts from Arab states to the people of <Location>Israel</Location>. In <Date>2009</Date>, she was an artist in residence at Delfina, <Location>London</Location> and was also artist in residence that same year at Artist Alliance in <Location>New York</Location> city, where she has been based since <Date>2007</Date>.

Pascal Hachem,http://nadour.org/artists/pascal-hachem/</Address>
The work of Pascal Hachem, whether through performances or installations, often starts with a diversion. Trained as an engineer, his knowledge of engines and materials give him a particular stance which he applies in creating artefacts and (often mechanized) installations. He uses daily objects and manages to extract their nature and their primary identity thanks to unusual associations and layouts. These machines inevitably cause a feeling of strangeness but paradoxically appear strangely familiar to whoever looks at them. A series of hammers slowly destroying a wall in a paced and almost liturgical motion, a t-shirt gradually torn under the weight of an accumulation of sand, knives gently emerging from a desert. These devices all unsettle the viewer whilst entailing issues of a political, social or environmental nature.
Pascal Hachem was born in <Date>1979</Date> in <Location>Lebanon</Location>. In <Date>2002</Date>, he graduated in <Organization>Spatial Design</Organization> from the USEK. He then became creative director at Pslab and at the same time taught design at the <Organization><Origin>American</Origin> University of Beirut</Organization>.
He has taken part in several group shows and in particular in Hopes and Doubts, the <Organization>Mario Merz Foundation</Organization> in <Location>Turin</Location> and <Location>Beirut</Location> in <Date>2008</Date>/<Date>2009</Date>, Fabrica : Les Yeux ouverts, Notebook project at the <Organization>Georges Pompidou Centre</Organization> in <Location>Paris</Location> and the <Location>Milan</Location> Triennial in <Date>2006</Date>/<Date>2007</Date>. His works have also been presented in solo shows in <Location>London</Location>, <Location>Istanbul</Location>, <Location>Freiburg</Location>, <Location>Amman</Location> as well as <Location>Rome</Location>. Pascal Hachem currently lives and works in <Location>Beirut</Location>, <Location>Lebanon</Location>.

Pouran Jinchi is an <Origin>Iranian</Origin>-born, <Location>New York</Location> artist who borrows from her home culture's traditions of literature and calligraphy to pursue her own aesthetic investigations. Having been trained in calligraphy, she finds the relation between words and forms, natural or non-objective, deeply intertwined. In Pouran's recent work, viewers will appreciate her increasingly detailed focus on the form of language as subject matter.
Pouran’s work often employs a mixture of calligraphy and abstract expressionism that intertwines Islamic geometry, <Origin>Iranian</Origin> traditions and contemporary aesthetics, with a unique lyricism. Pouran's early paintings were large scale and heavily layered abstractions, whose flowing lines of saturated color and rolling waves of calligraphy brought to life the form as well as the content of the text to which she was responding. With successive series, Pouran narrowed her focus to single words, repeated over and over to create the very object they signified, or aesthetics distilled from a single letter, emphasizing the building block of language and thought.

Pouya Parsamagham,http://ivde.net/artists/pouya_parsamagham/biography</Address>

In What Lies Beneath, following his participation <Date>last year</Date> with a group of still image light boxes, Parsamagham presents a group of light boxes of different sizes, each displaying film clips of moving figures, captured on his phone. Chasing the characters with his camera, keeping the future of each running figure ominous, incomplete, intriguing, Parsamagham creates a dramatic and mysterious narrative. The fates of the characters, gathered from different fictional events and moments in time, are intertwined into this ongoing chase. Rabih Mroué is an actor, director, playwright, visual artist and contributing editor for The Drama Review (TDR). Rachid Koraïchi,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Rachid-Koraïchi.aspx</Address>
Rachid Koraïchi began his studies at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in <Location>Algeria</Location> before moving to <Location>France</Location>, where he continued his studies at the Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs, the Institut d'Urbanisme, and the Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-Arts in <Location>Paris</Location>. Koraïchi's influences come from <Location>North Africa</Location> and <Location>France</Location>, although he is interested in ideas of shared prehistoric inheritance, and the ways in which the language of art can be universal and carry a global outlook. While Koraïchi is deeply tied to mystic and visual traditions and draws from the spiritual and artisinal heritage of the Maghreb, in his artwork these ideas and systems of communication are reworked to become part of a new artistic project.
Koraïchi comes from a Sufi family from <Location>Algeria</Location>, and his art is often framed within a tradition of Sufi spirituality in which aesthetics and metaphysics are intertwined. Writing and signs, for Koraïchi, hold sacred importance, and calligraphy is often a significant backbone of his work. Drawing from Arabic calligraphy, Koraïchi has created in some ways his own script or graphic language that includes Amazighi and Tuareg letters and mystical symbols. This calligraphy is sometimes legible but often is abstracted with thick repetitions, becoming signs or figures. He has had a long-standing interest in the Sufi poet and scholar Rumi, whose work inspired multiple installations of Koraïchi's long-term project "The Path of Roses" (Le Chemin de Roses). His work ranges from mystical, abstract works to direct political commentary in dialogue with revolutionary and liberation movements, as in a number of works supporting <Location>Palestine</Location> and the Palestinian people. Koraïchi's diverse oeuvre encompasses a wide range of artistic expression, from intimate prints to large-scale banners and installations. He works in varied media, including printmaking, paint, ceramics, and textiles.
Beyond Koraïchi's personal work, collaborations with writers and poets have been an important part of his oeuvre, as with Mohammed Dib, Jamel Eddine Bencheikh, René Char, Michel Butor. He notably collaborated with Mahmoud Darwish on the large scale project of poems and etchings A Nation in Exile (<Date>1981</Date>). A number of Koraïchi's works have also been executed in collaboration with <Location>North African</Location> artisans trained in traditional techniques, as in dyeing, weaving, or pottery. This collaborative work can be seen in the date-palm plantation in the <Origin>Algerian</Origin> Sahara that Koraïchi has been developing since <Date>2011</Date>. This plantation, conceived of as a kind of large-scale land art, will be ecologically sustainable and devoted to regional culture.​
Koraïchi has exhibited widely internationally, for instance at the 47th and 49th <Location>Venice</Location> Biennales (<Date>1997</Date> and <Date>2001</Date>), "Global Conceptualism" (The <Organization>Queens Museum of Art</Organization>, <Location>New York</Location>, <Date>1999</Date>), "The Short Century" (<Location>Munich</Location>, <Location>Berlin</Location>, <Location>Chicago</Location>, and <Location>New York</Location>, <Date>2001-2</Date>), "Word Into <Organization>Art</Organization>" (The <Organization>British Museum</Organization>, <Location>London</Location>, <Date>2006</Date>), and "The Future of Tradition – The Tradition of Future" (Haus der Kunst, <Location>Munich</Location>, <Date>2010</Date>). He has had a number of solo shows, such as the <Location>Emirates</Location> Palace Auditorium (<Location>Abu Dhabi</Location> Festival, <Location>Abu Dhabi</Location>, <Date>2011</Date>), the Herbert F. <Organization>Johnson Museum of Art</Organization> at Cornell Unversity (<Location>Ithaca</Location>, <Location>New York</Location>), Chapelle Saint Martin, Le Mejan (Arles), La Citadelle (<Location>Algiers</Location>), and <Organization>Darat al Funun (Amman)</Organization>. He also created a stained-glass window for the Chapelle Sainte-Cécile (Ceillac, <Location>France</Location>), and has provided illustrations for a number of publications by writers such as Mahmoud Darwish and Rumi. In <Date>2011</Date>, Koraïchi won the <Location>Victoria</Location> & <Organization>Albert Museum</Organization>'s Jameel Prize, an international prize for contemporary artists inspired by Islamic traditions of craft and design.  Koraïchi's work is held in a number of major public collections, including the <Organization>British Museum (London)</Organization>, the <Organization>National Museum</Organization> for African <Organization>Art</Organization> (<Location>Washington</Location>, <Location>D.C.</Location>), the Musée d'art Moderne de la Ville de <Location>Paris</Location> (<Location>Paris</Location>), and <Organization>Darat al Funun</Organization>/The <Organization>Khalid Shoman Foundation (Amman)</Organization>.

Ragheb Ayad,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Ragheb-Ayad.aspx</Address>
Ragheb Ayad was born in <Date>1892</Date> into a <Organization>Coptic</Organization> family in the neighborhood of Faggala in <Location>Cairo</Location>. He received his primary education at the École des Frères before joining the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the year of its creation by Prince Youssef Kamal in <Date>1908</Date>. He was among the first students of this new institution along with artists Mahmoud Mokhtar (<Date>1891 - 1934</Date>), Youssef Kamel (<Date>1891 - 1971</Date>), Antoine Haggar (<Date>1896 - 1962</Date>) and Mohammed Hassan (<Date>1892 - 1961</Date>). After he graduated in <Date>1911</Date>, Ayad worked as a drawing teacher at the <Organization>Coptic Secondary School</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> and made several trips to <Location>France</Location> and <Location>Italy</Location>. <Date>Between 1921 and 1922</Date>, Ayad and his friend, the painter Youssef Kamel, agreed on an exchange; in turns each would work as a teacher for one year to finance the other's stay in <Location>Italy</Location>. In 1925, both Ayad and Kamel received a scholarship to study at the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> along with their colleague Mohammed Hassan. During that time, Ayad traveled around <Location>Italy</Location> and visited the cities of <Location>Florence</Location>, Sienna and <Location>Venice</Location> where he attended the fifteenth Biennale in <Date>1926</Date>. After obtaining his diploma from the <Organization>Decoration department</Organization> of the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> in <Date>1928</Date>, he returned to <Location>Egypt</Location> the following year.
Ayad was the first to propose the idea of creating an <Organization><Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Academy</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> on the model of the other foreign academies established in the <Origin>Italian</Origin> capital. In 1930, He was appointed as the head of the <Organization>Decoration department</Organization> at the <Organization>School of Applied Arts</Organization> in Giza where he remained until 1937. Following this appointment, he became professor and director of the Free section of the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> that offered evening classes to students who had to work during the day. In 1936, he married the <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter Emma Caly (-Ayad), with whom he held several exhibitions in <Location>Egypt</Location>. Ayad also worked as a curator and played an important role in reorganizing the <Organization>Coptic</Organization> museum in <Date>1941</Date>. <Date>From 1950 to 1955</Date>, succeeding Youssef Kamel, he was named director of the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization>. During his tenure there, he created a special section in the Museum dedicated to the work of the sculptor Mahmoud Mokhtar, which was inaugurated in <Date>1952</Date>.
Ragheb Ayad is one of the leading painters of a generation of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> artists commonly referred to as the pioneers (al-ruwwād), as they were the first to be educated in artistic institutions established according to European models, such as the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. Ayad broke away from his academic education at the Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> and in <Location>Rome</Location> to create an original folklorist style that distinguishes him from his contemporaries. Throughout his career, he depicted scenes of rural and popular daily life, such as the market place, the labor in the fields and the popular café, as well as traditional practices rooted in <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> culture, such as the zār, a Nubian ritual trance dance, or the taḥtīb, an ancestral game of stick fighting practiced in Upper <Location>Egypt</Location>. He also painted religious scenes and exterior views of the <Organization>Coptic</Organization> monasteries.
Ayad mastered the art of sketching and besides his oil paintings, he produced numerous sketches and drawings enhanced with watercolors such as gouache. His expressive style is characterized by the vivacity of his textured strokes that express the dynamic of constant movement, as well as by the use of powerful colors. His work is profoundly marked by the arts of Ancient <Location>Egypt</Location>: the formal aesthetic of the decorative bas-reliefs and paintings of the tombs and temples of Thebes inspired him to reinvent the ancient system of superposed narrative scenes, which sometimes led him to use horizontal formats. Towards the end of his career, his style progressively evolved towards a purification of lines and stylization of forms. Ayad was also a skilled decorator and painted several interiors of public and private buildings. In 1935, he executed a series of decorative paintings for the old <Organization>Shepherd Hotel</Organization> that was unfortunately destroyed in the <Location>Cairo</Location> fire in <Date>1952</Date>. He also participated in the interior decoration of religious buildings such as the <Organization>Coptic Cathedral of Sohag</Organization> and the <Organization>Catholic</Organization> Churches of Minia and Samalut.
From the 1930's, Ragheb Ayad exhibited regularly at the Salon in <Location>Cairo</Location> founded by the <Organization>Society of Fine Art</Organization> Lovers. During his lifetime, he held numerous solo and collective exhibitions in <Location>Egypt</Location> and abroad. His works are exposed at the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> <Organization>Art</Organization>, the <Organization>Agricultural Museum</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and at Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>.

Rana Begum,http://www.thethirdline.com/artists/rana-begum/biography/</Address>
Rana Begum received her Fine Art Degree in painting at the <Organization>Chelsea College of Art and Design</Organization> and her MFA in painting from the <Organization>Slade School of Fine Art</Organization>, both of <Location>London</Location>.
Lodged between op-art and minimalism, Rana's previous works drew its inspiration from repetitive geometric patterns within Islamic art and architecture. The result is a series of tightly controlled compositions, where impeccably applied colorful hard-edge lines are coated in a thick layer of glossy resin, to create seductively tactile reflective surfaces. Rana's works were an exercise in rhythm and symmetry and much like music, had a spiritual quality to them that embraces the heart and gratifies the eye.
In more recent work, Rana's works draw inspiration from urban visual stimuli such as the abstract clashes of form and colour that can be seen in the city, and combines them with the traditional repetition of geometric form found in Islamic art. To view the work one is required to adjust their position for the work to unravel. As you move, the work reveals a constant shifting symmetry of colour that ripples, brakes, and reforms before your eyes. It is in this visual movement that Rana creates a compelling visual language where by with the tiniest of movements the surrounding chaos aligns itself into a moment of symmetry. 
Rana currently lives and works in <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location>.

The members of Raqs Media Collective enjoy playing a plurality of roles, often appearing as artists, occasionally as curators, sometimes as philosophical agents provocateurs. The collective makes contemporary art and films, curates exhibitions, edits books, stages events and collaborates with architects, computer programmers, writers and theatre directors. Following its self-declared imperative of “kinetic contemplation” to produce a trajectory that is restless in terms of the forms and methods that it deploys even as it achieves a consistency of speculative procedures, Raqs remains closely involved with the Sarai programme at the Centre for the Study of Developing Societies, an initiative that the collective cofounded in <Date>2000</Date>. Exhibitions include solo shows at the <Organization>Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum</Organization>, <Location>Boston</Location>, <Location>Massachusetts</Location>, <Location>USA</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>); <Organization>BALTIC Centre</Organization> for Contemporary Art, <Location>Gateshead</Location>, <Location>UK</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>); Tate <Location>Britain</Location>, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>); <Location>Asia</Location> Art Archive, <Location>Hong Kong</Location>, <Location>China</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>); and Palais des Beaux Arts, <Location>Brussels</Location>, <Location>Belgium</Location> (<Date>2004</Date>), among many others. The group curated Sarai Reader 09: The Exhibition (<Date>2012</Date>, <Organization>Devi Art Foundation</Organization>, <Location>New Delhi</Location>) and cocurated <Organization>Manifesta </Organization>7 (<Date>2008</Date>, Bolzano, <Location>Italy</Location>).
