Rasheed Araeen,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/a/araeen-rasheed</Address>
b. 1935, <Location>Karachi</Location>, PakistanLives and works in <Location>London</Location>, <Location>United Kingdom</Location>
<Location>London</Location>-based artist, writer and curator Rasheed Araeen began working as an artist while studying Civil Engineering at <Organization>NED University</Organization> in <Location>Karachi</Location>. In 1964 Araeen moved to <Location>London</Location>, and became an early pioneer and practitioner of Minimalism. With no formal training in sculpture, it was his work as a civil engineer and an early encounter with the sculptures of Anthony Caro that influenced the formal language and use of simple or industrial materials characteristic of Araeen’s best-known works.
Yet unlike Caro, Araeen tried to eliminate hierarchy and traditional notions of composition in his work. In early works, such as Sculpture No. 1, conceived in <Date>1968</Date>, steel girders were placed, without a plinth, in a simple grid on the gallery floor. In his later ‘Structures’, he used modular cubes or rectangles that were infinitely repeatable and re-combinable. While reflective of Minimalist aesthetics, Araeen’s work became increasingly participatory as seen in works such a Char Yar (<Date>1968</Date>) where viewers were free to manipulate a series of cubic forms. By <Date>1970</Date>, his growing interest in the performative and participatory possibilities of sculpture was realised with his seminal ‘Chakras’ where the artist and audience tossed a series of disks into the water at St. Katherine’s Docks.
After this time, Araeen’s practice became increasingly politicised. As an activist, Araeen was involved in various groups supporting liberation struggles, democracy and human rights in <Location>Britain</Location> and around the world. In <Date>1978</Date>, Araeen founded the critical journals Black <Location>Phoenix</Location>, Third Text and Third Text <Location>Africa</Location>. These were groundbreaking platforms for the views and ideas of non-Western artists whose works had been largely ignored or marginalised by traditional art institutions and the art establishment. The publications provided a crucial channel for the exchange of ideas among these artists by linking them together as part of a wider collective within the Black diaspora and Black nationalist movement that was prevalent at the time.
In <Date>the late 1980s</Date> Araeen also became known for his work curating influential exhibitions such as The Essential Black Art at the Chisenhale <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>1987</Date>) and The Other Story at the <Location>Hayward</Location> <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>1989</Date>). These exhibitions explored <Location>Britain</Location>’s colonial and post-colonial past and the legacy of racism, inequality and cultural insensitivity that Araeen felt pervaded <Origin>British</Origin> life.
Araeen has exhibited internationally and regionally with significant solo exhibitions including Zero to Infinity, Museo de Arte, <Location>Lima</Location>, <Location>Peru</Location> (<Date>2013</Date>), Before and After Minimalism: Drawings, Painting, Sculpture and Concepts, <Date>1959 - 1974</Date>, Aicon <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), To Whom It <Date>May</Date> Concern, <Organization>Serpentine Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>1996</Date>), V Habana <Organization>Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Havana</Location>, <Location>Cuba</Location> (<Date>1994</Date>), Strife and/or Structure, Modern Art <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Organization>Fukukoa Art Museum</Organization>, <Location>Fukuoka</Location> Prefecture, <Location>Japan</Location> (<Date>1993</Date>) and From Modernism to Postmodernism: Rasheed Araeen A Retrospective‭, ‬Ikon <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Birmingham</Location> (<Date>1987</Date>).
His work has been shown in group exhibitions including the <Organization>Shanghai Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Shanghai</Location>, <Location>China</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>), <Organization>Gwangju Biennale</Organization>, <Organization>Gwangju</Organization>, <Location>South Korea</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>), Migrations at Tate <Location>Britain</Location>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>), The <Organization>Mediterranean Project</Organization>, <Organization>Thessaloniki Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Thessaloniki</Location>, <Location>Greece</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>), Live in Your Head, Museu do Chiado, <Location>Lisbon</Location>, <Location>Portugal</Location> (<Date>2001</Date>), every day <Organization>Sydney Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Australia</Location> (<Date>1998</Date>), 2nd <Location>Johannesburg</Location> <Organization>Biennale</Organization> in <Location>South Africa</Location> (<Date>1997</Date>), Magicians de la terra, Centre George Pompifou/La Villetter, <Location>France</Location>, <Location>Paris</Location> (<Date>1989</Date>) and Art of Society at <Location>Whitechapel</Location> Art <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>1978</Date>).
Araeen is the recipient of honorary doctorates from <Organization>Southampton University</Organization>, <Organization>East London University</Organization> and <Organization>Wolverhampton University</Organization>.
The author of numerous essays and journals Araeen has written Art beyond Art/Ecoaesthetics: A Manifesto for the 21st Century, Third Text Publications, <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>) and the autobiographical Making Myself Visible, <Organization>Kala Press</Organization> (<Date>1984</Date>).
His work is included in the collections of the <Organization>Arts Council of England</Organization>, CANAL PLUS, <Location>Paris</Location>, <Organization>Fukuoka Art Museum</Organization>, Fukuok- Shi, <Location>Japan</Location> and Tate <Organization>Gallery</Organization> <Location>London</Location>.

Rashid Masharawi,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/m/masharawi-rashid</Address>
Rashid Masharawi was born and raised in Shati refugee camp in the <Location>Gaza Strip</Location>. He is a self-taught filmmaker. In <Date>1996</Date> he founded the <Organization>Cinema Production Centre</Organization> (<Organization>CPC</Organization>) in Ramallah, <Location>Palestine</Location>, which organises workshops geared towards teaching young Palestinian filmmakers how to navigate the field of film production. In addition, the centre’s <Organization>Mobile Cinema Department</Organization> screens films in remote villages and refugee camps, bringing cinema to communities who are otherwise deprived of the opportunity to engage with quality films.
Masharawi describes his work as an attempt to create a ‘cinema’ out of the Palestinian situation. He has produced over fifteen films which include features, shorts and documentaries, and which he feels together constitute a mirror or document of Palestinian life over the <Date>last twenty years</Date>. His feature films include Curfew (<Date>1993</Date>), Haifa (<Date>1996</Date>), and Ticket to <Location>Jerusalem</Location> (<Date>2002</Date>) and his documentaries include Live from <Location>Palestine</Location> (<Date>2001</Date>). His films have been broadcast on international television and received numerous awards and critical acclaim. While he recognises the value of international recognition in perpetuating his practice as a Palestinian filmmaker, he considers himself more of an artist and director than a Palestinian partisan.
Masharawi has screened his video installations and films internationally in exhibitions and events such as, the Biennale of Shargea, <Organization>MoMa</Organization> Presents: Rashid Masharawi’s Laila’s Birthday, <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization>, <Location>New York</Location>, <Location>USA</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>), en attente, Casino <Origin><Location>Luxembourg</Location></Origin> – Forum d’art contemporain (<Date>2005</Date>), <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> 6, <Location>UAE</Location> (<Date>2003</Date>), and KNOTS symmetric-asymmetric (curated by Gangart), MAK – <Origin>Austrian</Origin> <Organization>Museum of Applied Arts</Organization>/Contemporary Art, <Location>Vienna</Location>, <Location>Austria</Location> (<Date>2002-2003</Date>). His feature films have been included on academic curriculums at the <Organization><Origin>Israeli</Origin> Academy of Film</Organization> and Television and <Organization>Harvard University</Organization>, <Location>Cambridge</Location>, <Location>USA</Location>, among other institutions.

Reem Al Ghaith,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/g/ghaith-reem-al</Address>
In an installation entitled '<Location>Dubai</Location>: What's left of her land' — part building site, part abstract sculpture and both chaotic and heroic in its arrangement of pulleys, tools, maps, cement and silhouetted workers — young <Location>Dubai</Location> artist Reem Al Ghaith simultaneously celebrates and critiques the voracious urbanisation of the region.
Louisa Buck
The work of Reem Al Ghaith reflects the ambivalence felt by most Emiratis about the rapid changes that have brought wealth and, particularly for artists, opportunities, but have also resulted in a loss of cultural identity and the rapid destruction of any physical connection to the landscape of the past.
For the 9th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization>, Al Ghaith recreated a <Date>2008</Date> installation titled <Location>Dubai</Location>: What's left of her land? The work combined a wide range of media in what was a large-scale and ambitious project.
Al Ghaith has been shown in exhibitions including at the Haus der Kunst, <Location>Munich</Location>, <Location>Germany</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), the <Organization>Centre Pompidou</Organization>, <Organization>Musée National</Organization> d´Art Moderne, <Location>Paris</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), the <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> (<Date>2009</Date>), the <Organization>Emirates Palace Hotel</Organization>, <Location>Abu Dhabi</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>), the <Organization>Vitra Design Museum</Organization>, Weil An Rhein, <Location>Germany</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>) the <Organization>Tashkeel</Organization> Gallery, <Location>Dubai</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>) and <Organization>House</Organization> 69, Bastakiya, <Location>Dubai</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>).
Reem Al Ghaith graduated with a BSc in Visual Communication from the <Organization>School of Architecture and Design</Organization>, <Organization><Origin>American</Origin> University of Sharjah</Organization>, <Location>UAE</Location>. She was born in <Date>1985</Date> in <Location>Dubai</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location>, where she currently lives and works.

René Gabri,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/g/gabri-rena</Address>
Rene Gabri is interested in the complex mechanisms which constitute the world around us. 
Often working within the folds of cultural practice, social thought and politics, much of his practice springs from contact with others, dialogues and conversations with friends, colleagues, thinkers and individuals he encounters by chance.
In Disorientation II, Gabri and long-time artist and activist collaborator Ayreen Anastas presented What Everyone Knows (<Date>2006</Date>), a video installation work that explores the lives lived by Palestinians in occupied <Location>Palestine</Location> and in <Location>Israel</Location>.Anastas and Gabri were among the principal organizers of the <Location>New York</Location> artist community 16 <Organization>Beaver Group</Organization>, founded in <Date>1999</Date>. Their work together includes The Meaning of Everything, One Step Forward Two Steps Back (<Date>2010</Date>),<Location>Camp Campaign</Location> (<Date>2006</Date>), RadioActive Discussions (<Date>2002</Date>) and United We Stand (<Date>2003</Date>). Their films have been shown widely including at the <Organization>Beirut Art Center</Organization> (<Date>2009</Date>), and Kettle’s Yard, <Location>Cambridge</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>). Their book The Meaning of Everything, Vol. 1 was published in <Date>2009</Date> by <Organization>Paraguay Press</Organization>, <Location>Paris</Location>.Other projects by Gabri include his film Movements (<Date>2002</Date>) and his work with the <Origin>German</Origin> collective e-Xplo.Born in <Location>Tehran</Location>, Gabri lived in <Location>Athens</Location> and <Location>Los Angeles</Location> before moving to <Location>New York</Location> where he continues to live and work. Gabri completed the <Organization>Whitney Museum</Organization> Independent Study Program in <Date>1999</Date>. He has taught at the <Organization>University of Architecture</Organization> in <Location>Venice</Location> and the <Organization>City University of New York</Organization>, <Location>Staten Island</Location>.<Date>October 2010</Date>

Reza Aramesh,http://nadour.org/artists/reza-aramesh/</Address>
Reza Aramesh’s soon found his medium of predilection in photography - ideal form in which to meld his interest in the history of painting, film and literature with modern society and politics.In his series entitled, Between the Eye and the Object Falls a Shadow…, Aramesh freezes in black and white re-enacted scenes of disputes that took place in the <Location>Middle East</Location> or in <Location>Vietnam</Location> from the 1960 to the present day. These classic and dramatic scenes found their incongruous setting in lavish <Origin>British</Origin> homes and historical museums. This audacious subversion of space and time came to the fore in Aramesh’s Action 71. Here, Aramesh invited homeless individuals to spend their night in selected rooms of the Tate <Location>Britain</Location>, sleeping with portraits produced between the seventeenth and eighteenth century representing individuals that focused on status and lineage.
Reza Aramesh was born in Awhaz, <Location>Iran</Location> in <Date>1970</Date>. He left his homeland at the age of fifteen to <Location>London</Location> where he first achieved an undergraduate in chemistry, he then decided to redirect his life and completed a Master’s in Fine Art at the <Organization>Goldsmith College</Organization> in <Date>1997</Date>. He currently lives and works in <Location>London</Location>.
Reza Aramesh’s photographic, sculptural, video and performance works have received international acclaim. His work has been featured in solo shows in <Location>Dubai</Location>, <Location>Shanghai</Location>, <Location>Rabat</Location> as well as in <Location>London</Location> at the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Arts, the <Organization>Barbican Centre</Organization>, Tate <Location>Britain</Location> and at the <Organization>ICA</Organization>.

Robert MacPherson,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/m/macpherson-robert</Address>
For over thirty years the artist Robert MacPherson has produced objects and installations in which he exploits the emotive tension between anonymous functional objects and a highly specific, visually allusive language with which they are named, often drawn from Australian working class slang.
Trevor Smith
Long considered an important Australian artist, Robert MacPherson uses the rich and colourful culture of his rural childhood to address the environmental, colloquial and distinctive aspects of Australian landscape and language. Over the course of his career he has worked with text, drawings, paintings, dramatic room-scale installations, objects and sculpture.
His work explores the philosophical propositions of what constitutes a work of art and often incorporates familiar imagery and everyday materials such as road signs, paint brushes, office stationery, shovels and blankets.
For the 9th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> Macpherson presented a variety of existing sculptural, installation and painted works covering a period <Date>from 1973 to 1993</Date>. Exhibited across two adjacent spaces in the <Organization>Sharjah Art Museum</Organization> the collected works provided a compelling glimpse into the distinct poetics of Macpherson’s life and work.
Macpherson’s work has been numerous exhibitions throughout his career including major solo presentations at the <Organization>Institute of Modern Art</Organization>, <Location>Brisbane</Location> (<Date>2007</Date>) and the <Organization>Museum of Contemporary Art</Organization>, <Location>Sydney</Location> (<Date>2001</Date>). His work was exhibited in the <Organization>Sydney Biennale</Organization> (<Date>2010</Date>, <Date>2002</Date>), the <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> (<Date>2009</Date>), the <Organization>University of Queensland Art</Organization> Museum, <Location>Brisbane</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>), <Location>The Hague</Location> Sculpture Festival, <Location>Netherlands</Location> (<Date>2007</Date>), the <Date>October</Date> Salon, <Location>Belgrade</Location> (<Date>2006</Date>) and the Hamburger Bahnhof, <Location>Berlin</Location> (<Date>2003</Date>).
Robert Macpherson was born in <Date>1937</Date> <Location>Brisbane</Location>, <Location>Australia</Location> where he continues to live and work.

Rula Halawani,http://nadour.org/artists/rula-halawani/</Address>
Rula Halawani shoots and produces images of the changes taking place daily on the Palestinian territory. She explains “I am an artist, a photographer who lives and works in an intensely political environment (…) the question of making political art does not arise in the Palestinian context. Our existence is entirely defined, at all levels, by political circumstances. ”
The Intimacy series gives an account of the inevitable contact between Israelis and Palestinians, Rula here chose to highlight the body searches at the Qualandia checkpoint, revealing what has become a true ritual of authority. In Negative Incursion as in the <Location>Wall</Location> series, she transcends the photographic documentary tradition while making her large scale pictures almost unreal, depicting an improbable world which should only exist in nightmares.
Rula Halawani was born, grew up and still lives in the <Location>Mount</Location> of Olives district in <Location>East Jerusalem</Location>. She started as photojournalist and worked as freelance journalist for many newspapers and magazines. Her subjective view of the <Origin>Israeli</Origin>-Palestinian conflict pushed her to cease this activity and to turn exclusively to visual arts since <Date>1988</Date>. She is the founder and director of the photography department of the <Organization>Birzeit University</Organization>.
The photographs of Rula Halawani have been shown through solo exhibitions in <Location>London</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>), at the Suha Shoman foundation, Darat Al Funun in <Location>Amman</Location> in <Location>Jordan</Location> (<Date>2006</Date>), in <Location>Palestine</Location> (<Date>2003</Date> and <Date>2004</Date>) and at the <Organization>City Museum</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> (<Date>2002</Date>). She has also taken part in group exhibitions, in particular at <Organization>Institut du Monde Arabe</Organization> in <Location>Paris</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>) and on the of occasion of the 6th and 7th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization> in the <Location>United Arab Emirates</Location> (<Date>2003</Date> and <Date>2005</Date>) as well as the <Location>Busan</Location> Biennial in <Location>Korea</Location> (<Date>2004</Date>).

Runa Islam,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/i/islam-runa</Address>
b. <Date>1970</Date>, <Location>Dhaka</Location>, <Origin><Location>Bangladesh</Location></Origin>
Lives and works in <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location>
<Date>1998</Date> MPhil, <Organization>Royal College of Art</Organization>, <Location>London</Location>
<Date>1995</Date> Rijksakademie van Beeldende Kunsten, <Location>Amsterdam</Location>, <Location>the Netherlands</Location>
Runa Islam’s work explores and challenges the structures, materiality and histories of representation and visuality, often in relation to cinematographic and architectural concerns. In her recent practice, she uses a pared-back filmic language to delve into questions of perception and the role of lens-based technologies in mediating how we see and understand the world. Her visual syntax is often so restricted that the image is all but denied; what comes to the fore is the act of looking itself. In Magical Consciousness, <Date>2010</Date>, the back of a <Origin>Japanese</Origin> folding screen serves as an allegory for the “silver screen”. This Much Is Uncertain, <Date>2009</Date>–10, relates the grain of film stock to the glittering volcanic sand found on the <Origin>Italian</Origin> island of <Location>Stromboli</Location>. Islam has held solo exhibitions at venues including Arter, <Location>Istanbul</Location>, <Location>Turkey</Location> (<Date>2012</Date>); <Organization>Museum of Modern Art</Organization>, <Location>New York</Location>, <Location>New York</Location>, <Location>USA</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>); SITE <Location>Santa Fe</Location>, <Location>New Mexico</Location>, <Location>USA</Location> (<Date>2011</Date>); Musée d’<Organization>Art</Organization> Contemporain, <Location>Montreal</Location>, <Location>Canada</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>); <Organization>Museum of Contemporary Art</Organization>, <Location>Sydney</Location>, <Location>Australia</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>); MUMOK, <Location>Vienna</Location>, <Location>Austria</Location> (<Date>2008</Date>); <Organization>Serpentine Gallery</Organization>, <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location> (<Date>2006</Date>); and the <Organization>Hammer Museum</Organization>, <Location>Los Angeles</Location>, <Location>California</Location>, <Location>USA</Location> (<Date>2005</Date>). She was nominated for the Turner Prize in <Date>2008</Date>.

Saad Bin Mohammed,http://www.artclvb.com/artist/saad-bin-mohammed</Address>
Saad Bin Mohammed was born in <Location>Jeddah</Location> in <Date>1969</Date>. Saad's paintings - the result of a tumultuous journey of self-discovery and exploration - are what he describes as 'the essence of the Creator incarnate in creation'. As Saad admits, all his works are 'recreations of what already exists'. However, with his singular style and approach, he is able to create depictions of his turbulent inner emotions and feelings that are totally unique. 'All I am aware of is a turbulent struggle; a journey, that, as soon as it's anywhere near ending, starts all over again', says Saad. Though throughout his career Saad has been influenced by myriad artists, he attests that he doesn't 'follow' anyone; and, likewise, Saad is not an artist who wants to be 'followed', either. As Saad himself notes, 'I raise the white flag and surrender to what's within me, so it can emerge naturally without obstructing its due course. That is me. No one is to judge - they should only embrace or reject'.

Saâdane Afif,http://nadour.org/artists/saadane-afif/</Address>
In his work, Saâdane Afif favours a playful yet eclectic approach, which he tends to share with other artists from across the spectrum, involving musicians along with critics and writers. His working method is based on the idea of keeping the outcome open to all possibilities throughout the production of the piece, up until the final result. Whilst moving away from a more egotistic approach the artist quotes widely from other artists, involving materials and forms in a transformation cycle which is part of an entire process: his pieces are retrieved in order to be re-interpreted by other artists, in texts, musical scores, live performances, which produces new and dynamic objects which are hard to classify. Saâdane Afif thus maintains a great freedom in his method, swinging between a formal levity and a subtlety with underlying issues. He asks that the spectator think about the space he occupies in relationship to the artwork and its status.
Saâdane Afif was born in Vendome in <Date>1970</Date>. He studied at <Organization>Bourges School of Fine Arts</Organization> before completing his post graduate course in Nîmes.
His work has been exhibited in places as varied and prestigious as the <Organization>Palais de Tokyo</Organization> in <Date>2005</Date> (<Location>Paris</Location>), the XIIth Kassel <Organization>Documenta</Organization> in <Date>2007</Date>, with his latest exhibition being held at the <Organization>Pompidou Centre</Organization> at the end of <Date>2010</Date>. Parallel to this, Saâdane Afif led a nomadic existence, residing in Marseilles, then Nice (Villa Arson) and <Location>Glasgow</Location> (Villa Medicis Hors les Murs), before choosing <Location>Berlin</Location> where he has lived since <Date>2003</Date>. He was awarded the international Prize for contemporary art by the Prince Pierre of <Organization>Monaco Foundation</Organization>, and received the Marcel Duchamp Prize in <Date>October 2009</Date>; his reward was an exhibition at the <Origin>French</Origin> Pavilion at <Location>Shanghai</Location>’s universal exhibition in <Date>2010</Date>.

Saba Innab,http://www.zaragallery.org/content/ArtistDetails.aspx?a_id=147/nSaba</Address> Innab is an artist and architect whose work is concerned with urbanism and processes of space production and re-production. Born in <Date>1980</Date>, acquired a bachelor’s degree in <Organization>Architecture- Jordan University of Science</Organization> and <Organization>Technology-</Organization> <Date>2004</Date>./nHer architectural practice in <Location>Amman</Location>- <Location>Jordan</Location> landed her recently in reconstruction of Nahr el Bared Camp. Saba's artistic practice is very much influenced by her architectural work and her examination of cities and places. In the <Date>past 7 years</Date> she has been part of regional and international exhibitions, art residencies and workshops./nIn her new exhibition, Saba Innab moves us with a new experience of forms which seem familiar, yet equally unreasonable in configuration, reminding us of an architectural building in ruins or of a dysfunctional internal structure of human civilizations, all based on something of an illusion. 
 
Conversely, the artwork captures the richness of her paintings through their simplicity, yet the complexity of the details is coated by mystery. This combination takes one into the deep sub consciousness of humanity.

Saeed Salem,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-saeedsalem.html</Address>
Saeed Salem (<Date>1984</Date>) was born and raised in <Location>Jeddah</Location>, a place where <Origin>Saudi</Origin>'s walk the sky sometimes. <Location>Salem</Location> is a photographer and has shown his art on both Flickr and deviantART using the name saeedesign. Safeya Binzagr,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-safeyabinzagr.html</Address>
Safeya Binzagr (<Date>1940</Date>) is an artist who presents her work in her own museum. The 'Darat Safeya Binzagr' which opened in Jiddah in <Date>2000</Date> celebrates both the <Origin>Saudi</Origin> and <Location>Hijaz</Location> heritage. 
'It is important for Saudis to remember, and for the West to learn. This book will be a record for the new generation,' is how Binzagr introduces <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>, an artist's view of the past (<Date>1979</Date>). She then writes: 'I don't think that I can live without painting.' She may never have tried. The many colour illustrations of her oil paintings, watercolours, pastels, drawings and etchings are grouped around the themes: marriage, traditional dress, old architecture, religion, daily life and desert life. Illustrated here from the book is a ceremony in which a groom is shaved while his mother places a gold coin on the barber's forehead and wedding musicians entertain him. A scene from the religion chapter, which the artist will not have witnessed herself, is named Al-Mahmal after a decorated camel litter which was used to ceremoniously carry the Kaaba covering for the Hajj into <Location>Mecca</Location>. The covering used to be presented by <Location>Egypt</Location> and arrived by ship through the Suez canal accompanied by a 'Prince of the Hajj,' she writes. Binzagr may have used old photographs to reconstruct this scene as she is reported to have spent much effort to research and collect photographic material from such collections as the <Organization>Royal Geographic Society</Organization> in <Location>London</Location>. She also uses her family as a source and sometimes as a model as she did with her sister for her trademark picture Zabun. The'Safeya's Mona Lisa' is a portrait of a <Origin>Saudi</Origin> lady in a traditional and unvieled dress that was still common in the 1960's in the western province of <Location>Hijaz</Location>.
Binzagr was born to a well known merchant family in Jiddah and attended school in <Location>Sussex</Location>, <Location>England</Location>. In the mid 1960's she started her career as a professional artist with a program of full time art studies in <Location>Cairo</Location>.

Sahand Hesamiyan,http://www.thethirdline.com/artists/sahand-hesamiyan/biography/</Address>

Salim al-Dabbagh,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Salim-al-Dabbagh.aspx</Address>
Salim al-Dabbagh, the renowned <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> artist printmaker, is one of a generation of artists who enriched the progress of modern art movements in <Location>Iraq</Location> dating back to <Date>the mid-1960s</Date>. Born and raised in Mosul in <Date>1941</Date>, al-Dabbagh developed a love for the traditions of his hometown, a love which soon metamorphosed into a cultural pursuit. <Date>From 1958 to 1961</Date>, al-Dabbagh studied at the <Organization>Institute of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location>. He was trained by a number of prominent modern <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> artists, including Jewad Selim, Faiq Hassan, Ismail al-Shaikhly and Khalid al-Rahhal. After obtaining his degree in painting, al-Dabbagh continued his studies at the <Organization>Academy of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> <Date>from 1961 to 1965</Date> where he was a member of the first graduating class. The faculty included modernist artists Roman Artymowski from <Location>Poland</Location> who worked with engraving and printmaking, and Burkow Lazsky from <Location>Yugoslavia</Location>, known for his mural paintings. Though trained in purely classical and realistic artistic techniques, al-Dabbagh and some of his fellow students manifested their initial daring attempts to experiment with semi-geometric compositions and artistic abstraction.
Al-Dabbagh has worked as an art and graphic design professor and served as head of the <Organization>Graphic Department</Organization> at the <Organization>Institute of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> <Date>from 1971 to 2000</Date>. He then worked at the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> Fashion <Organization>House</Organization> as an art expert. He currently devotes his time to work on his art in his atelier in <Location>Baghdad</Location>.

Saloua Raouda Choucair,http://www.tate.org.uk/context-comment/articles/life-work-choucair/nSaloua</Address> Raouda Choucair is one of the most respected living artists in <Location>Lebanon</Location>, though her work is little known outside of her home country./nShe was born in <Location>Beirut</Location> in <Date>1916</Date>. She learnt to draw and paint under the tutelage of Omar Onsi and Moustafa Farroukh, prominent <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> artists who adopted impressionist and realist styles. A trip to <Location>Egypt</Location> in <Date>1943</Date> sparked her passion for Islamic art and architecture and her conviction – despite the beliefs of her tutors – that Arab artists ‘reached into the essence of the subject, stripping it of all the associated with art since the time of the Greeks until the end of the 19th century.’/nAt the end of <Date>the 1940s</Date> Choucair spent three important years in <Location>Paris</Location> where she absorbed the current themes, trends and philosophies of European modernism. Though she was a student at the <Organization>École des Beaux-Arts</Organization> and attended the studio of the master Fernand Léger, Choucair found like-minded individuals at the <Organization>Atelier d’Art Abstrait</Organization>, a group of artists committed to the pursuit of abstract or non-objective art. The exhibition at <Organization>Tate Modern</Organization> begins with a group of vibrant gouache paintings from this period, showing the artist’s experiments with repeated, modular forms inspired by her love of geometry and mathematics.
Saloua Raouda Choucair Infinite Structure <Date>1963-5</Date>/nSaloua Raouda Choucair
Infinite Structure 1963–5/n© <Organization>Saloua Raouda Choucair Foundation</Organization>/nIn <Date>the late 1950s</Date>, working from her home studio in <Location>Beirut</Location>, Choucair began modelling in clay and carving wood. Her first series of sculptures explores the trajectory of a line. Choucair was interested in the ability of a line to follow a path that allows it to transform itself into numerous shapes. The line and curve are basic elements of the visual language that she used throughout her career, finding its way into a variety of media including painting, sculpture, textiles, murals and other domestic designs./nIn <Date>the 1960s</Date> she worked on a series known as ‘interforms’; simple cubes or blocks housing intricately carved, complex internal forms. This was followed by the series she later titled ‘poems’, modular sculptures with parts that stack together in a flexible way. Each module, like the stanzas of Arabic poetry, may stand alone or be stacked with others to be read as a whole. A further group of works are known as the ‘duals’, having two interlocking parts./nChoucair’s ideas are often worked out across various materials, and forms from her early paintings are repeated in later sculptures and in other items she made to express her belief that art should be a living, architectural reality. The exhibition brings groups of these works together, showing the rich and complex connections between pieces and exploring the artist’s belief in the power of non-objective art. An extensive display of small maquettes that Choucair made throughout her career shows fascinating ‘studies’ that reveal the artist’s impressive creative energy. One of her modular paintings from <Date>the late 1940s</Date> was pierced by shards of shattered glass in the artist’s apartment during a bombing raid in the <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> civil war of <Date>the 1980s</Date>. The object bears witness to that history and the circumstances through which Choucair not only survived, but continued to work with energy and enthusiasm./nThe final room showcases a group of experimental sculptures from <Date>the 1980s</Date> made of aluminium, plexiglass and nylon thread that relate to Choucair’s ambitions to incorporate water and movement into her works./nThroughout <Date>the 1980s</Date> and 90s Choucair received increasing recognition and awards for her work. In <Date>1982</Date> she was commissioned by the <Organization><Origin>Lebanese</Origin> Lions Club</Organization> to create a major public sculpture. The piece was installed at the southern entrance to <Location>Beirut</Location>, but was vandalised and then disappeared completely. Seif Wanly,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Seif-Wanly.aspx</Address>
Mohammed Seif al-Din Wanly was born into an aristocratic family of <Origin>Turkish</Origin> origin on his father's side, Ismaïl Bey Mohammed Wanly, and of Caucasian origin from his mother, Ismat Hanem al-Daghistani. He grew up with his four sisters and his younger brother, <Organization>Adham</Organization>, in an intellectual francophone environment. They were educated by private tutors in their family house, the Urfan <Organization>Pacha</Organization> Palace located in the neighborhood of <Date>Muharram</Date> Bey in <Location>Alexandria</Location>. Seif worked as a public official at the customs archives of Alexandria and started painting with his brother, <Organization>Adham</Organization>. In 1929, Ottorino Bicchi (<Date>1878 - 1949</Date>), an <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter from <Location>Livorno</Location>, opened a studio in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and the Wanly brothers were among his first students. After Bicchi left <Location>Egypt</Location> in <Date>1934</Date>, Seif and Adham established their own studio in Alexandria the following year together with their friends, the painter Ahmad Fahmi and the filmmaker Mohammed Bayoumi.
During the 1950's, the two brothers traveled regularly to <Location>Europe</Location> and visited <Location>France</Location>, <Location>Italy</Location> and <Location>Spain</Location> where they sketched and painted numerous scenes of ballet, opera and theater performances, as well as landscapes. When sculptor Ahmad Osman (<Date>1907 - 1970</Date>) established the <Organization>Faculty of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location> in <Date>1957</Date>, Seif was appointed professor within the painting department. In 1959, the <Organization>Ministry of Culture</Organization> commissioned the Wanly brothers along with many artists of their generation, such as Tahiya Halim and Hussein Bikar, to record the architectural heritage of Nubia before its flooding due to the construction of the High Dam in <Location>Aswan</Location>. The same year, when his brother <Organization>Adham</Organization> passed away, Seif lived through a difficult period, which was reflected in his work. At the age of sixty-eight, he married the <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> painter Ihsan Mokhtar. He died in <Date>1979</Date> in <Location>Stockholm</Location> where he was preparing an exhibition of his Scandinavian landscapes.
The Wanly brothers were very close in their life and work. They influenced one another and developed a similar style. Seif only used his first name to sign his paintings while his brother, <Organization>Adham</Organization>, signed them by the name of Wanly or E. Wanly (Edham Wanly). Together, they introduced modern pictorial trends in <Location>Alexandria</Location> and were among the first to depict international subjects, breaking away from the folklorist style of their contemporaries.
Seif was a prolific artist who produced more than a thousand paintings, as well as numerous drawings and sketches. His early works are inspired by the use of the light and gentle strokes of his <Origin>Italian</Origin> professor, Ottorino Bicchi, who was close to the <Origin>Italian</Origin> Macchiaioli and the École de Barbizon. Later in his career, Seif used larger surfaces of bold colors and exercised greater freedom in his compositions, both of which brought him closer to Fauvism. 
Seif was fascinated by the performance arts and depicted scenes of circus, ballet, opera, music concerts, bull-fighting as well as all types of sports​, including horse races. He represented the life of the performers on stage and backstage by expressing their vivid and dynamic movements. His fascination with performance arts also led him to design several sets for theater and opera productions in <Location>Egypt</Location>. He painted numerous views of traditional Nubian villages before they were flooded, as well as many landscapes of <Location>Egypt</Location> and all the countries he visited, including <Location>Spain</Location>, <Location>France</Location>, <Location>Italy</Location>, <Location>Yugoslavia</Location>, <Location>Poland</Location> and <Location>Russia</Location>. Seif is also the author of a series of self-portraits that reflect his sense of humor and derision. Following the death of his brother, <Organization>Adham</Organization>, which affected him profoundly, he introduced a darker palette of colors and shades in his paintings. His works can be seen at the Seif and <Organization>Adham Wanly Museum</Organization> hosted in the villa of the <Organization>Mahmoud Saïd Museum</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Alexandria</Location>, the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> Art in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the Mathaf <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>, as well as in numerous private collections around the world.

Shadi Ghadirian,http://ivde.net/artists/shadi_ghadirian/biography</Address>
Shadi Ghadirian’s photography takes conflicting visual signifiers and drags them into ironic yet subtly unnerving relationships with the viewer. Born in <Date>1974</Date> in <Location>Tehran</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>, Ghadirian emerged in <Date>2000</Date> among a generation of photographers prepared to tackle the confusing reality of a woman’s place in contemporary <Location>Iran</Location> and to play with understandings of the region. By placing objects of war into scenes of domestic harmony, Ghadirian’s Nil-Nil comments on the disparity between these two worlds. Some are haunting, such as the bloodstained boots discarded alongside an equally blood red set of high heel shoes, while others veer into absurdity, like the bullets that sit in a make up purse.
Like Everyday is a series of photographs depicting anonymous chador-wrapped figures with kitchen utensils instead of faces. This simple, ominous collision of potent symbols – the veil and domesticity –parodies stereotypical understanding of women of the region and universally. Qajar is a recreation of the photographic compositions and styles of the studio portraits that flourished in the Qajar dynasty, who ruled <Location>Iran</Location> from <Date>1794-1925</Date>. With fierce monobrows and period dress, Ghadirian’s models mimic the photography of that time against a painted background. But clear intrusions of modernity surface in the work, in the form of ghetto blasters and television sets. She lives and works in <Location>Tehran</Location>.

Shafic Abboud
,http://www.claude-lemand.com/artiste/shafic-abboud-2?souspage=bio</Address>
Born in <Date>1926</Date> in <Location>Lebanon</Location>, Shafic Abboud is one of the foremost Arab artists of the 20th century. His paintings are a manifesto for freedom, colour, light and joy, as well as being a permanent bridge between the art scenes of <Location>France</Location> and <Location>Lebanon</Location> and that of <Location>Europe</Location> and the <Location>Middle East</Location>. Both <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> and Parisian, he was very attached to <Location>Lebanon</Location>, to its landscapes, its light and his own childhood memories. He was from a <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> Arab Modern culture. The stories of his grandmother, who was the village’s story-<Location>teller</Location>, left an indelible mark on him, at a very early age. He was familiar with the paintings of the travelling story-tellers. The artist’s eye was also strongly influenced by Byzantine icons and traditions from his church. The writings, debates, ideals, hopes and battles characterising the Arab Nahda, a modernist and anti-clerical Renaissance which was initially driven by Arab and <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> writers, were to later have a significant impact on Abboud’s intellectual education.
Shafic Abboud arrived in <Date>1947</Date> in <Location>Paris</Location>. He blended in perfectly with the city’s artistic life, just as many other artists who had come from all over the world after the Second World War (from North and <Location>South America</Location>, <Location>Europe</Location>, <Location>Asia</Location> and <Location>North Africa</Location>). This was the second major movement of migration to <Location>Paris</Location>. <Location>France</Location>’s capital was still at the time the <Location>City</Location> of lights and the favourite destination of upcoming artists seeking for modernity, embodied by Claude Monet’s last painting period and by all the Parisian masters of the 20th century. He had a particular preference for works by Pierre Bonnard, Roger Bissière and Nicolas de Staël. Abboud’s painting gradually moved from the poetic <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> figuration towards the lyrical Parisian abstraction, followed by a move from abstraction towards a very subtle and sublime personal “abboudian transfiguration”, which was simultaneously traditional and modern, pagan and sacred.
His work is often an invitation to the joy of life, a pagan hedonism yet limited by our frail human condition. However, this does not prevent a tragic element from being present in some of his paintings. These occasionally evoke, in an obvious or subtle way, difficult situations from stages of his life or that of his friends’, the tragic events happening in <Location>Lebanon</Location>, in the Arab world and in various parts of the World. Although Abboud never overtly put forward his engagements, his oeuvre and his interviews with the Arab press reveal his opinion as well as his political and social concerns.
When I described his mature work as being ‘transfigurative’ earlier on, it seems to me that this word reflects best Abboud’s search for a synthesis between his fairy-tale like childhood world and his technical mastering of abstract Parisian painting. He sought to transcend the latter, stimulated by both Bonnard and de Staël, by giving it a soul of its own and a rich and luminous texture. Through his paintings, Abboud aimed to share his own view on both his inside and outside worlds. He transfigured images filtered from his memory into painting, such as his series of Destroyed Cafés of <Date>1990</Date>. These large colourful compositions beam the tragic reality of the war in <Location>Lebanon</Location> devastating the cafés by the sea in <Location>Beirut</Location>, which Abboud loved going to on his own or with his friends, when he used to visit every winter until <Date>1975</Date>. In a similar way, he also transfigured his memory of his friend Simone after her death, whose dresses fascinated Abboud with their various shimmering fabrics. Being neither a devout follower nor believer of any religion, Abboud was nonetheless very much influenced by the glory of the Byzantine <Origin>Greco</Origin>-Arab liturgy. Symbolically, Art triumphs over death.
Please allow me to remind you the importance of this artist. Not only the <Origin>French</Origin> but also the <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> and Arab critics acknowledged the quality of Abboud’s painting at a very early stage in his life. Furthermore, he was the first and only artist from the Arab World to participate to the first <Organization>Biennale of Paris</Organization> in <Date>1959</Date>. In <Location>Lebanon</Location>, during two decades <Date>1950-1970</Date>, he played a major role for <Location>Beirut</Location>’s cultural and artistic life. <Location>Beirut</Location> was the beam of all the Near-Eastern countries, and had experienced many fruitful hours of freedom, creativity, prosperity and a particular way of life, which contributed to its international reputation. Up to <Date>1975</Date>, Abboud was used to spending the three winter months in <Location>Lebanon</Location>. He taught at the <Organization>Lebanese University</Organization> and organised personal exhibitions in one of the best galleries of the capital. Abboud’s works were exhibited alongside the biggest names of the Parisian art scene up to 1968, and he participated to the <Organization>FIAC</Organization> in <Location>Paris</Location>, from <Date>1983</Date> onwards. In <Date>1994</Date>, after 15 years of war, the show of his oeuvre in <Location>Beirut</Location> was a huge media and commercial success. When Abboud passed away in <Date>April 2004</Date>, a moving farewell ceremony was organised at the <Location>Parc</Location> Montsouris in <Location>Paris</Location>’ 14th district, very close to where the artist had his small studio. Abboud then received a triumphant welcome, when his body was transferred to <Location>Beirut</Location> and to <Location>Mount Lebanon</Location>, where he was buried, as per his wish./n

Shahpour Pouyan,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/29-shahpour-pouyan/overview/</Address>
Shahpour Pouyan's work is a commentary about power, domination and possession through the force of culture.  His interest lies in singling out particular objects whose images captivate him, and by painting them he releases the feeling of anguish they create.
Pouyan's hooves are symbols for the aspiration of power, lonely beings with vain attempts at grandeur which are faintly ridiculous provoking mixed feelings of pity and contempt.  The works draw their inspiration from <Origin>Iranian</Origin> miniatures with references to the cow as the symbol of power in the ancient cultures of Sumer, Babylon, <Location>Iran</Location> and Hinduism, emphasising the superego of male aggression throughout the centuries.
Pouyan brings the same spirit to his projectiles, demonstrating his wry sense of humour through references to high Persian culture.  Working with traditional armourers and metal-smiths, and taking intricately decorated costume armour and military helmets, he has morphed them into the shape of modern rockets or 'projectiles'.  These suspended sculptures have an unsettling human-like experience closely resembling actors in the 'Taziyeh' (passion play) performed during the month of <Date>Muharram</Date>.
Born in <Location>Isfahan</Location>, <Location>Iran</Location>, in <Date>1979</Date>, Shahpour Pouyan currently lives and works between <Location>New York</Location> and <Location>Tehran</Location>. He previously studied Neoplatonic Philosophy at the <Origin>Iranian</Origin> <Organization>Institute of Philosophy</Organization> and received a diploma in Math and Physics from <Organization>Elmieh School</Organization>, <Location>Tehran</Location>. <Date>Between 2007 and 2009</Date> he taught art history and the history of Persian Architecture at <Organization>Science</Organization> and <Organization>Culture University</Organization>, <Location>Tehran</Location>. Pouyan has had numerous solo gallery shows including <Organization>XVA Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Dubai</Location> (<Date>2009</Date>), Sixty Six <Organization>Art</Organization> <Organization>Gallery</Organization>, <Location>Tehran</Location> (<Date>2010</Date>) and <Organization>Lawrie Shabibi</Organization> (<Date>2014</Date>), and has participated in numerous group exhibitions and art fairs around the world, most recently in the Kochi-Muziris Biennale, <Location>India</Location> (<Date>2014</Date>), UNTITLED <Organization>Art</Organization> Fair, <Location>Miami Beach</Location>, <Location>Florida</Location> (<Date>2014</Date>), the Mykonos Biennale, <Location>Greece</Location> (<Date>2013</Date>) and <Organization>Art</Organization> 13 <Location>London</Location>, <Location>UK</Location> (<Date>2013</Date>). His work has also been included in publications produced both in and out of <Location>Iran</Location> and is part of many prominent private collections and of the permanent collection of the <Organization>Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art</Organization>. He has participated in several international residencies including International Cite Des Arts, <Location>Paris</Location>, and the <Organization>Pegasus Art Foundation</Organization>, <Location>Hyderabad</Location>, <Location>India</Location>, and begins one at the <Organization>Elizabeth Foundation</Organization> for the Arts, <Location>New York</Location>, in <Date>March 2014</Date>.

Shaikha Al Mazrou,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/134-shaikha-al-mazrou/overview/</Address>

Influenced by artists from the Modernist and Bauhaus Movements - such as Paul Klee, Carle Andre and Wassily Kandinsky  - Al Mazrou uses the formal aspects of minimalism to engage with a current fascination with materiality in art. Often in her works she combines mass-produced materials - such as electronic waste or construction materials - with colour and form, experimenting with these resources to create abstract geometric arrangements. Fascinated by notions of physical space, her sculptures and installations materialise as simple gestures that emphasise the representation of tension, weight and space.

Shalima Sharbatli,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-shalimasharbatli.html</Address>
Shalima Sharbatli. So we read on the internet: in <Location>Jeddah</Location> the apples from <Location>France</Location> and the oranges from <Location>Egypt</Location> come in Sharbatli boxes and have Sharbatli stickers on them. It is no surprise then that Shalima Sharbatli informs people that she lives with art 24 hours a day. 'An instinctive <Origin>Saudi</Origin> painter,' she herself was branded by Arab News and having to juggle at a young age with a touch of paradise perhaps educated her with knowledge that needs discovery. No images of her artwork travel on the internet, but for the picture in Arab News of herself as an artist, revealing a pair of trousers usually reserved for the atelier, and in front of one of her large outside works in <Location>Jeddah</Location>. The latest news on her is that she is planning a joint exibition in <Location>Paris</Location> with two artists from <Location>France</Location> and <Location>Spain</Location>. Mitterand Jr. will open the show. It is indeed about finding - not building - bridges, but art is not an international language, as Shalima is quoted to have said in wonder of people who 'imprison' themselves in local subjects. Art needs a viewpoint. The very best artists have eyes at the back of their heads, instinctively. As she is reported to have said that the music made her proud, a closer look at Sharbatli's work will surely reveal some lines of the national anthem of <Location>Saudi Arabia</Location>. Perhaps the daring scale of her work is such a line and those visiting the government guesthouse in <Location>Jeddah</Location>, should look out for a 17 meter long wall painting and be the judge of it. The limited glimpse of her work in the Arab News photo reminds me of a <Origin>Dutch</Origin> woman of noble birth, Jacoba van Heemskerk, who's more abstract paintings were influenced by Cubism and <Origin>German</Origin> expressionism, and who started very much by painting with the brain and struggled to jump out. But that is not Shabatli. It looks like the paint jumped on her first.

Sliman Mansour,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Sliman-Mansour.aspx</Address>
Sliman Mansour is one of the most distinguished Palestinian artists working <Date>today</Date>. Throughout his forty-year career, Mansour has established himself as an internationally recognized artist dedicated to giving visual expression to Palestinian identity.
Born in <Date>1947</Date> in Birzeit, a Palestinian town north of Ramallah, Mansour studied fine arts at <Organization>Bezalel Art Academy</Organization> in <Location>Jerusalem</Location>. Since the seventies, he has contributed to the development of an iconography of the Palestinian struggle through his works on paper. Uniting Mansour's body of work is the depiction of the orange tree (considered to symbolize the 1948 Nakba), the olive tree (considered to symbolize the 1967 war), traditional Palestinian embroidery, village life, and the figure of the Palestinian woman as the mother figure figure of <Location>Palestine</Location>, giving birth to and protecting the Palestinian people. One of Mansour's most recognized works is the <Date>1974</Date> painting, Camel of Hardship. In this image, the figure of the porter bends under the weight of his satchel, which is significantly shaped like an eye and holds the city of <Location>Jerusalem</Location> as identified by the <Organization>Dome</Organization> of the <Location>Rock</Location>. Personifying <Location>Palestine</Location> through the figure of an old, weary, and isolated man, Mansour captures the concept of sumud, or steadfastness, and the continuing endurance of the struggle despite hardship. Before its international acclaim, the piece resonated locally as it was printed as posters in <Date>1975</Date> and displayed in homes and public venues throughout the <Organization>West Bank</Organization> and <Location>Gaza</Location>.
In <Date>1987</Date>, together with artists Vera Tamari, Tayseer Barakat, and Nabil Anani, Mansour founded New Visions, a collective formed in response to the first intifada (<Date>1987 - 1993</Date>). While fostering a revolutionary approach to aesthetics in Palestinian art, the artists also participated in the intifada by boycotting art supplies imported from <Location>Israel</Location>. Working instead with natural materials such as coffee, henna, and clay, the artists tied the process of art making to both the land and the struggle. This body of work documents an important moment in the history of Palestinian art. Although the artists adopted a nationalist agenda similar to other artists working in the social realist style, the distinction lies in an abstracted composition. <Organization>Art</Organization> no longer merely represented the political, but instead artistic production itself constituted a political act.
Since then, Mansour has become acclaimed for a unique body of work that uses mud as a medium. Layering and molding mud into figural compositions on a wooden framework, Mansour deploys the actual land to depict <Location>Palestine</Location>, its history, and people. Working in a variety of sizes—some pieces are life-size—the artist creates what critics have termed "emblems of decay," as the cracks and distortions of the drying process suggest the passage of time and the impermanence of materiality. In one of his most important series from <Date>1996</Date> entitled, I am Ismail, the artist molds a relief of the biblical figure into what appears as an ancient tombstone. Commemorating Ismail's story of exile and his relation to the land, Mansour suggests through the title his own autobiographical connection to the story of Ismail. The series documents the artist's continued dedication to a set of aesthetic concerns intimately related to the visualization of the Palestinian struggle in all its hardships and aspirations.
Mansour has contributed extensively to the development of an infrastructure for the fine arts in the <Organization>West Bank</Organization>. He was the head of the League of Palestinian Artists <Date>from 1986 to 1990</Date>. In <Date>1994</Date>, Mansour co-founded al-Wasiti <Organization>Art Center</Organization> in <Location>East Jerusalem</Location> and served as Director <Date>from 1995 to 1996</Date>. He is a member of the <Organization>Founding Board of Directors</Organization> of the <Organization>International Academy of Art Palestine</Organization>, established in <Date>2004</Date> in Ramallah. He has taught at numerous cultural institutions and universities throughout the <Organization>West Bank</Organization>, including <Organization>Al-Quds University</Organization>. Also a professional cartoonist, Mansour published <Date>from 1981 to 1993</Date> in Al-Fajr <Origin>English</Origin> Weekly, a Palestinian <Origin>English</Origin> weekly formerly published in <Location>Jerusalem</Location>. He is the co-author of the <Date>1998</Date> publication, Both Sides of Peace: <Origin>Israeli</Origin> and Palestinian Political Poster <Organization>Art</Organization>.

Suad Al Attar,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Suad-al-Attar.aspx</Address>
Suad al-Attar's is part of a generation of artists who benefited from the educational foundation laid by art educators like Hafidh al-Droubi and Faiq Hassan. As one of <Location>Iraq</Location>'s leading female artists, however, she is also a pioneer in her own right. Al-Attar earned degrees from the <Organization>Academy of Fine Art</Organization> in <Location>Baghdad</Location> and <Organization>California State University</Organization>. She also did graduate work in <Location>London</Location>, studying printmaking at the <Organization>Wimbledon School of Art</Organization> and the <Organization>Central School of Art</Organization> and Design. Following her studies, Al-Attar taught at the <Organization>University of Baghdad</Organization>. In 1965, the artist held a solo exhibition in <Location>Baghdad</Location>, becoming the first woman to do so. Her surreal canvases have a uniquely mysterious quality that resonate with <Location>Iraq</Location>'s rich literary past. Al-Attar is counted among the many modern and contemporary <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> artists who are committed to preserving the cultural traditions of their homeland.
Suad al-Attar became actively engaged in the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> art scene in <Date>the 1960s</Date>. However, her artistic output reached maturity in <Date>the 1970s</Date>. During this time <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> art gained unprecedented international exposure. The government frequently sponsored artists to travel for international art events and foreign artists were invited to participate in domestic art festivals and exhibitions.  Al-Attar played a major role in this outward movement exhibiting extensively in international biennials, where she won a number of awards (specifically at biennials in <Location>London</Location> in <Date>1978</Date>, <Location>Cairo</Location> in <Date>1984</Date>, <Location>Brazil</Location> in <Date>1985</Date>, and <Location>Malta</Location> in <Date>1995</Date>). Al-Attar also participated in the London-based Third World Biennale of Graphic <Organization>Art</Organization> in <Date>1980</Date> which brought together printmakers from various nations in collective exploration of the media.
Although al-Attar has lived in <Location>London</Location> since <Date>1976</Date>, she has remained faithful to the cultural heritage of her birthplace. She has embraced <Location>Iraq</Location>'s folkloric past drawing inspiration from Arab poetry, history, and mythology. Winged and composite creatures make a regular appearance as subject matter for the artist, recalling Assyrian and Sumerian visual culture. Other common motifs like palm trees, horses, and peacocks are also indicative of Mesopotamian, as well as medieval Islamic, influence. These subjects have since become powerful symbols for <Location>Iraq</Location> itself. In addition, classical and contemp​orary poetry​ of the region has been a constant source of inspiration for the artist. The ancient Mesopotamian Epic of Gilgamesh for example provided a literary backdrop for al-Attar's visual interpretations of the story's setting and characters. The artist also draws textual parallels in more obvious ways by weaving calligraphic poetry in and around her landscapes and figures.
Her vision of <Location>Iraq</Location>'s past and present is imbued with fantastical properties. Al-Attar's oeuvre is composed of a kaleidoscope of surreal landscapes, mythical creatures, and epic characters. Even the artist's portraits are infused with a dreamlike quality. The phantasmagoric nature of al-Attar's canvases con​jure imaginative tales of days past and transports the viewer to an otherworldly space. Oftentimes utilizing a monochromatic color scheme, her characters emerge from fantastic landscapes or fading architecture. They gaze out at the viewer, inviting them to participate in an emotive and epic narrative as if the audience is the ultimate interpreter of the enigmatic scene.
Encouraged by her graphic sensitivity, much of her work is flat, linear, and emblematic. Pattern and ornamentation play a central role in her compositions. It has been suggested that al-Attar developed her style based on Islamic miniatures. Although her canvases can be quite large, this influence can be clearly seen in al-Attar's treatment of plant life, her attention to minute detail, and in her use of decorative patterning. Furthermore, there seems to be an effort towards beautification and novelty of design that is ever-present in both instances.
Al-Attar's visual interpretations of poetry and folklore are deeply personal and provocative in a way that is distinct and still resonates with viewers. Although al-Attar's oeuvre can and should be viewed within the tradition modern <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> inaugurated by the work of such figures as Faiq Hassan and Jewad Selim, her art also contains introspective qualities that hint at an underlying femininity. She has developed a personalized set of symbols that disclose an intimate engagement with her subjects through self-exploration and remembrance. Derived from her childhood memories these symbols include gold for the domes of the city, a fish for the Tigris, and a rooster for life in <Location>Baghdad</Location>; all reminders of home. Indeed, Al-Attar's blending of dreamscape and reality is transformative leading the viewer to a metaphysical understanding of <Location>Iraq</Location>'s rich cultural heritage. Ultimately, however, this understanding is mediated through the artist​'s private emotive lens.
Al-Attar's more recent works continue this emotively imaginative quality, yet at the same time also engage more directly with current national realities, exploring and expressing the trauma that <Location>Iraq</Location> has suffered since <Date>the 1990s</Date>.
Al-Attar's work is held in both private and public collections, including many prestigious art institutions like the <Organization>British Museum</Organization> and the <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>, <Location>Qatar</Location>. Unfortunately, her work is also featured on the <Origin>Iraqi</Origin> <Organization>National Museum</Organization> of Modern <Organization>Art</Organization>'s Red List, meaning her work was looted from the museum in the wake of the US-led invasion.

Sulayman Al Bassam
Theatre 
SABAB - Sulayman Al Bassan Theatre,http://www.sharjahart.org/people/people-by-alphabet/b/bassam-sulayman-al</Address>
SABAB (Sulayman Al Bassam Theatre) is an independent, international touring theatre company led by celebrated <Origin>Kuwaiti</Origin> writer/director Sulayman Al Bassam. 
Based in <Location>Kuwait</Location> and working internationally across national and cultural boundaries, SABAB uses theatre to engage with issues of identity, history, language and culture. The aim of SABAB’s work is to establish new spaces of action and reflection inside the contemporary Arab world and beyond it. SABAB uses as raw material the points of articulation - literary, historical, geo-political and imagined - that link the Arab World to a wider global context, and seeks to initiate new ones through its theatrical process.
Working alongside <Location>UK</Location> producer Georgina Van Welie, with an ensemble of pan Arab and international actors, musicians and designers, SABAB's productions are characterised by a radical approach to text, bold production styles and playful, provocative combinations of content and form.
The company has achieved worldwide acclaim and recognition for its productions, performing to audiences across four continents. Recent work includes: Richard III: An Arab Tragedy, commissioned by the <Organization>Royal Shakespeare Company</Organization> (<Organization>RSC</Organization>) for the Complete Works Festival; The Mirror for Princes / Kalila wa Dimna co-produced by the <Organization>Tokyo International</Organization> Arts Festival, <Location>Barbican</Location> bite06 and <Location>Dar</Location> al Athar al Islamiyyah, <Location>Kuwait</Location>; and The Al-Hamlet Summit, co-produced by the <Organization>Tokyo International</Organization> Arts Festival.
Sulayman Al-Bassam was born in <Location>Kuwait</Location> in <Date>1972</Date> and graduated from the <Organization>University of Edinburgh</Organization> in <Date>1994</Date>. He founded Zaoum Theatre in <Location>London</Location> in <Date>1996</Date>, from which emerged the Arabic production platform of the Al Bassam Theatre, in <Location>Kuwait</Location> in <Date>2002</Date>.
<Date>October 2010</Date>

Tagreed Al-Bagshi,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-tagreedalbaghsi.html</Address>
Tagreed Al-Bagshi (<Date>1975</Date>) from Ahsa holds a <Organization>BA</Organization> in science and education and is a supervisor in the education of girls. She knows how to handle paint and learned to do so in painting classes given in Damman, Qatif and <Location>Syria</Location>. As a painter she has steadily been building a body of work, that shows she got to know the classics of modern art, which fit very well <Origin>Saudi</Origin> concepts that there is not much gain in trying to depict nature-true with paint. It is the modern abstaction which accepts gracefully our own failure at creation and makes the best of it. So at least could be a vision of art. A very frank Al-Bagshi shares with us however her first efforts of <Date>2001</Date> in her on-line gallery, which indicate she moved from a romantic sea shore vision to the inner thoughts of humans, often ruled by the moon; in form not unlike those caught in stone by Modigliani. It is in <Date>2007</Date> that suddenly again the sun appears and her paintings flow with colour. Then too, all figurative efforts sometimes dissolve as they did in two painted boards. It looks like the artist can now handle with wise ease anything that may sweep ashore in <Location>the Persian Gulf</Location>. 
Tagreed Al-Bagshi has had solo exhibitions in both Riyadh and <Location>Jeddah</Location> and has joined numerous exhibitions abroad to show and promote Arab culture.

Talal Al-Zeid,http://www.greenboxmuseum.com/sa-talalalzeid.html</Address>
Talal Al-Zeid (<Date>1981</Date>) has a website which repeats three times an opening statement: that we should never judge a painting by its colour. Yes, that we should never judge a painting by its colour. And readers who agree with Talal should never judge a painting by its colour. As long as they remember that when the sky is blue it might not rain.
Talal is one of those much travelled <Origin>Saudi</Origin>'s who has set up camp again in <Location>Riyadh</Location> and it seems that he has rediscovered the austere black-and-white fashion of local wisdom among the many flags of the world. Those flags perhaps, one may agree, advertise no more than biscuits. They are all biscuits (<Date>2009</Date>) it reads in mirror image in his paint on paper work of similar title. It is only the idea that tastes well in this work of art, so it is in essence no different from the world's oldest calligraphy. And actually it is a very funny idea. Imagine a gathering of officially dressed <Origin>Saudi</Origin> males and then allow on stage Talal's simple thought about biscuits.
'Being unoriginal is <Date>today</Date>'s "Pandemic," is another statement the artist allows pride of place on his website. So is the artist himself original? Graffitti and armed comics are the shoulders on which Talal's art stands, but his stance is not just a love affair with this underground smell. His stones are thrown with measured intelligence and with a genuine interest in the many faces of humanity. One day we may wake up finding the artist has become an official in the foreign office and has forgiven even the spoilt brats who appear to irritate him. One wonders if he writes Arabic too.Talal exhibited his work at <Organization>Oasis Magazine</Organization>'s first "O" exhibition in <Date>2010</Date>. (<Date>2010</Date>).

Tanbak,http://www.beirutexhibitioncenter.com/learn/artist/tanbak</Address> 
Born and raised in <Location>Beirut</Location>, Tanbak left her native country at the age of eighteen to study <Origin>Spanish</Origin> literature in <Location>Madrid</Location> and international relations at <Organization>Georgetown University</Organization> in <Location>Washington</Location>, <Location>D.C.</Location> She later settled in <Location>Paris</Location>, and is now based in <Location>Beirut</Location>.
Tanbak initially sought to become an author. However, the <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> civil war left her profoundly marked, and she found that she could best deal with her traumas through the power of the image. She thus embarked on an artistic career as an autodidact, painting and creating installations using every object she could find that inspired her. Tanbak’s choice of materials thus corresponds to her desire to encompass all aspects of her daily life. She exploits the expressive possibilities of paint, watercolour, paper, glue, but also of more unusual materials such as trash or old buttons. Her art combines a variety of medias and textures to inspire a reflection on the eternal cycle of life and death, to provoke a meditation on the real meaning of art and show how a human body can move and relate to others. 
Tanbak regularly exhibits in <Location>Paris</Location>, <Location>London</Location> and <Location>Beirut</Location>, in individual and collective exhibitions./n

Born in <Location>Kuwait</Location> in <Date>1962</Date>, Tarek Al-Ghoussein’s position as a Palestinian <Origin>Kuwaiti</Origin> shapes the dominant themes of identity, displacement, and structural and political control prominent in much of his work. Guggenheim Museum, <Location>New York</Location>; <Organization>Mori Art Museum</Organization>, <Location>Tokyo</Location>; the <Organization>Sharjah Art Foundation</Organization>, <Location>Sharjah</Location>, <Location>UAE</Location>; <Organization>Mathaf Museum</Organization>, <Location>Qatar</Location>; and the <Organization>Barjeel Art Foundation</Organization>, <Location>Sharjah</Location>, among others. His work has been shown internationally at the <Organization>Sharjah Art Museum</Organization>, <Location>Sharjah</Location>; the 53rd <Organization>Venice Biennale</Organization>, <Location>Venice</Location>; the 6th <Organization>Sharjah Biennial</Organization>, <Location>Sharjah</Location>; the <Organization>Royal Photography Museum</Organization>, <Location>Copenhagen</Location>; Aperture Gallery, <Location>New York</Location>.

Wafa Hourani,http://nadour.org/artists/wafa-hourani/</Address>
Born in <Date>1979</Date> in <Location>Hebron</Location> in <Location>Palestine</Location>, Wafa Hourani now lives and works in Ramallah. Deeply marked by the <Origin>Israeli</Origin>-Palestinian conflict and the future of the <Location>Middle East</Location>, the artist develops a work which reveals the social, political and economical context of life in <Location>Palestine</Location>.
Graduate from the school of Art and Cinema in <Location>Tunis</Location>, he first directed films before shifting to a visual production in <Date>2006</Date>. According to him, this is a more suited format to express the Palestinian question. Using photography and sculpture, he has been creating environments revealing a reality in which past and future are intrinsically linked.
Integral part of the Photolife project, the Qalandia series (<Date>2006-2009</Date>) particularly expresses the involvement of the artist through the vision of a Palestinian reality projected a hundred years after the great events of its history: the Palestinian exodus (Qalandia 2047), the six-day war (Qalandia 2067) and the first Intifada (Qalandia 2087). Emblematic of the artist production, the works which reconstitutes one of the main check-points and Palestinian refugee camps as an architectural model were (separately) exhibited at the 1st <Location>Thessaloniki</Location> biennial in <Date>2007</Date>, and in <Date>2009</Date> at "Unveiled: New Art from the <Location>Middle East</Location>" at the Saatchi Gallery in <Location>London</Location>, the 11th <Location>Istanbul</Location> biennial and at "Disorientation II" in <Location>Abu Dhabi</Location>.

Wafaa Bilal,http://www.lawrieshabibi.com/artists/70-wafaa-bilal/overview/</Address>
Known internationally for his on-line performative and interactive works, Bilal's thought provoking works deal with international politics and internal dynamics often using his body as the canvas.  His most recent and provocative work 3rdi involved surgically implanting a camera on the back of his head to spontaneously transmit images to the web 24 hours a day - a statement on surveillance, the mundane and the things we leave behind. Bilal's <Date>2010</Date> work "....And Counting" similarly used his own body as a medium. Yazid Oulab,http://nadour.org/artists/yazid-oulab/</Address>
Informed by the issues surrounding <Location>Western Art</Location>, drawing from a literary and poetic tradition, the work of Yazid Oulab is a quest for meaning. In his sculptures, videos, installations and also his drawings, the artist declines an iconography linked to his own experience: everyday objects (jars, scales, crates, carpets) , sometimes with a sacred association (incense sticks, sacrificial knives), or to the building trade which he practised in order to finance his studies (trowel, carpenter’s pencil, scaffolding).
Simple, pared down, the forms he creates can never be reduced to mere signs however, since their physicality and the gestures they elicit hold a power and nobility of their own. The artist’s work bridges the gap between feeling and symbolism, symbol and text, craft and ritual, it accompanies a move towards spiritual knowledge, going beyond surface appearance.

He has taken part in numerous exhibitions at major institutions such as the <Organization>Centre Georges Pompidou(Paris)</Organization> The Grand Palais (<Location>Paris</Location>), the Musée des Abattoirs (<Location>Toulouse</Location>), the MUDAM (<Origin><Location>Luxembourg</Location></Origin>) and the MNAC (<Location>Bucharest</Location>).
