Younès Rahmoun,http://nadour.org/artists/younes-rahmoun/</Address>
Younès Rahmoun was born in <Date>1975</Date> in <Location>Tetouan</Location>, in <Location>Morocco</Location>, where he currently lives and works. He studied at the <Organization>National Fine Arts Institute</Organization> of the city and set up his workshop, in <Date>1998</Date>, in a small room of the family house which later inspired his series of installations Ghorfa.
In an obvious simplicity of materials and forms and whatever the formats (video, installation, performance), Younès Rahmoun evokes a personal universe, intrinsically connected to Sufi thought and practice. He makes them accessible, willing to trigger an exchange, a meeting and a dialogue. A certain number of codes and practices can be found in his work – including repetition, incantation, insistence, concentration, the orientation of his installations towards <Location>Mecca</Location>, the use of sacred numbers, or the use of green light - which invite the visitor to experience immateriality.
As opposed to cultural and identity remoteness, the concern of Younès Rahmoun manifests itself as the expression of a presence in the world. Between the use of new technologies and the appropriation of techniques resulting from the most local craft, the artist syntheses a context in order to highlight what is related to a specific space/time. Presented on the international scene through several major exhibitions and biennials, such as the Canaries, Pontevedra, <Location>Dakar</Location> or <Location>Singapore</Location> Biennials, his work spreads a universal message of intimate and interpersonal communion.

Youssef Kamel,http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org/en/bios/Pages/Youssef-Kamel.aspx</Address>
Youssef Kamel was born in the neighborhood of El-Dahir in <Location>Cairo</Location>. In 1908, he was among the first students to join the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> together with artists Mahmoud Mokhtar (<Date>1891 - 1934</Date>), Ragheb Ayad (<Date>1892 - 1982</Date>), Antoine Haggar (<Date>1896 - 1962</Date>) and Mohammed Hassan (<Date>1892 - 1961</Date>). The School was founded the same year by Prince Youssef Kamal. Kamel studied in the painting section under the <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter Paolo Forcella. He graduated in <Date>1911</Date> and the same year, and participated in the first exhibition of the students of the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> held at the <Organization>Automobile Club</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. In 1912, he was appointed as a drawing teacher in secondary schools. <Date>Between 1921 and 1922</Date>, Kamel and his friend, the painter Ragheb Ayad agreed on an exchange, according to which each of them would work in turns as a teacher for one year to finance the other's stay in <Location>Italy</Location>.
In 1925, Kamel received a scholarship to pursue his studies at the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location> together with his colleagues, Ragheb Ayad and Mohammed Hassan. He shared a studio with them in <Location>Rome</Location> and studied under the renowned <Origin>Italian</Origin> painter Umberto Coromaldi (<Date>1870 - 1948</Date>). During that period, he executed several copies of masterpieces in the collection of the Villa Borghese and painted a series of vedute, <Origin>Italian</Origin> townscape views, featuring Roman antique and Renaissance monuments, a genre he would later transpose to medieval <Location>Cairo</Location>. After receiving his diploma from the <Organization>Royal Academy</Organization> of Fine <Organization>Arts</Organization> in <Location>Rome</Location>, Kamel returned to his homeland in <Date>1929</Date> and was appointed professor of painting at the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. In 1937, he became the head of the painting section when the Alexandrian painter and diplomat, Mohammed Naghi (<Date>1888 - 1956</Date>), was director of this institution. Kamel also worked as a curator and directed the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> Art <Date>from 1948 to 1949</Date> before he was named director of the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location> <Date>between 1950 and 1953</Date>.
Youssef Kamel belongs to a generation of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> artists commonly referred to as the pioneers (al-ruwwād), as they were the first to be educated in artistic institutions established according to European models, such as the <Organization>School of Fine Arts</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>. Kamel remained faithful to the lessons of his two <Origin>Italian</Origin> teachers, Paolo Forcella and Umberto Coromaldi, who were both followers of the Machiaioli movement. They introduced him to the technique of oil painting and the genres of landscape, nudes and portraits, which Kamel adapted to <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> subjects. His work expresses a sense of peacefulness and nostalgic timelessness through the use of light strokes and gentle colors. Kamel also portrayed some of his contemporaries and friends with great sincerity, such as the sculptor Mahmoud Mokhtar as well as individuals from the countryside and the working-class neighborhoods of <Location>Cairo</Location>. His works can be found in private collections, the <Organization>Museum of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> Modern</Organization> Art in <Location>Cairo</Location>, the <Organization>Agricultural Museum</Organization> in <Location>Cairo</Location>, as well as in the Mathaf: <Organization>Arab Museum of Modern Art</Organization> in <Location>Doha</Location>. Unfortunately, on the <Date>20th of July 2012</Date>, an important collection of his works was stolen, following a looting in his family villa in the neighborhood of Matariya in <Location>northern Cairo</Location> where many of his paintings were preserved.

Youssef Nabil,http://nadour.org/artists/youssef-nabil-bio/</Address>
Brought up on the great era of <Origin>Egyptian</Origin> cinema Youssef Nabil retains a feeling of nostalgia for the glamorous aestheticism of the ‘40s and ‘50s. Born in <Location>Egypt</Location> in <Date>1972</Date>, he grew up in the streets of <Location>Cairo</Location> where hand-painted cinema posters gave the walls a timeless elegance, whilst classics from a past era shown on television were to inspire his first love of the big screen.

Zena El Khalil uses a very personal visual language, marked by disillusion, irony and romance. Her universe illustrates the madness and contrasts of a city like <Location>Beirut</Location>, where war is always latent and where bombs punctuate people’s existence.
Her large scale painting or installation compositions bring together a whole set of war memorabilia, objects and iconographies from the seventies to the present days. There, Zena juxtaposes large pink fabrics where plastic tanks and Kalashnikovs decorated with spangles are entangled within numerous cheap artefacts. They reflect the “other” obsessions which haunt young <Origin>Lebanese</Origin> women living under threat; the search for a husband, plastic surgery, pop stars, etc. These alternative concerns are strongly recommended for their powerful sedative power.
